document_info.title: Qualified Health Plan (QHP) Certification Updates for the Federally-facilitated Exchange (FFE) and State-based Exchanges on the Federal Platform (SBE-FPs) in Response to City of Columbus v. Kennedy, No. 25-cv-2114-BAH (D.Md.) (PDF)

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document provides updates on Qualified Health Plan (QHP) certification for the Federally-facilitated Exchange (FFE) and State-based Exchanges on the Federal Platform (SBE-FPs) in response to a court order in City of Columbus v. Kennedy. The court has stayed the implementation of certain provisions of the Marketplace Integrity and Affordability Final Rule, affecting plan designs and certification processes for Plan Year 2026. Issuers must revise their plan designs and submit updated rate and form filings to comply with the court's order, particularly regarding actuarial value calculations.

next_steps.action: Revise plan designs and submit updated rate and form filings

key_requirements: Revise QHP plan designs to comply with court-ordered actuarial value ranges
Submit updated rate and form filings during the specified Data Change Window

source_citations.context:
deadlines.  
 
Form Review  
Issuers in states where CMS is directly enforcing the Affordable Care Act (ACA)  market -
wide reforms  (MO, OK, TN, TX, and WY) must review all forms and templates included in 
Tables 1 and 2 of CMS’s Form Filing Instructions for SERFF  for Plan Year 2026 (Form Filing 
Instructions). 7F8 This includes any forms and templates that are listed as required for non -
QHPs only (e.g., the Plans & Beneﬁts Template and the Results of the Actuarial Value 
Calculator). If any materials listed in these tables require revisions in response to the court’s order , the issuer must send CMS a request to reopen the ﬁling, via SERFF, in 
accordance with the directions for acknowledged/closed ﬁlings under Section IX. 
Coordination with State Reviewers of the Form Filing Instructions.  This includes providing a 
description of and reason for the changes made  (e.g., August 22, 2025, City of Columbus v. 
Kennedy court order ), including the corresponding document names, impact

source_citations.context:
QHP Application Data Change Window   
 During the September 30 – October 1 Data Change Window, affected issuers are 
required to make all QHP application data changes needed to account for the 
narrowing of  the actuarial value de minimis ranges as required by the court’s order. 
However, all QHP issuers can request and make approved changes to their plan data. 
Issuers will not be approved to change a plan’s metal level or add new plans.  
 In the coming days, CMS will notify affected issuers and states of the applicable plan 
variants that require updating. So long as the August 22, 2025, District Court  order  is in 
effect, CMS cannot certify a QHP with an actuarial value that does not comply with the de 
minimis ranges in effect under the court’s order.   Issuer Action Required  
Issuers in FFE states and states performing plan management functions are required to submit and receive approval on a Data Change Request  to enter the Data Change 
Window. Instructions for submitting

source_citations.context:
QHP Application Data Change Window   
 During the September 30 – October 1 Data Change Window, affected issuers are 
required to make all QHP application data changes needed to account for the 
narrowing of  the actuarial value de minimis ranges as required by the court’s order. 
However, all QHP issuers can request and make approved changes to their plan data. 
Issuers will not be approved to change a plan’s metal level or add new plans.  
 In the coming days, CMS will notify affected issuers and states of the applicable plan 
variants that require updating. So long as the August 22, 2025, District Court  order  is in 
effect, CMS cannot certify a QHP with an actuarial value that does not comply with the de 
minimis ranges in effect under the court’s order.   Issuer Action Required  
Issuers in FFE states and states performing plan management functions are required to submit and receive approval on a Data Change Request  to enter the Data Change 
Window. Instructions for submitting

Window), during which  FFE and SBE -FP issuers seeking certiﬁcation of QHPs may  reﬁle 
their QHP plan data  submission  for plans with actuarial values that comply with the court’s 
order. 5F6 Issuers can then submit revised Rates Table Templates and other QHP application 
materials to CMS Plan Management during the  September 30  – October 1, 2025,  Data 
Change  Window

document_info.title: Additional Guidance on Qualified Health Plan Certification and City of Columbus v. Kennedy (PDF)

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document provides guidance on the Qualified Health Plan (QHP) certification process in response to the City of Columbus v. Kennedy case. It requires issuers to revise their QHP applications, rate filings, and form filings to comply with a court order affecting actuarial value policy. The guidance also allows for adjustments due to expanded access to catastrophic coverage and other state or CMS-approved reasons. The revisions are necessary to maintain market stability despite operational challenges.

next_steps.action: Revise QHP applications, rate filings, and form filings

key_requirements: Revise QHP applications to comply with court order
Submit updated filings for expanded catastrophic coverage

document_info.title: Information regarding City of Columbus v. Kennedy, No. 25-cv-2114-BAH (D.Md.) (PDF)

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document discusses a court order staying the implementation of certain provisions of the Marketplace Integrity and Affordability Final Rule due to ongoing litigation in City of Columbus v. Kennedy. These provisions, initially set to take effect on August 25, 2025, include changes to premium requirements, coverage policies, and eligibility verification processes. The Department of Justice has filed motions to stay the order concerning the actuarial value policy.

next_steps.action: Monitor the outcome of the appeal and adjust compliance strategies accordingly.

key_requirements: Stay on $5 monthly premium for non-compliance with eligibility updates
Stay on pre-enrollment eligibility verification for special enrollment periods

document_info.title: Guidance on Hardship Exemptions for Individuals Ineligible for Advance Payment of the Premium Tax Credit or Cost-sharing Reductions Due to Income, and Streamlining Exemption Pathways to Coverage (PDF)

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document provides guidance on hardship exemptions for individuals ineligible for advance payment of the premium tax credit or cost-sharing reductions due to income, allowing them to enroll in catastrophic coverage. It aims to address rising health insurance premiums by expanding access to affordable coverage options. The guidance also outlines the process for streamlining exemption applications through HealthCare.gov and paper applications, without altering current CMS regulations.

next_steps.action: Review and understand the new hardship exemption criteria and application process.

key_requirements: Understand the criteria for hardship exemptions due to income ineligibility for APTC or CSRs.
Familiarize with the streamlined application process for catastrophic coverage.

document_info.title: CMS Issues Guidance to Strengthen Oversight of Medicaid Financing

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has issued guidance to strengthen oversight of Medicaid financing by limiting healthcare-related taxes and closing a tax loophole. This initiative is projected to save taxpayers $200 billion over the next decade. The guidance aligns with the Working Families Tax Cuts legislation and aims to restore fiscal integrity by prohibiting new or increased healthcare-related taxes and ending practices that allowed states to improperly draw federal funds. Transition periods are provided for states to comply with the new requirements.

next_steps.action: Review and adjust state Medicaid financing structures to comply with new tax limits.
next_steps.timeline: By the end of state fiscal year 2026 for managed care organizations and 2028 for other tax classes.

key_requirements: Prohibition of new or increased healthcare-related taxes.
Closure of provider tax loophole by specified transition periods.

financial_impact.estimated_cost: Potential savings of $200 billion over 10 years

primary_analysis.compliance_deadline: End of state fiscal year 2026 for managed care organizations and 2028 for other tax classes

CMS Issues Guidance to Strengthen Oversight of Medicaid Financing
New limits on health care-related taxes and closure of a tax loophole projected to save taxpayers $200 billion over 10 years
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is issuing preliminary guidance for states regarding the implementation of new federal requirements on health care-related (provider) taxes in Medicaid. Providing this guidance now allows states time to plan their efforts to meet the requirements laid out in the Working Families Tax Cuts legislation (Public Law 119-21) while CMS develops additional policies, guidance, and implementing regulations. The letter sent today provides details regarding limits on new or increased healthcare-related taxes. It also includes information about transition periods related to the closure of a financing loophole and the next steps for compliance.
In line with the changes made under the WFTC legislation, CMS will generally prohibit new or incre

document_info.title: 2026 Medicare Parts A & B Premiums and Deductibles
document_info.date: 2026 Medicare Parts A & B Premiums and Deductibles 2026 Medicare Part D Income-Related Monthly Adjustment Amounts On November 14, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) released the 2026 premiums, deductibles, and coinsurance amounts for the Medicare Part A and Part B programs, and

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) announced the 2026 premiums, deductibles, and coinsurance amounts for Medicare Parts A and B. Part A inpatient hospital deductible will increase to $1,736, while Part B standard monthly premium will rise to $202.90. The adjustments are due to projected price changes and utilization increases. Income-related monthly adjustments for Part B will affect high-income beneficiaries, with premiums varying based on income levels.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect new Medicare premiums and deductibles.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new rates
Communicate changes to patients and staff

financial_impact.estimated_cost: Varies by facility size and patient volume

2026 Medicare Parts A & B Premiums and Deductibles
2026 Medicare Part D Income-Related Monthly Adjustment Amounts
On November 14, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) released the 2026 premiums, deductibles, and coinsurance amounts for the Medicare Part A and Part B programs, and the 2026 Medicare Part D income-related monthly adjustment amounts.
Medicare Part A Premium and Deductible
Medicare Part A covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice, inpatient rehabilitation, and some home health care services. Approximately 99% of Medicare beneficiaries do not have a Part A premium since they have at least 40 quarters of Medicare-covered employment, as determined by the Social Security Administration.
The Medicare Part A inpatient hospital deductible that beneficiaries pay if admitted to the hospital will be $1,736 in 2026, an increase of $60 from $1,676 in 2025. Part A inpatient hospital deductible covers beneficiaries’ share of cos

document_info.title: CMS Announces New Drug Payment Model to Strengthen Medicaid and Better Serve Vulnerable Americans

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has introduced the GENEROUS Model, a new drug payment initiative aimed at reducing prescription drug costs in Medicaid by aligning prices with those in select other countries. This model, launching in 2026, allows CMS to negotiate lower drug prices with manufacturers and encourages state Medicaid programs to adopt uniform coverage criteria. The initiative seeks to improve access to medications and ensure fair pricing, ultimately benefiting vulnerable populations and preserving Medicaid funds.

next_steps.action: Review the Request for Applications (RFA) for drug manufacturers interested in the GENEROUS Model.
next_steps.timeline: Before the application deadline set by CMS

next_steps.action: Submit letters of intent if interested in participating in the GENEROUS Model.

key_requirements: State Medicaid programs must express interest and formally apply to participate.
Drug manufacturers need to apply and be accepted to participate in the model.

document_info.title: All 50 States Seek to Transform Rural Health with CMS

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) announced that all 50 states have applied for the $50 billion Rural Health Transformation Program, aimed at improving rural healthcare. This initiative, under the Working Families Tax Cuts legislation, seeks to expand access, enhance quality, and improve patient outcomes through state-driven innovation. The program focuses on strategic goals such as supporting rural health innovations, ensuring sustainable access, workforce development, innovative care models, and tech innovation.

next_steps.action: Submit complete and compliant applications for CMS review

key_requirements: Complete application submission
Compliance with Notice of Funding Opportunity requirements

All 50 States Seek to Transform Rural Health with CMS
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) today announced that all 50 states submitted applications for the $50 billion Rural Health Transformation Program—a landmark initiative created under the
Working Families Tax Cuts legislation
[Public Law 119-21] to strengthen health care across rural America.
The application period, open from September 15 through November 5, 2025, invited every state to design a plan for transforming its rural health care system. Each proposal must outline how states intend to expand access, enhance quality, and improve outcomes for patients through sustainable, state-driven innovation.
“When every state steps up to strengthen rural health, it shows the true character of our nation,”
said Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.
“Rural families have been left behind—driving hours for care or going without it entirely. This program restores fairness and brings qua

document_info.title: CMS Modernizes Payment Accuracy and Significantly Cuts Spending Waste

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is implementing changes to the Medicare Physician Fee Schedule for 2026 to enhance payment accuracy and reduce unnecessary spending. Key measures include a -2.5% efficiency adjustment for certain services, a new payment model for chronic disease management, and significant reductions in spending on skin substitutes. These changes aim to improve care quality, promote preventive health, and ensure better use of Medicare funds.

next_steps.action: Review and adjust billing practices to align with the new efficiency adjustments and payment models.

key_requirements: Implement efficiency adjustments for select services
Adopt new payment model for chronic disease management

CMS Modernizes Payment Accuracy and Significantly Cuts Spending Waste while Improving Chronic Disease Management for Medicare Beneficiaries
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is increasing quality of care for Medicare beneficiaries while significantly reducing unnecessary spending and promoting payment accuracy. The calendar year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule (PFS) final rule advances primary care management through improved quality measures, reduces waste and unnecessary use of skin substitutes, and introduces a new payment model focused on improving care for chronic disease management.
“The new Medicare fee schedule delivers a major win for seniors, protects hometown doctors, and safeguards American taxpayers,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. “It realigns doctor incentives and helps move our country from a sick-care system to a true health care system.”

CMS Modernizes Payment Accuracy and Significantly Cuts Spending Waste while Improving Chronic Disease Management for Medicare Beneficiaries
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is increasing quality of care for Medicare beneficiaries while significantly reducing unnecessary spending and promoting payment accuracy. The calendar year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule (PFS) final rule advances primary care management through improved quality measures, reduces waste and unnecessary use of skin substitutes, and introduces a new payment model focused on improving care for chronic disease management.
“The new Medicare fee schedule delivers a major win for seniors, protects hometown doctors, and safeguards American taxpayers,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. “It realigns doctor incentives and helps move our country from a sick-care system to a true health care system.”

document_info.title: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F)
document_info.date: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F) On October 31, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) issued a final rule that announces final policy changes for Medicare payments under the Physician Fee Schedule (PFS), and other Medicare Part B

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CY 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule introduces changes to Medicare payments under the Physician Fee Schedule, effective January 1, 2026. It includes separate conversion factors for qualifying and non-qualifying APM participants, with updates of +0.75% and +0.25% respectively. The rule also finalizes updates to geographic practice cost indices and malpractice RVUs, and introduces an efficiency adjustment to work RVUs to address overinflated time assumptions in service valuations.

next_steps.action: Review and adjust billing practices to align with new conversion factors and efficiency adjustments.

key_requirements: Adopt new conversion factors for APM participants
Implement efficiency adjustments to work RVUs

Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F)
On October 31, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) issued a final rule that announces final policy changes for Medicare payments under the Physician Fee Schedule (PFS), and other Medicare Part B issues, effective on or after January 1, 2026.
The calendar year (CY) 2026 PFS final rule is one of several final rules that reflect a broader Administration-wide strategy to create a health care system that results in better quality, efficiency, empowerment, and innovation for all Medicare beneficiaries.
Background on the Physician Fee Schedule
Since 1992, Medicare payment has been made under the PFS for the services of physicians and other billing professionals. Physicians’ services paid under the PFS are furnished in a variety of settings, including physician offices, hospitals, ambulatory surgical centers (ASCs), skilled nursing facilities and other post-acute care setti
source_citations.document_title: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F)

source_citations.claim: It includes separate conversion factors for qualifying and non-qualifying APM participants, with updates of +0
source_citations.supporting_text:
CY 2026 PFS Rate Setting and Conversion Factor
As required by statute, beginning in CY 2026, there will be two separate conversion factors: one for qualifying alternative payment model (APM) participants (QPs) and one for physicians and practitioners who are not QPs. The changes to the PFS conversion factors for CY 2026 include these updates as required by statute, a one-year increase of +2

Per statutory requirements, we are also finalizing updates to the geographic practice cost indices (GPCIs) and malpractice RVUs. [1]
In order to mitigate these effects and take into account changes in medical practice, we are finalizing application of an efficiency adjustment to the work RVUs and corresponding intraservice portion of physician time for non-time-based services that we expect to accrue gains in efficiency over time

document_info.title: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F) Medicare Shared Savings Program Changes
document_info.date: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F) Medicare Shared Savings Program Changes On October 31, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) issued the calendar year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule (PFS) final rule (CMS-1832-F) that

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CY 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule final rule introduces changes to the Medicare Shared Savings Program, aiming to enhance chronic disease management, resource efficiency, and innovation. Key changes include reducing the duration for ACOs in a one-sided model, modifying eligibility and financial reconciliation requirements, and updating quality performance standards. The rule also addresses extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policies and requires ACOs to report changes in participant and affiliate lists.

next_steps.action: Review and adjust ACO participation strategies to align with new one-sided model duration limits.
Update quality reporting processes to comply with revised standards and definitions.
Implement systems to report changes in ACO participant and SNF affiliate lists.

key_requirements: ACOs must transition to two-sided risk models within 5 years.
ACOs must report changes in participant and affiliate lists during the performance year.

Medicare Shared Savings Program Changes
On October 31, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) issued the calendar year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule (PFS) final rule (CMS-1832-F) that includes changes to the Medicare Shared Savings Program (Shared Savings Program) to allow for timely improvements to program policies and operations. The Trump Administration is committed to ensuring that participation in the Shared Savings Program will promote better chronic disease management and prevention, more efficient use of resources, promote innovation, and drive increased savings for the Medicare Trust Funds.
As of January 1, 2025, the Shared Savings Program has 477 Accountable Care Organizations (ACOs) with over 650,000 healthcare providers providing care to over 11.2 million people with Traditional Medicare. We continue to gain experience with and observe the impac
source_citations.document_title: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F) Medicare Shared Savings Program Changes

source_citations.context:
evise the Definition of a “Beneficiary Eligible for Medicare CQMs”
We are finalizing to revise the definition of a beneficiary eligible for Medicare CQMs, as proposed, for performance year 2025 and subsequent performance years, to require at least one primary care service with a date of service during the applicable performance year from an ACO professional who is a primary care physician or who has one of the specialty designations included in § 425.402(c), or who is a physician assistant, nurse practitioner, or clinical nurse specialist.
Revising the definition of a beneficiary eligible for Medicare CQMs reduces ACOs’ burden in the patient matching necessary to report Medicare CQMs because the list of beneficiaries eligible for Medicare CQMs will have greater overlap with the list of beneficiaries that are assignable to an ACO.

source_citations.document_title: Calendar Year (CY) 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Final Rule (CMS-1832-F) Medicare Shared Savings Program Changes

source_citations.context:
evise the Definition of a “Beneficiary Eligible for Medicare CQMs”
We are finalizing to revise the definition of a beneficiary eligible for Medicare CQMs, as proposed, for performance year 2025 and subsequent performance years, to require at least one primary care service with a date of service during the applicable performance year from an ACO professional who is a primary care physician or who has one of the specialty designations included in § 425.402(c), or who is a physician assistant, nurse practitioner, or clinical nurse specialist.
Revising the definition of a beneficiary eligible for Medicare CQMs reduces ACOs’ burden in the patient matching necessary to report Medicare CQMs because the list of beneficiaries eligible for Medicare CQMs will have greater overlap with the list of beneficiaries that are assignable to an ACO.

document_info.title: Plan Year 2026 Marketplace Plans and Prices Fact Sheet
document_info.date: Plan Year 2026 Marketplace Plans and Prices Fact Sheet The Health Insurance Marketplace ® Open Enrollment Period for plan year 2026 begins on November 1, 2025, and runs until January 15, 2026. The average HealthCare.gov premium after tax credits is projected to be $50 per month for the lowest cost

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Plan Year 2026 Marketplace Plans and Prices Fact Sheet outlines the projected costs and options for HealthCare.gov enrollees. The average premium after tax credits for the lowest cost plan is expected to be $50 per month, a $13 increase from 2025. Issuer participation remains strong with 183 Qualified Health Plan issuers, and nearly 60% of eligible re-enrollees will have access to plans costing $50 or less after tax credits. The expansion of HSA-eligible plans will provide more options for consumers across all counties using HealthCare.gov.

next_steps.action: Review and adjust financial forecasts based on the new premium projections and issuer participation data.

key_requirements: Ensure access to HSA-eligible plans for all consumers
Monitor changes in premium tax credit coverage

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document announces a new interest rate of 11.125% for Medicare overpayments and underpayments, effective October 22, 2025. This rate is certified by the Department of the Treasury and applies to the first quarter of FY 2026. The change is intended to protect the Medicare Trust Funds by assessing interest on delinquent debts. The update is part of the CMS Manual System and affects Chapter 3, Section 10.

next_steps.action: Implement the new interest rate of 11.125% for Medicare overpayments and underpayments.

key_requirements: Implement an interest rate of 11.125% for overpayments and underpayments
Ensure compliance with 42 CFR Section 405.378

SUBJECT: Notice of New Interest Rate for Medicare Overpayments and Underpayments - 1st

source_citations.context:
CMS Manual System  Department of Health & 
Human Services (DHHS)  
Pub 100 -06 Medicare Financial Management  Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS)  
Transmittal  13440  Date: November 14, 2025  
 Change Request 14278  
 
 
SUBJECT: Notice of New Interest Rate for Medicare Overpayments and Underpayments - 1st 
Quarter Notification for FY 2026  
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES: Medicare Regulation 42 CFR Section 405.378 provides for the charging and payment of interest on overpayments and underpayments to Medicare providers. The Secretary of Treasury certifies an interest rate quarterly. Treasury utilizes the most comprehensive data available on consumer interest rates to determine the certified rate. Interest is assessed on delinquent debts in order to protect the Medicare Trust Funds. The attached Recurring Update Notification applies to Chapter 3, Section 10. 
EFFECTIVE DATE: October 22, 2025  
*Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service.  
IMPLEMENTATION D

source_citations.context:

the higher of the current value of funds rate (one percent for calendar year 2026) or the private consumer 
rate as fixed by the Department of the Treasury.  
B. Policy: The Department of the Treasury has notified the Department of Health and Human Services 
that the private consumer rate has been changed to 11.125% percent.

source_citations.context:
For Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs):  
The Medicare Administrative Contractor is hereby advised that this constitutes technical direction as defined in your contract. CMS does not construe this as a change to the MAC Statement of Work. The contractor is not obligated to incur costs in excess of the amounts allotted in your contract unless and until specifically authorized by the Contracting Officer. If the contractor considers anything provided, as described above, to be outside the current scope of work, the contractor shall withhold performance on the part(s) in question and immediately notify the Contracting Officer, in writing or by e- mail, and request formal directions 
regarding continued performance requirements.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the release of the January 2026 Quarterly Average Sales Price (ASP) and Not Otherwise Classified (NOC) drug pricing files for Medicare Part B. These files are updated quarterly based on data from manufacturers and are used to determine payment limits for Medicare Part B drugs. The document specifies that contractors must use these files for claims processed on or after January 1, 2026, with service dates from January 1, 2026, to March 31, 2026.

next_steps.action: Review and integrate the January 2026 ASP and NOC drug pricing files into billing systems.

key_requirements: Use January 2026 ASP and NOC drug pricing files for claims with service dates from January 1, 2026, to March 31, 2026.
Ensure no additional payment calculations are made beyond the provided ASP, WAC, or AWP limits.

by manufacturers.  
 
EFFECTIVE DATE: January 1, 2026 *Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service.  
IMPLEMENTATION DATE: January 5, 2026

files for Medicare Part B drugs on a quarterly basis. The ASP methodology is based on quarterly data 
submitted to the  CMS  by manufacturers. CMS will supply the contractor s with the ASP and NOC drug 
pricing files for Medicare Part B drugs on a quarterly basis. Payment allowance limits under the Outpatient Prospective Payment System (OPPS) are incorporated into the Outpatient Code Editor (OCE) through separate instructions t hat can be located in chapter 4, section 50 of the Internet -only Manual.

(i.e., 106% ASP, 106% Wholesale Acquisition Cost (WAC), or 95% Average Wholesale Price (AWP)); 
therefore, Medicare contractors shall not make any additional payment cal culations.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document provides instructions for Medicare contractors to download and implement the annual Opioid Treatment Program (OTP) payment rates file for 2026. Contractors must be prepared to implement up to three revised OTP payment files if technical errors or corrections are needed. This update is mandated by the SUPPORT Act, which requires annual updates to OTP payment rates. The effective date is January 1, 2026, with implementation by January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Download the 2026 OTP payment file from the cloud service

key_requirements: Medicare contractors shall download the 2026 OTP payment file from the cloud service.
Be prepared to implement up to three revised OTP payment files if necessary.

source_citations.claim: The document provides instructions for Medicare contractors to download and implement the annual Opioid Treatment Program (OTP) payment rates file for 2026
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: This CR provides the Medicare contractors with instructions for downloading, testing, 
and implementation of the annual OTP update. In addition, Medicare contractors will need to be prepared to implement up to three revised January OTP payment files in the event that technical errors are discovered or any other corrections are required
source_citations.context:
A. Background: This CR provides the Medicare contractors with instructions for downloading, testing, 
and implementation of the annual OTP update. In addition, Medicare contractors will need to be prepared to implement up to three revised January OTP payment files in the event that technical errors are discovered or any other corrections are required.  
B. Policy: Section 2005 of the Substance Use -Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and 
Treatment for Patients and Communities  (SUPPORT) Act requires that the payment rates for OTPs be 
updated on an annual basis. All of the codes in the OTP file can be bil led by specialty D5 (Opioid Treatment 
Program).  The OTP file will reflect all current allowable codes and reflect any newly added codes for 2026 
dates of service.  Codes deleted from the OTP list for 2026 dates of service have been removed from t he 
2026 OTP file.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a Change Request (CR) from CMS to inform contractors about two new CLIA-waived tests approved by the FDA. These tests are for detecting Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and for detecting SARS-CoV-2 and influenza types A and B. The update is necessary for accurate claims processing and applies to chapter 16, section 70.8 of the Internet Only Manual (IOM). The effective date for these changes is January 1, 2026, with implementation by January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to include new HCPCS codes with QW modifier for waived tests.
Ensure all relevant staff are informed about the new waived tests and their coding requirements.

key_requirements: Facilities must be appropriately certified for each test performed under CLIA.
Use of HCPCS codes 87494QW and 87812QW with QW modifier for claims processing.

financial_impact.estimated_cost: Minimal, related to system updates and staff training

Drug Administration. Since these  tests are marketed immediately after approval, the CMS  mus t notify its 
contractors of the new tests so that the contractors can accurately process claims. There are two (2) newly added waived complexity tests. This recurring update notification applies to chapter 16, section 70.8 of the Internet Only Manual (IOM).

pay for laboratory tests categorized as waived complexity under CL IA in facilities with a CLIA certificate of

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA) regulations require 
a facility to be appropriately certified for each test performed. To ensure that Medicare and  Medicaid only 
pay for laboratory tests categorized as waived complexity under CL IA in facilities with a CLIA certificate of 
waiver, laboratory claims are currently edited at the CLIA certificate level.  
Listed below is the latest test(s) approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as waived tests 
under CLIA. The Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) codes for the following new test(s) must have the modifier QW to be recognized as a waiv ed test(s).   
The HCPCS code, effective date, and description for the latest test(s) approved by the FDA as waived test(s) under CLIA is  the following:

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA) regulations require 
a facility to be appropriately certified for each test performed. To ensure that Medicare and  Medicaid only 
pay for laboratory tests categorized as waived complexity under CL IA in facilities with a CLIA certificate of 
waiver, laboratory claims are currently edited at the CLIA certificate level.  
Listed below is the latest test(s) approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as waived tests 
under CLIA. The Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) codes for the following new test(s) must have the modifier QW to be recognized as a waiv ed test(s).

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the introduction of two new FDA-approved waived tests under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) effective January 1, 2026. These tests require the use of the QW modifier for recognition as waived tests. The document emphasizes the need for appropriate CLIA certification for facilities to perform these tests and ensures Medicare payments are made only for tests categorized as waived complexity. It also provides guidance on how to learn more about these tests and their use.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the new waived tests and the requirement to use the QW modifier.

key_requirements: Facilities must have appropriate CLIA certification to perform the new waived tests.
Use the QW modifier for the new CPT codes to ensure recognition as waived tests.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the procedures for the Calendar Year 2026 Medicare participation enrollment, detailing the responsibilities of contractors in managing the enrollment process. It specifies the effective and implementation dates, and provides guidance on the publication of the updated Medicare Participating Physicians and Suppliers Directory (MEDPARD). The document also includes instructions for sending participation announcement letters to providers.

next_steps.action: Review and understand the new participation enrollment procedures for CY 2026.
Ensure all eligible providers are informed about the participation enrollment period.

key_requirements: Contractors must manage the enrollment period from November 15, 2025, to December 31, 2025.
Publish updated MEDPARDs on local websites after the enrollment period ends.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines the procedures for the Calendar Year 2026 Medicare participation enrollment, detailing the responsibilities of contractors in managing the enrollment process
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background:  Contractors  conduct  an enrollment  period on an annual  basis  in order to  provide  eligible 
physicians, practitioners and suppliers with an opportunity to make their calendar year Medicare 
participation decision by December 31. The purpose  of this recurring  update  notification  is to furnish  contractors  with information  needed  for the 
CY 2026 participation enrollment effort
source_citations.context:
A. Background:  Contractors  conduct  an enrollment  period on an annual  basis  in order to  provide  eligible 
physicians, practitioners and suppliers with an opportunity to make their calendar year Medicare 
participation decision by December 31. Providers (physicians, practitioners, or suppliers) who want to maintain their current Participating (PAR) status (PAR or non -PAR) do not need to take any action in the 
upcoming annual participation enrollment program. To sign a participating agreement is to agree to accept assignment  for all  covered  services  that are provided to  Medicare patients. After the  enrollment  period ends, 
contractors publish an updated list of participating physicians, practitioners, and suppliers in their local MEDPARDs on their websites.  
 
B. Policy:  The annual  participation  enrollment  program  for CY 2026 will commence on November  15, 
2025, and will run through December 31, 2025.

providers who are currently  enrolled  in the Medicare Program  can change their current  participation

source_citations.context:
If you bill for physicians’  professional  services,  services  and supplies  provided  incident  to physicians’  professional 
services, outpatient physical and occupational therapy services, diagnostic tests, or radiology services, your 
Medicare fee schedule amounts are 5 percent higher if you participate.  Also, providers receive direct and 
timely reimbursement from Medicare.  
Regardless of the Medicare Part B services for which you are billing, participants have “one stop” billing for 
beneficiaries who have Medigap coverage not connected with their employment and who assign both their 
Medicare and Medigap payments to participants. After we have made payment, Medicare will send the claim 
on to the Medigap  insurer  for payment  of all coinsurance  and deductible  amounts  due under  the Medigap  policy. 
The Medigap insurer must pay the participant directly.

to post it  to their website. Instead, the MACs will be directed to post  a CMS weblink. Once it  is cleared by 
CMS, the letter will be sent to the MACs through an email notification via the Pa

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document provides instructions for Medicare contractors to download, test, and implement the January 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Database (MPFSDB) datasets from a cloud service. It also prepares contractors to implement up to three revised datasets if technical errors or corrections are needed. This update is part of the annual recurring update notification for the MPFS. The effective date is January 1, 2026, with implementation by January 5, 2026.

Be prepared to implement up to three revised datasets if needed

source_citations.claim: The document provides instructions for Medicare contractors to download, test, and implement the January 2026 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Database (MPFSDB) datasets from a cloud service
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR)  is to provide instructions  for the Medicare 
contractors to download, test, and implement the datasets for the annual January MPFSDB update. This CR provides the Medicare 
contractors with instructions on how they will receive the datasets for downloading, testing, and 
implementation of the annual January MPFS update
source_citations.context:
II. GENERAL INFORMATION   
 
A. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR)  is to provide instructions  for the Medicare 
contractors to download, test, and implement the datasets for the annual January MPFSDB update.  
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services  releases  a recurring Change Request  (CR) each year for the 
annual January Medicare Physician Fee Schedule (MPFS)  update. This CR provides the Medicare 
contractors with instructions on how they will receive the datasets for downloading, testing, and 
implementation of the annual January MPFS update. In addition, Medicare contractors  will need to be 
prepared to implement up to three revised January MPFS payment datasets in the event that technical errors are discovered or any other corrections are required. 
B. Policy: Contractors shall follow the instructions for retrieving the annual January MPFS datasets as 
stated in Publication 100- 04, Chapter 23, Section 30.1.

Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR)  is to provide instructions  for the Medicare

source_citations.context:
II. GENERAL INFORMATION   
 
A. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR)  is to provide instructions  for the Medicare 
contractors to download, test, and implement the datasets for the annual January MPFSDB update.  
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services  releases  a recurring Change Request  (CR) each year for the 
annual January Medicare Physician Fee Schedule (MPFS)  update. This CR provides the Medicare 
contractors with instructions on how they will receive the datasets for downloading, testing, and 
implementation of the annual January MPFS update. In addition, Medicare contractors  will need to be 
prepared to implement up to three revised January MPFS payment datasets in the event that technical errors are discovered or any other corrections are required. 
B. Policy: Contractors shall follow the instructions for retrieving the annual January MPFS datasets as 
stated in Publication 100- 04, Chapter 23, Section 30.1.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a quarterly update for the Durable Medical Equipment, Prosthetics, Orthotics, and Supplies (DMEPOS) Competitive Bidding Program (CBP) effective January 1, 2026. It provides instructions for updating DMEPOS CBP files, including changes to the Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS), ZIP code, and single payment amount files. The update aims to improve Medicare's payment methodology, reduce beneficiary expenses, and ensure access to quality services.

source_citations.supporting_text:
The 
DMEPOS CBP files are provided to the Durable Medical Equipment (DME) Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) and the Pricing, Data Analysis, and Coding (PDAC) contractor via CMS’s mainframe telecommunication system on a quarterly basis. The Hybrid Cloud Data Center (HCDC) transmits the DMEPOS CBP files when received from the

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this CR is to provide instructions for updating the DMEPOS CBP files. 
The DMEPOS CBP was mandated by Congress through the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and 
Modernization Act of 2003. The statute requires that Medicare replace the current fee schedule payment 
methodology for selected DMEPOS items with a competitive bidding process. The intent is to improve the effectiveness of the Medicare methodology for setting DMEPOS payment amounts, which will reduce beneficiary out -of-pocket ex penses and save the Medicare program money while ensuring beneficiary access 
to quality items and services.  
The CMS has competed multiple rounds of the DMEPOS CBP since 2011. However, due to a delay in the announcement of a round of the DMEPOS CBP, there was a temporary gap period in the DMEPOS CBP from 2019 through 2020. During that time, CMS made changes to the DMEPOS CBP and awarded Round 2021 DMEPOS CBP contracts.  
On October 27, 2020, the CMS announced

source_citations.supporting_text: Background: The purpose of this CR is to provide instructions for updating the DMEPOS CBP files. Instructions for updating the DMEPOS CBP files are included in these transmittals
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this CR is to provide instructions for updating the DMEPOS CBP files. 
The DMEPOS CBP was mandated by Congress through the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and 
Modernization Act of 2003. The statute requires that Medicare replace the current fee schedule payment 
methodology for selected DMEPOS items with a competitive bidding process. The intent is to improve the effectiveness of the Medicare methodology for setting DMEPOS payment amounts, which will reduce beneficiary out -of-pocket ex penses and save the Medicare program money while ensuring beneficiary access 
to quality items and services.  
The CMS has competed multiple rounds of the DMEPOS CBP since 2011. However, due to a delay in the announcement of a round of the DMEPOS CBP, there was a temporary gap period in the DMEPOS CBP from 2019 through 2020. During that time, CMS made changes to the DMEPOS CBP and awarded Round 2021 DMEPOS CBP contracts.  
On October 27, 2020, the CMS announced

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the implementation of the Ambulance Inflation Factor (AIF) for the calendar year 2026, which is used to determine payment limits for ambulance services under Medicare. The AIF is calculated based on the Consumer Price Index for Urban Consumers and adjusted for productivity changes as mandated by the Affordable Care Act. This update is crucial for Medicare contractors to accurately process claims for ambulance services.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to incorporate the new AIF for 2026.

key_requirements: Incorporate the AIF into payment calculations for ambulance services.
Ensure compliance with the productivity adjustment as per the Affordable Care Act.

Background: This document furnishes the CY 2026 AIF  for determining the payment limit for 
ambulance services required by section 1834(l)(3)(B) of the Social Security Act (the Act), and updates 
Publication (Pub. Section 1834(l)(3)(B) of the Act provides the basis for an update to the payment limits for ambulance services that is equal to the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for all Urban Consumers (CPI -
U) for the 12 -month period ending with June of the previous year
source_citations.context:
A. Background: This document furnishes the CY 2026 AIF  for determining the payment limit for 
ambulance services required by section 1834(l)(3)(B) of the Social Security Act (the Act), and updates 
Publication (Pub.) 100- 04, Medicare Claims Processing Manual, chapter 15, s ection 20.4. 
Section 1834(l)(3)(B) of the Act provides the basis for an update to the payment limits for ambulance services that is equal to the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for all Urban Consumers (CPI -
U) for the 12 -month period ending with June of the previous year. Section 3401 of the Affordable Care Act 
amended Section 1834(l)(3) of the Act to apply a productivity adjustment to this update equal to the 10- year 
moving average of changes in economy- wide private nonfarm business multi -factor producti vity beginning 
January 1, 2011. Beginning with the November 18, 2021, release of productivity data, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) replaced the term multifactor productivity with T

Processing Manual, chapter 15, section 20.4.

source_citations.claim: Estimated cost: Not specified
source_citations.supporting_text:
The statute defines the productivity adjustment to be equal to the 10-
year moving average of changes in annual economy- wide TFP  (as projected by the Secretary for the 10 -year 
period ending with the applicable fiscal year, cost reporting period, or other annual period)
source_citations.context:
A. Background: This document furnishes the CY 2026 AIF  for determining the payment limit for 
ambulance services required by section 1834(l)(3)(B) of the Social Security Act (the Act), and updates 
Publication (Pub.) 100- 04, Medicare Claims Processing Manual, chapter 15, s ection 20.4. 
Section 1834(l)(3)(B) of the Act provides the basis for an update to the payment limits for ambulance services that is equal to the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for all Urban Consumers (CPI -
U) for the 12 -month period ending with June of the previous year. Section 3401 of the Affordable Care Act 
amended Section 1834(l)(3) of the Act to apply a productivity adjustment to this update equal to the 10- year 
moving average of changes in economy- wide private nonfarm business multi -factor producti vity beginning 
January 1, 2011. Beginning with the November 18, 2021, release of productivity data, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) replaced the term multifactor productivity with T

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal that updates ICD-10 coding changes specific to National Coverage Determinations (NCDs) effective January 1, 2026. It rescinds a previous transmittal to ensure the functionality of the NCD zip URL and updates the policy section. The changes are maintenance updates and do not include policy-related changes, which continue to be implemented through the existing NCD process.

coding changes appear in ICD -10 quarterly updates that can be found at:

along with other CRs implementing new policy NCDs. Edits to ICD -10 and other coding updates specific to 
NCDs will be included in subsequent quarterly releases and individual CRs as appropriate. No policy- related 
changes are included with the ICD -10 quarter ly updates. Any policy- related changes to NCDs continue to be 
implemented via the current, longstanding NCD process.

changes are included with the ICD -10 quarter ly updates. Any policy- related changes to NCDs continue to be 
implemented via the current, longstanding NCD process.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the January 2026 update to ICD-10 and other coding revisions for National Coverage Determinations (NCDs). It highlights that no substantive changes were made other than updating the CR release date, transmittal numbers, and links. The update includes new or deleted ICD-10 diagnosis codes effective January 1, 2026, affecting various NCDs such as cardiac output monitoring and cancer screenings. Providers are advised to ensure their billing staff is aware of these updates.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal updating the DMEPOS fee schedule for October 2025. It rescinds a previous transmittal to correct the status of HCPCS Level II code E0716, which will not be deleted. The update ensures the fee schedule reflects current codes and payment policies, as mandated by the Social Security Act and relevant regulations. The changes are effective from October 1, 2025, with implementation by October 6, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect the new DMEPOS fee schedule.

key_requirements: Update DMEPOS fee schedule to include current codes and payment policies.
Ensure compliance with the Social Security Act and 42 CFR regulations.

source_citations.claim: Ensure compliance with the Social Security Act and 42 CFR regulations.
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: Payment on a fee schedule basis is required for certain Durable Medical Equipment 
(DME), prosthetic devices, orthotics, prosthetics, and surgical dressings by Subsection (§)1834(a), (h), and 
(i) of the Social Security Act (the Act). Also, payment on a fee schedule basis is a regulatory requirement at 42 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) §414
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Payment on a fee schedule basis is required for certain Durable Medical Equipment 
(DME), prosthetic devices, orthotics, prosthetics, and surgical dressings by Subsection (§)1834(a), (h), and 
(i) of the Social Security Act (the Act). Also, payment on a fee schedule basis is a regulatory requirement at 42 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) §414.102 for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (PEN), splints, casts and Intraocular Lenses (IOLs) inserted in a physician’s office. Also, the DMEPOS fee schedule file includes national payment amounts for lymphedema compression treatment items established in accordance with §1834(z) of the Act and regulations at 42 CFR §414.1650.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the October 2025 quarterly update to the DMEPOS fee schedule, including the addition and deletion of HCPCS codes and corrections to deflation factors. It addresses changes in payment policies due to the gap period in the DMEPOS Competitive Bidding Program and updates to rural and former CBA ZIP Code files. The update is crucial for providers billing Medicare Administrative Contractors for DMEPOS services.

next_steps.action: Inform billing staff about the updated HCPCS codes and fee schedule changes.

Adjust fee schedules according to the updated DMEPOS file.

Sections 1834(a), (h), and (i) of the Social Security Act  require payment on a fee schedule basis for 
certain DMEPOS and surgical dressings. Regulations at 42 CFR 414.102 also require fee schedule 
payment for parenteral and enteral nutrition (PEN), splints, casts, and intraocular lenses (IOLs) 
inserted in a physician’s office. The DMEPOS fee schedule file includes national payment amounts 
for lymphedema compression treatment items established according to section 1834(z) of the  
Social Security Act  and regulations at 42 CFR 414.1650.  
Payment for Items Provided in Former Competitive Bidding Areas

braces expired on December 31, 2023.

braces expired on December 31, 2023.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the implementation of the Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM) 3-Day Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) Waiver. This waiver allows hospitals to discharge patients to SNFs without the traditional 3-day hospital stay requirement, using demonstration code A9. The initiative aims to enhance care coordination and reduce Medicare expenditures while maintaining care quality.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing processes to incorporate demonstration code A9 for SNF claims.

key_requirements: Incorporate demonstration code A9 in SNF claims
Ensure compliance with TEAM model guidelines

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CMS document outlines the implementation of the Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM), which waives the 3-day rule for skilled nursing facility admissions. This model aims to reduce Medicare spending and improve care quality by holding acute care hospitals accountable for the cost and quality of care for selected surgical procedures. The model will run from January 1, 2026, to December 31, 2030, and includes various participation tracks with different levels of financial risk.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the TEAM model details and payment criteria.

key_requirements: Hospitals must discharge patients to SNFs without a 3-day hospital stay under certain conditions.
SNF claims must include the TEAM demonstration code A9 for payment.

SNF 3 -Day Rule Waiver  
To enhance care coordination across the post -acute spectrum and support participating hospitals in 
managing patient care, we’re conditionally waiving certain Medicare payment requirements for 
patients in TEAM episodes starting for dates of service on or after January 1, 2026. 580(b) , we’re waiving the requirement for a 3- day inpatient hospital stay

source_citations.context:
age 5 of 6 MLN Matters: MM 14098  Related CR 14098  
Key Updates 
SNF 3 -Day Rule Waiver  
To enhance care coordination across the post -acute spectrum and support participating hospitals in 
managing patient care, we’re conditionally waiving certain Medicare payment requirements for 
patients in TEAM episodes starting for dates of service on or after January 1, 2026. Specifically, per 
regulations at 42 CFR 512.580(b) , we’re waiving the requirement for a 3- day inpatient hospital stay 
prior to a Medicare- covered SNF stay for eligible TEAM patients.  
Under standard Medicare rules, we cover  SNF services if a patient has  a qualifying inpatient hospital 
stay of at least 3 consecutive days (including the day of hospital admission but not the day of 
discharge) . Effective for episodes starting on or after January 1, 2026, until December 31, 2030 , 
patients  in a TEAM episode of care may  receive SNF or  swing bed services without meeting  
the 3-day hospital stay  requirement . Pay

source_citations.supporting_text:
If your MAC determines the patient doesn’t meet TEAM eligibility criteria but meets all other Medicare 
rules for coverage and payment for Part A -covered SNF services,  they’ll remove demonstration code 
A9 and reprocess it as an FFS claim. ● Demonstration code A9 is present in the treatment authorization code field (2300 REF02 Segment, where REF01=P4 for electronic claims)

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a transmittal from CMS updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual Part 2, specifically for Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) cost reporting. It includes revisions to forms and instructions, particularly for reporting vaccine costs and electronic cost report specifications. The changes are effective for cost reporting periods ending after December 31, 2024.

next_steps.action: Review and update internal cost reporting processes to align with new CMS-224-14 instructions.

key_requirements: Incorporate new instructions for reporting hepatitis B vaccines.
Update electronic cost report specifications.

source_citations.claim: The document is a transmittal from CMS updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual Part 2, specifically for Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) cost reporting
source_citations.supporting_text:
Federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) are required under 
42 CFR 405. In accordance 
with §§1815(a) and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the Act), providers of medical and 
other health services as defined under §1861(s), participating in the Medicare program are required 
to submit annual information to achieve settlement of costs for health care services rendered to 
Medicare beneficiaries
source_citations.context:
The Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 requires that the private sector be informed as to why 
information is collected and what the information is used for by the government.  In accordance 
with §§1815(a) and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the Act), providers of medical and 
other health services as defined under §1861(s), participating in the Medicare program are required 
to submit annual information to achieve settlement of costs for health care services rendered to 
Medicare beneficiaries.  Federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) are required under 
42 CFR 405.2470, to maintain adequate financial and statistical records.  FQHCs are also required 
to provide annual cost reports as the Secretary determines necessary to administer the program.  
The data submitted on the cost reports supports management of Federal programs.  The FQHC 
cost report must be submitted to the Medicare administrative contractor (hereafter referred to as 
contractor) electronically in accordan

source_citations.claim: The document is a transmittal from CMS updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual Part 2, specifically for Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) cost reporting
source_citations.supporting_text:
--Indicate whether the FQHC has changed ownership immediately prior to the beginning 
of the cost reporting period. If column 1 is “N”, submit a copy of the internally prepared financial statements, and written 
statements of significant accounting policy and procedure changes affecting Medicare 
reimbursement which occurred during the cost reporting period
source_citations.context:
REIMBURSEMENT QUESTIONNAIRE  
 
This worksheet collects organizational, financial and statistical information previously reported on 
Form CMS-339.  Where instructions for this worksheet direct the FQHC to submit 
documentation/information, mail or otherwise transmit the requested documentation to the 
contractor with submission of the ECR.  The contractor has the right under §§1815(a) and 1883(e) 
of the Act to request any missing documentation.  When filing a consolidated cost report, this 
worksheet applies only to the primary FQHC. 
 
To the degree that the information in the questionnaire constitutes commercial or financial 
information which is confidential and/or is of a highly sensitive personal nature, the information 
will be protected from release under the Freedom of Information Act.  If there is any question 
about releasing information, the contractor should consult with the CMS Regional Office. 
 
NOTE: The responses on all lines are “yes” or “no” unless otherwise indica

source_citations.supporting_text:
A 
date without an alpha suffix, such as [10/01/2014], indicates the edit is effective for cost reporting 
periods ending on or after the date in brackets. A date followed by a “b,” such as [10/01/2014b], 
indicates the edit is effective for cost reporting periods beginning on or after the date in brackets
source_citations.context:
TABLE 6 - EDITS 
 
Medicare cost reports submitted electronically must meet a variety of edits.  These include 
mathematical accuracy edits, certain minimum file requirements, and other data edits.  Any vendor 
software which produces an electronic cost report file for Medicare FQHCs must automate all of 
these edits.  Failure to properly implement these edits may result in the suspension of a vendor's 
system certification until corrective action is taken.  The vendor’s software should provide 
meaningful error messages to notify the FQHC of the cause of every exception.  The edit message 
generated by the vendor systems must contain the related 4 digit and 1 alpha character, where 
indicated, reject/edit code specified below.  Any file submitted by a provider containing a level 1 
edit will be rejected by the contractors.  Notification must be made to CMS for any exceptions. 
 
The edits are applied at two levels.  Level 1 edits (1000 series reject codes) test the format of the 
data

source_citations.claim: Incorporate new instructions for reporting hepatitis B vaccines.
source_citations.supporting_text:
Effective January 1, 2025, hepatitis B vaccines and their 
administration are paid at 100 percent of reasonable cost. This worksheet provides for the 
computation of the cost of the pneumococcal , influenza, and hepatitis B  vaccines
source_citations.context:
The cost and administration of pneumococcal and influenza vaccines to Medicare beneficiaries are 
paid at 100 percent of reasonable cost .  Effective January 1, 2025, hepatitis B vaccines and their 
administration are paid at 100 percent of reasonable cost.  This worksheet provides for the 
computation of the cost of the pneumococcal , influenza, and hepatitis B  vaccines.  Additionally, in 
accordance with §3713 of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, 
during the COVID-19 public health emergency (PHE), this worksheet computes the cost of COVID-
19 vaccines and monoclonal antibody products for treatment of COVID-19 and their administration 
to Medicare and Medicare Advantage (MA) enrollees for calendar years 2020 and 2021. 
 
For services rendered prior to July 1, 2025, report  the applicable data in columns 1, 2, 2.01, and 
2.02, for pneumococcal vaccines, influenza vaccines, COVID-19 vaccines, and monoclonal 
antibody products for treatment of COVID-19 ,

§1834(o) of the Act to establish a new system of payment for the costs of FQHC services under 
Medicare Part B based on prospectively set rates. The statute requires implementation of the 
FQHC prospective payment system (PPS) for FQHCs with cost reporting periods beginning on or 
after October 1, 2014
source_citations.context:
§1834(o) of the Act to establish a new system of payment for the costs of FQHC services under 
Medicare Part B based on prospectively set rates.  The statute requires implementation of the 
FQHC prospective payment system (PPS) for FQHCs with cost reporting periods beginning on or 
after October 1, 2014.  Form CMS-224-14 must be used by all freestanding FQHCs for cost 
reporting periods beginning on or after October 1, 2014.   
 
NOTE: This form is to be used by freestanding FQHCs and FQHC’s previously reported as part 
of a SNF complex or a HHA complex.  FQHCs that are part of a hospital healthcare complex must 
use the Form CMS-2552. 
 
According to the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995, no persons are required to respond to a 
collection of information unless it displays a valid OMB control number.  The valid OMB control 
number for this information collection is 0938-1298 (expires 07/31/2028 ).  The time required to 
complete this information collection is estimated to average 58 hou

Column 1 - Contract Labor Costs.--Enter the amount paid for services furnished under contract, 
rather than by employees, for direct patient care and management services for the occupations on 
lines 2 through 15.  Line 1 is the aggregate of lines 2 through 15.  DO NOT include cost for 
equipment, supplies, travel expenses, and other miscellaneous or overhead items (non-labor costs).  
 
Column 2 - Benefit Costs.--Enter the amount of employee benefit costs, also referred to as wage-
related costs, for direct patient care services for the occupations listed on lines 2 through 15.  Line 1 
is the aggregate of lines 2 through 15.

of the job categories specified in lines 16 through 29.

REIMBURSEMENT QUESTIONNAIRE  
 
This worksheet collects organizational, financial and statistical information previously reported on 
Form CMS-339.  Where instructions for this worksheet direct the FQHC to submit 
documentation/information, mail or otherwise transmit the requested documentation to the 
contractor with submission of the ECR.  The contractor has the right under §§1815(a) and 1883(e) 
of the Act to request any missing documentation.  When filing a consolidated cost report, this 
worksheet applies only to the primary FQHC. 
 
To the degree that the information in the questionnaire constitutes commercial or financial 
information which is confidential and/or is of a highly sensitive personal nature, the information 
will be protected from release under the Freedom of Information Act.  If there is any question 
about releasing information, the contractor should consult with the CMS Regional Office.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal related to the Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC) cost report, which is required by law. It outlines the procedures for submitting cost reports, either electronically or manually, and the consequences of misrepresentation or falsification of information. The document also includes certification requirements for the Chief Financial Officer or Administrator and provides a settlement summary for Medicare programs.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a transmittal from CMS updating the Medicare Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically Chapter 48, which deals with the Home Office Cost Statement, Form CMS-287-22. The updates clarify instructions for cost reporting periods ending on or after August 31, 2025, including revisions to Schedule S-2, Schedule A, and Schedules E and E-1. These changes also include updates to electronic reporting specifications.

next_steps.action: Review and implement the updated instructions for cost reporting.
next_steps.timeline: Before the end of the next cost reporting period after August 31, 2025.

key_requirements: Revised instructions for Schedule S-2, Parts I through III.
Clarified instructions for reporting other capital-related costs in Schedule A.

source_citations.supporting_text:
he home office cost statement provides the mechanism to allocate allowable HO/CO costs to the 
healthcare provider components (providers), non- healthcare components, and region/division 
components. A Medicare- certified healthcare complex  with one or more subproviders or provider -
based entities , such as a provider- based HHA or provider -based RHC,  receives a HO/CO cost 
allocation only under the primary CCN for the entire healthcare complex
source_citations.context:
he home office cost statement provides the mechanism to allocate allowable HO/CO costs to the 
healthcare provider components (providers), non- healthcare components, and region/division 
components .  A Medicare- certified healthcare complex  with one or more subproviders or provider -
based entities , such as a provider- based HHA or provider -based RHC,  receives a HO/CO cost 
allocation only under the primary CCN for the entire healthcare complex .  Each component of the 
home office must receive its  allocable share of HO/CO capital and non- capital costs.  Starting with 
the HO/CO total costs (including those costs paid on behalf of providers), remove all costs that are 
not allowable in accordance with program instructions.  Group the remaining costs (total allowable 
costs) as either capital related costs or non -capital related costs, and allocate each group to all 
components that received services from the HO/CO.  Allocate HO/CO  costs to the components in 
the following ord

This section sets forth edits to validate the following criteria:  
 
• data entries meet the size and usage requirements defined in §4890.30, Table  3 
• mathematical computations calculate resultant numbers as defined in the cost reporting 
instructions 
• data records comply with the minimum file requirements specified in this chapter  
 
When a data entry, mathematical computation, or data record fails to meet the requirements of an 
edit, the software must provide a meaningful error message that identifies both the edit number 
(see §§4890.50.10 and  4891.50.20) and the cause of the failure.   Edit numbers consist of four digits 
for general edits or four digits and one alphabetical character for schedule -specific edits.  CMS 
may suspend the approval of software that fails to properly implement edits until the software 
correctly implements the edits.  
 The edits apply at two levels.  Level 1 edits (1000 series numbers) validate critical data elements 
required to generate a v

source_citations.claim: These changes also include updates to electronic reporting specifications
source_citations.supporting_text:
The 
Form CMS -287- 22 specifications in §4890ff provide the standard format of the ECR records for 
electronic reporting as well as the requirements for the PI file. CMS requires that the HO/CO submit the Form CMS -287- 22 in an electronic format that includes 
an electronic cost report (ECR) file and a print image (PI) file, each created using CMS -approved 
software from an ECR software vendor
source_citations.context:
CMS requires that the HO/CO submit the Form CMS -287- 22 in an electronic format that includes 
an electronic cost report (ECR) file and a print image (PI) file, each created using CMS -approved 
software from an ECR software vendor.  The software creates the E CR file, a file containing data 
entered by the HO/CO and data calculated by the software, and the PI file, a printable or electronically viewable home office cost statement created from the data in the ECR file.  The 
Form CMS -287- 22 specifications in §4890ff provide the standard format of the ECR records for 
electronic reporting as well as the requirements for the PI file.  HO/CO cost statement ECR and PI files must comply with the instructions and specifications in this chapter.  
 The ECR file contains four types of records:  type  1, type  2, type  3, and type  4.  Type  1 records 
contain HO/CO and cost statement identifying information.  Type  2 records contain: 
 
• the text of Schedule A line labels for cost centers
source_citations.section: 4890. ELECTRONIC REPORTING SPECIFICATIONS FOR FORM CMS -287-22

source_citations.claim: Clarified instructions for reporting other capital-related costs in Schedule A.
source_citations.supporting_text:
To accommodate reporting 
needs, the HO/CO may subscript lines 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6, on Schedule  A, to add lines to report costs 
for additional nonstandard capital cost centers. For example, the HO/CO may subscript the Schedule  A, line  1, Capital Related Costs -
Buildings & Fixtures, by assigning subscripted line  1
source_citations.context:
Schedule A provides blank lines  and permits adding lines through subscripting (see §4890.40 
Table 4- A, Data Elements the HO/CO May Subscript (Usage)) for reporting costs of additional 
cost centers unique to the HO/CO, i.e.,  nonstandard cost centers.  To accommodate reporting 
needs, the HO/CO may subscript lines 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6, on Schedule  A, to add lines to report costs 
for additional nonstandard capital cost centers.  The HO/CO may subscript lines 8 through 28, and 
use lines 29 through 98, and subscripts, to report costs for additional nonstandard non- capital  cost 
centers.  Lines subscripted from standard cost centers must relate to the cost center from which they are subscripted.  The HO/CO must define each nonstandard capital and non- capital cost center 
by assigning a unique descriptive line label to a Schedule A line number.  Other than for limited exceptions, the HO/CO must number subscripted lines s equentially beginning with 01 through  99. 
 For example, the

ound computations to two decimal places  unless otherwise specified. If a residual exists as a 
result of computing costs using a fraction, adjust the largest absolute value  resulting from the 
computation by the residual amount
source_citations.context:
ound computations to two decimal places  unless otherwise specified.  If a residual exists as a 
result of computing costs using a fraction, adjust the largest absolute value  resulting from the 
computation by the residual amount .  For example, in cost finding, a unit cost multiplier (UCM) 
is applied to the statistics in determining costs.  After rounding each computation, the sum of the 
allocation may be more or less than the total cost to be allocated.  Adjust the largest absolute value 
resulting from the allocation by the residual amount so that the sum of the allocated amounts equals 
the amount to be allocated.

(see §§4890.50.10 and  4891.50.20) and the cause of the failure.   Edit numbers consist of four digits 
for general edits or four digits and one alphabetical character for schedule -specific edits.  CMS 
may suspend the approval of software that fails to properly implement edits until the software 
correctly implements the edits.  
 The edits apply at two levels.  Level 1 edits (1000 series numbers) validate critical data elements 
required to generate a v

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a comprehensive guide for the CMS Form CMS-287-22, which is used for reporting home office costs and certifying compliance with federal regulations. It includes instructions for completing the form, certification requirements, and potential legal consequences for misrepresentation. The form is essential for ensuring accurate cost reporting and compliance with healthcare laws.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically Chapter 40, which deals with hospital cost reporting forms and instructions. It includes revisions to various worksheets, such as S-2, A, E, and M, to clarify instructions and update effective dates for certain programs and adjustments. New questions and edits have been added to address changes in regulations and reporting requirements.

next_steps.action: Review and update cost reporting processes to align with new instructions and effective dates.

key_requirements: Extend effective date for low-volume adjustment as per 42 CFR 412.101.
Establish and maintain a 6-month buffer stock of essential medicines.

and hospital health care c omplexes with cost reporting periods beginning on or after May  1, 2010
source_citations.context:
The Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 requires that you be informed why information is collected 
and what the information is used for by the government.  In accordance with §§1815(a), 1833(e), 
and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the  Act), providers of service participating in the 
Medicare program are required to submit annual information to achieve settlement of costs for 
health care services rendered to Medicare beneficiaries.  In accordance with these provisions, all 
hospital and hospit al health c are complexes must complete Form  CMS -2552 -10 with a valid Office 
of Management and Budget (OMB) control number in order to determine program payment.  In 
addition to determining program payment, the data submitted on the cost report support  
management of the federal programs, e.g.,  data extraction in developing cost limits, data extraction 
in developing and updating various prospective payment systems.  The information reported on 
Form  CMS -2552 -10 must conform
