source_citations.context:
4004.2  Part II - Hospital and Hospital Health Care Complex Reimbursement Questionnaire .-- 
The information required on Part II of this worksheet (formerly Form  CMS -339) must be 
completed by all hospitals submitting cost reports to the Medicare contractor under title XVIII of 
the Act.  Its purpose is to assist you in preparing an acceptable cost report, to minimize the need 
for direct contact between you and your contractor, and to expedite review and settlement of cost 
reports.  It is designed to answer pert inent questions about key reimbursement concepts displayed 
in the cost reports and to gather information necessary to support certain financial and statistical 
entries on the cost report.  The questionnaire is a tool used in arriving at a prompt and equita ble 
settlement of your cost report.  
 
Where the instructions for this worksheet direct you to submit documentation/information, mail or 
otherwise transmit to the contractor immediately after submission of the ECR.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal outlining the requirements for hospitals and healthcare providers to submit cost reports as mandated by federal law. It includes instructions for electronic and manual submissions, certification requirements by CFOs or administrators, and settlement summaries for various healthcare services. The document emphasizes the legal implications of misrepresentation and the necessity for compliance with healthcare laws.

next_steps.action: Ensure all cost reports are prepared and submitted in compliance with CMS guidelines.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Common Working File (CWF) edits for Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) Patient Driven Payment Model (PDPM) interrupted stay claims to include Prospective Payment System (PPS) Swing Bed providers, excluding Swing Bed Critical Access Hospital (CAH) providers. This change is effective January 1, 2026, with implementation on January 5, 2026. The update is a technical adjustment to ensure claims processing adheres to current policy, with no new policy introduced.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate new CWF edits for SNF PDPM claims.

key_requirements: The contractor shall modify current editing for PDPM claims to include swing bed TOB 18X (excluding CAH Swing Beds) as edit criteria for interrupted stay editing.
Ensure IURs are consistent with updated CWF edits 7258, 7159, 7260, 7261, 7269, and 727A.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the CMS's updated coverage policy for Transcatheter Tricuspid Valve Replacement (TTVR) for treating symptomatic Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR) under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED). The effective date for this coverage is March 19, 2025, with implementation set for January 5, 2026. The transmittal modifies a previous requirement by changing the logical operator from OR to AND for ICD-10 code Q22.8, ensuring precise claims processing instructions.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing and claims processing systems to align with the new TTVR coverage criteria.

key_requirements: Contractors shall allow claims for TTVR for symptomatic TR under CED.
Contractors shall process TTVR claims with specific ICD-10-PCS codes and criteria.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the National Coverage Determination (NCD) for Transcatheter Tricuspid Valve Replacement (TTVR), effective March 19, 2025. It specifies that TTVR is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) for treating symptomatic tricuspid regurgitation (TR) when performed within a CMS-approved study. The document details patient and physician criteria, study requirements, and claims processing instructions, emphasizing the need for a heart team and adherence to specific scientific standards.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the new TTVR coverage and claims processing requirements.

key_requirements: TTVR must be performed within a CMS-approved CED study.
Adherence to patient and physician criteria as outlined in NCD 20.37.

source_citations.claim: Adherence to patient and physician criteria as outlined in NCD 20.37.
source_citations.supporting_text:
Physician Criteria  
The patient is under the care of a heart team (preoperatively and postoperatively), which includes,  
at a minimum:  
● Cardiac surgeon  
● Interventional cardiologist  
● Cardiologist with training and experience in heart failure management  
● Electrophysiologist  
● Multi -modality imaging specialist  
● Interventional echocardiographer  
All the specialists above must have experience car ing for and treat ing TR. Affected Providers 
● Physicians 
● Hospitals

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a change in the Medicare National Coverage Determinations for Transcatheter Tricuspid Valve Replacement (TTVR), effective March 19, 2025. The change involves replacing 'OR' with 'AND' in the business requirement for ICD-10 code Q22.8. This update is intended to inform contractors about the coverage for TTVR under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) for symptomatic Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR). The implementation date for these changes is January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to reflect the new coverage criteria for TTVR.
Educate clinical staff about the new coverage criteria for TTVR.
Ensure compliance with the new NCD requirements.

key_requirements: Contractors shall cover TTVR for symptomatic TR under CED.
Update ICD-10 code Q22.8 criteria from 'OR' to 'AND'.

aware of coverage for Transcatheter Tricuspid Valve Replacement (TTVR) on March 19, 2025.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: March 19, 2025  
*Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the National Coverage Determination (NCD) for Transcatheter Tricuspid Valve Replacement (TTVR), effective March 19, 2025. It specifies that TTVR is covered for treating symptomatic tricuspid regurgitation under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) criteria. The document details patient and physician criteria, CED study requirements, and claims processing instructions. It emphasizes that TTVR is only covered within CMS-approved studies or under specific clinical trial policies.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the new TTVR coverage criteria and claims processing requirements.

key_requirements: TTVR is covered only under CMS-approved CED studies.
Physicians must meet specific criteria and be part of a heart team.

source_citations.supporting_text:
Professional Claims  
We cover claims for TTVR in a clinical research study when billed with:  
● HCPCS code 0646T  
● The 8- digit clinical trial identifier number  
● Modifier Q0 — Investigational clinical service provided in a clinical research study that ’s in an 
approved clinical research study  
● Appropriate ICD -10-CM principal diagnosis code and ICD -10-CM diagnosis code Z00. 1 (Clinical Trial Policy) 
or through the investigational device e xemption policy

source_citations.claim: Physicians must meet specific criteria and be part of a heart team.
source_citations.supporting_text:
Patient Criteria  
Patients must have symptomatic TR  despite optimal medical therapy, and their heart team must 
consider tricuspid valve replacement as an appropriate treatment. Physician Criteria  
The patient is under the care of a heart team (preoperatively and postoperatively), which includes,  
at a minimum:  
● Cardiac surgeon  
● Interventional cardiologist  
● Cardiologist with training and experience in heart failure management  
● Electrophysiologist  
● Multi -modality imaging speci

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a Change Request (CR) for updating systems to comply with the CORE 360 Uniform Use of Claim Adjustment Reason Codes (CARC), Remittance Advice Remark Codes (RARC), and Claim Adjustment Group Code (CAGC) Rule. These updates are part of the Phase III Electronic Remittance Advice (ERA) and Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT) operating rules. The updates are based on the CORE Code Combination List, which will be published around October 1, 2025, with an effective date of January 1, 2026, and an implementation date of January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Update systems based on the CORE 360 Uniform Use of CARC, RARC, and CAGC rule publications.

key_requirements: Update systems to comply with CORE 360 Uniform Use of CARC, RARC, and CAGC rule.
Ensure systems are ready for the CORE Code Combination List publication.

of DHHS (the Secretary ) to adopt standards for certain transactions to enable health information to be 
exchanged more efficiently and to achieve greater uniformity in the transmission of health information.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the October 2025 updates to the Hospital Outpatient Prospective Payment System (OPPS), including changes to billing instructions and payment policies. Key updates involve coding changes for Covid-19 related codes, new services, and pass-through drugs and devices. A significant change is the status indicator update for a Covid-19 vaccine code, which is now paid at a reasonable cost, not subject to deductible or coinsurance, retroactive to August 27, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect new coding and payment policies.
Communicate changes to clinical staff regarding the updated Covid-19 vaccine code status.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new HCPCS and APC codes.
Ensure compliance with the revised status indicator for Covid-19 vaccine code 91323.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines the October 2025 updates to the Hospital Outpatient Prospective Payment System (OPPS), including changes to billing instructions and payment policies
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The purpose of this CR is to describe changes to and billing instructions for various 
payment policies implemented in the October 2025 OPPS update. This RUN provides instructions on coding changes and policy updates  that are effective October 1, 2025, for 
the Hospital  OPPS
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this CR is to describe changes to and billing instructions for various 
payment policies implemented in the October 2025 OPPS update. 
This RUN provides instructions on coding changes and policy updates  that are effective October 1, 2025, for 
the Hospital  OPPS. The updates include coding and policy changes for Covid- 19 related codes, PLA codes, 
new services, pass -through drugs and devices , and other items and services. The October 2025 revisions to 
I/OCE data files, instructions, and specifications are provided in the forthcoming October 2025 I/OCE CR. 
B. Policy: 1.  Status Indicator Change for a Covid -19 Vaccine Code  
On April 1, 2025, the American Medical Association (AMA) released Current Procedural Terminology 
(CPT) code 91323 associated with a Covid- 19 vaccine. It was effective July 1, 2025. In the July 2025 I/OCE 
update, this code was assigned to status indicator “ E1” (Not paid by Medicare when submitted on outpatient 
claims (any ou

source_citations.claim: Key updates involve coding changes for Covid-19 related codes, new services, and pass-through drugs and devices
source_citations.supporting_text:
We note that we preliminarily approved three new devices for pass -through status under the OPPS with an 
effective date of October 1, 2025, specifically, HCPCS codes C1740, C1741 and C1742. Device Offset from Payment for the Following HCPCS Codes  
Section 1833(t)(6)(D)(ii) of the Act requires that we deduct from pass -through payments for devices an 
amount that reflects the device portion of the APC payment amount
source_citations.context:
a. New Device Pass -Through Category Effective October 1, 2025  
Section 1833(t)(6)(B) of the Social Security Act requires that, under the OPPS, categories of devices be 
eligible for transitional pass -through payments for at least two, but not more than three years. In addition, 
section 1833(t)(6)(B)(ii)(IV) of the Act requires that we create additional categories for transitional pass -
through payment of new medical devices not described by existing or previously existing categories of devices.  
We note that we preliminarily approved three new devices for pass -through status under the OPPS with an

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Hospital Outpatient Prospective Payment System (OPPS) effective October 1, 2025. Key changes include new HCPCS codes for COVID-19 monoclonal antibodies and pleural-peritoneal shunts, updates to CPT proprietary laboratory analyses, and status indicator changes for a COVID-19 vaccine code. These updates are crucial for hospitals, physicians, and other providers billing Medicare Administrative Contractors for outpatient services.

Action Needed 
Make sure your billing staff knows about these Hospital Outpatient Prospective P ayment System 
(OPPS)  updates effective October 1, 2025, including coding and billing changes for:  
● New COVID- 19 m onoclonal antibody and pleural -peritoneal shunt HCPCS codes  
● CPT proprietary laboratory analyses  (PLA)  and Hospital OPPS device categories  
● Status indicator updates  
● Drugs, biologicals, and radiopharmaceuticals  
● Skin substitutes

source_citations.claim: The document outlines updates to the Hospital Outpatient Prospective Payment System (OPPS) effective October 1, 2025
source_citations.supporting_text:
We aren’t publishing the updated payment rates in this CR; however,  you can find 
the update d payment rates effective October 2025 in the October 2025 Hospital OPPS Addendums  
A and B. We’re making these changes in 
the October 2025 I/OCE update effective October 1, 2025
source_citations.context:
e’re changing payment status indicators for 6 drug, biological, and radiopharmaceutical  
HCPCS codes to K, M, or N retroactive to July 1, 2025.  We listed the status indicators for these 
HCPCS codes as E2 in the July 2025 Addendum B.  
See Table 15 for the list of codes and their revised status indicators. We’re making these changes in 
the October 2025 I/OCE update effective October 1, 2025.  
Descriptor Changes to HCPCS Codes for Drugs, Biologicals & Radiopharmaceuticals 
We’re making substantial descriptor changes to 2 drug, biological, and radiopharmaceutical  
HCPCS codes as of October 1, 2025. See Table 16  for the list of codes.  
Drugs & Biologicals with Payments Based on Average Sales Price  
For CY 2025, we pay for most non- pass -through drugs, biologicals, and therapeutic 
radiopharmaceuticals at a single rate of average sales price (ASP) +6% (or ASP +6 or 8% of the 
reference product for biosimilars). In CY 2025, we make a single payment of ASP +6% for pass -
through dru

where specific codes weren’t previously available starting on October 1, 2025. Existing HCPCS Codes for Certain Drugs, Biologicals & Radiopharmaceuticals Starting  Pas
source_citations.context:
New HCPCS Code Describing the Insertion of a Pleural -Peritoneal Shunt with 
Intercostal Pump Chamber  
We’re establishing a new HCPCS code C8006 to describe the procedure to insert a pleural -peritoneal 
shunt with an intercostal pump chamber. See Table 6 for the long descriptor, status indicator, and 
APC assignment. Refer to Addendum B for the short descriptor, status indicator, and payment rate.  
Descriptor Revision for HCPCS Code C1982  
We’re revising the long descriptor for HCPCS code C1982 ( Catheter, pressure- generating, (e.g., one-
way valve, intermittently occlusive) ) to align the device descriptor with the procedure descriptors.  
C1982 describes a pressure- generating catheter that’s used with vascular embolization or occlusion 
procedures and simulation procedures.  
See Table 7 for the code  and its status indicator. Refer to Addendum B for the short descriptor, status 
indicator, and payment rate.

f 7 MLN Matters: MM 14223  Related CR 14223  
Drugs, Biol

New HCPCS Code Describing the Insertion of a Pleural -Peritoneal Shunt with 
Intercostal Pump Chamber  
We’re establishing a new HCPCS code C8006 to describe the procedure to insert a pleural -peritoneal 
shunt with an intercostal pump chamber. See Table 6 for the long descriptor, status indicator, and 
APC assignment. Refer to Addendum B for the short descriptor, status indicator, and payment rate.  
Descriptor Revision for HCPCS Code C1982  
We’re revising the long descriptor for HCPCS code C1982 ( Catheter, pressure- generating, (e.g., one-
way valve, intermittently occlusive) ) to align the device descriptor with the procedure descriptors.  
C1982 describes a pressure- generating catheter that’s used with vascular embolization or occlusion 
procedures and simulation procedures.  
See Table 7 for the code  and its status indicator. Refer to Addendum B for the short descriptor, status 
indicator, and payment rate.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the 2026 annual update of HCPCS codes for Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) Consolidated Billing. It details changes to the codes and how Medicare Physician Fee Schedule designations will be used to revise Common Working File edits. This update allows A/B Medicare Administrative Contractors to make appropriate payments in accordance with policy for SNF Consolidated Billing.

next_steps.action: Review and understand the changes to HCPCS codes and Medicare Physician Fee Schedule designations.
Access and review the new code files once posted on the CMS website.
next_steps.timeline: By the first week in December 2025

key_requirements: The CWF contractor shall accept new A/B MAC (B) and A/B MAC (A) SNF coding files.
Process SNF CB claims for dates of service starting January 1, 2026.

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The CWF currently has edits in place for claims received for beneficiaries in a Part A 
covered SNF stay, as well as for beneficiaries in a non -covered stay. These edits allow only those services that 
are excluded from consolidated billing to be paid separately. Barring any delay in the Medicare Physician Fee 
Schedule, the new code files will be provided to CWF by November 1, 2025. 
For A/B MAC (B) processing only:  As soon as possible after the final Medicare Physician Fee Schedule is 
released, new code files will be posted to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) website at: 
https://www.cms.gov/medicare/coding -billing/skilled -nursing- facility -snf-consolidated -billing.  
For A/B MAC (A) processing only: By the first week in December 2025, new code files will be posted to the CMS website at: https://www.cms.gov/medicare/coding -billing/skilled -nursing- facility -snf-consolidated- billing.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a change in the start date for the expanded outlier reconciliation criteria for hospitals under the Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) and Long Term Care Hospital Prospective Payment System (LTCH PPS). The effective and implementation date is set for October 1, 2025. This change affects how Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) handle cost reports and outlier payment reconciliations, requiring them to refer certain cost reports to the CMS Central Office for approval.

next_steps.action: Review and update internal processes to align with the new start date for outlier reconciliation criteria.

key_requirements: MACs must refer cost reports with a begin date on or after October 1, 2025, to the CMS Central Office for approval if certain conditions are met.
MACs must follow specific instructions for reconciling outlier payments if approval is received from the CMS Central Office.

A. Background: Under existing regulations at 42 CFR §412.84(i)(4) for the IPPS and 42 CFR 412.525(a) 
for the LTCH PPS, outlier payments may be reconciled upon cost report settlement to account for 
differences between the Cost -to-Charge Ratio (CCR) used to pay the claim at its original submission by the 
provider and the CCR determined at final settlement of the cost reporting period during which the discharge occurred.  
In change request 13566, we expanded the outlier reconciliation criteria effective for IPPS and LTCH PPS

14233.1  For cost reports with a begin 
date on or after October 1, 2025 (instead of cost reports with a begin date on or after October 1, 2024), MACs shall refer cost reports to the CMS Central Office for approval of reconciliation of the outlier payments of IPPS hospitals at the time of cost report settlement if the actual operating CCR is found to be plus or minus 20 percent or greater from the CCR used during that time period to make outlier payments, and the sum of operating and capital outlier payments in that cost reporting period exceed $500,000. 
If the MAC receives approval from the CMS Central Office, MACs shall follow the instructions in section 20.1.2.7 of Chapter 3 of the Medicare Claims Processing Manual and shall reconcile the outlier payments of the hospital.

A. Background: Under existing regulations at 42 CFR §412.84(i)(4) for the IPPS and 42 CFR 412.525(a) 
for the LTCH PPS, outlier payments may be reconciled upon cost report settlement to account for 
differences between the Cost -to-Charge Ratio (CCR) used to pay the claim at its original submission by the 
provider and the CCR determined at final settlement of the cost reporting period during which the discharge occurred.  
In change request 13566, we expanded the outlier reconciliation criteria effective for IPPS and LTCH PPS

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) payment system effective October 1, 2025, with implementation on October 6, 2025. It introduces new billing instructions and payment policies, including the addition of new device pass-through categories under the OPPS, applicable to ASCs. Two new devices, identified by HCPCS codes C1741 and C1742, have been preliminarily approved for pass-through status.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to incorporate new ASC payment policies and device pass-through categories.

key_requirements: Incorporate new HCPCS codes C1741 and C1742 into billing systems.
Ensure compliance with updated ASC payment policies.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) Payment System effective October 1, 2025. Key changes include new device pass-through categories, a new HCPCS code for a specific surgical procedure, and updates to drug, biological, and radiopharmaceutical coding. These updates are intended to align with the Hospital Outpatient Prospective Payment System (OPPS) and ensure accurate billing and reimbursement for ASCs.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to incorporate new HCPCS codes and payment indicators.

key_requirements: Implement new HCPCS codes for device pass-through payments.
Update billing procedures for drugs, biologicals, and radiopharmaceuticals.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines updates to the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) Payment System effective October 1, 2025
source_citations.supporting_text:
See the October 2025 ASC Addendum BB for updated payment 
rates effective October 1, 2025. We preliminarily approved 2 new devices for pass -through status under the Hospital OPPS with an 
effective date of October 1, 2025, that may be applicable in the ASC setting:  
● HCPCS code C1741  
● HCPCS code C1742  
We’ll discuss the device applications associated with C1741 and C1742 in the CY 2027 Hospital OPPS and ASC proposed and final rules
source_citations.context:
transitional pass -through payments for at least 2 but not more than 3 years  under the Hospital OPPS . 
In addition, section 1833(t)(6)(B)(ii)(IV) of the Social Security Act requires that CMS create additional 
categories for transitional pass -through payment of new medical devices not described by existing or 
previously existing device categories. We also implemented this policy in the ASC payment system.  
We’re required by section 1833(t)(6)(D)(ii) of the Social Security Act  to deduct from pass -through 
payments for devices in the Hospital OPPS an amount that shows the device portion of the 
ambulatory payment classification (APC) payment amount. This deduction is the device offset or the 
portion of the APC amount that’s associated with the pass -through device cost. We also implement 
this device offset policy in ASCs. The device offset from payment represents a deduction from  
pass -through payments from the ASC procedure payment for the applicable pass -through device.  
W

source_citations.context:
transitional pass -through payments for at least 2 but not more than 3 years  under the Hospital OPPS . 
In addition, section 1833(t)(6)(B)(ii)(IV) of the Social Security Act requires that CMS create additional 
categories for transitional pass -through payment of new medical devices not described by existing or 
previously existing device categories. We also implemented this policy in the ASC payment system.  
We’re required by section 1833(t)(6)(D)(ii) of the Social Security Act  to deduct from pass -through 
payments for devices in the Hospital OPPS an amount that shows the device portion of the 
ambulatory payment classification (APC) payment amount. This deduction is the device offset or the 
portion of the APC amount that’s associated with the pass -through device cost. We also implement 
this device offset policy in ASCs. The device offset from payment represents a deduction from  
pass -through payments from the ASC procedure payment for the applicable pass -through device.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Medicare Claims Processing Manual, specifically Chapter 18, Section 210, to include Place of Service code 19 for Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) screening services. It introduces a new HCPCS code G0567 for HCV screening procedures, effective June 27, 2024. The implementation date for these changes is October 20, 2025, and they align with the National Coverage Determination 210.13.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to include POS code 19 and HCPCS code G0567
Educate clinical staff on new HCV screening procedures

key_requirements: Contractors shall be aware of the POS updates to the IOM Pub. Chapter 18, Section 210.
Contractors shall be aware of the new HCPCS code G0567, Screening Hep C detect.

SUBJECT: Update  to Pub 100-04, Chapter  18 - Preventive and  Screening  Services  
 
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES:  The purpose  of this  Change  Request  (CR) is  to update  Publication  100-04, 
Medicare Claims Processing Manual, Chapter 18, Section 210 to incorporate Place of Service (POS) code 19 (Off Campus -Outpatient Hospital) as an approved setting for Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) screening 
services. Additionally, this  CR adds the new  Healthcare Common Procedure  Coding System (HCPCS) code 
G0567 for HCV screening procedures.  
 
EFFECTIVE DATE:  June  27, 2024  
*Unless  otherwise  specified,  the effective  date is the date of service.  
IMPLEMENTATION  DATE:  October 20, 2025

source_citations.claim: The document outlines updates to the Medicare Claims Processing Manual, specifically Chapter 18, Section 210, to include Place of Service code 19 for Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) screening services
source_citations.supporting_text:
For claims with dates of service on or after June 2, 2014, Medicare will allow coverage for HCV screening, HCPCS  G0472 or  G0567 (Effective  June 27, 2024) , only when  submitted  with  one of the 
following place of service (POS) codes:  
 
11 - Physician’s  Office  
19 – Off Campus -Outpatient  Hospital 
22 – On  Campus  -Outpatient  Hospital 
49 - Independent Clinic  
71 - State  or Local  Public  Health  Clinic 
81 - Independent Laboratory 
 
HCV screening  claims  submitted  without one  o
source_citations.context:
birth  year.  “High  risk”  is defined  as persons  with a current  or past  history of illicit injection  drug 
use and persons who have a history of receiving a blood transfusion prior to 1992. 
 
3. Repeat  HCV screening  for a sub-set of high risk persons  regardless  of birth  year is  covered 
annually only for persons who have had continued illicit injection drug use since the prior negative HCV screening test.  
 
NOTE:  Annual  means  a full 11 months  must  elapse following the month in which  the previous 
negative HCV screening took place.  
 
B. Determination  of High  Risk  for Hepatitis  C Disease  
 
The determination  of “high risk for HCV”  is identified  by the  primary  care physician or practitioner  who 
assesses the patient’s history, which is part of any complete medical history, typically part of an annual 
wellness visit, and considered in the development of a comprehensive prevention plan. The medical 
record should be a reflection of the service provided.

source_citations.context:
NOTE:  
Anesthesia services furnished in conjunction with and in support of a screening 
colonoscopy  are reported  with CPT code  00812 and coinsurance  and deductible  are 
waived.  When a screening colonoscopy becomes a diagnostic colonoscopy, 
anesthesia services are reported with CPT code 00811 and with the PT modifier; 
only the deductible is waived.  
Coinsurance  and deductible  are waived  for moderate  sedation  services  (reported  with 
G0500 or 99153) when  furnished in conjunction with and in support of a screening 
colonoscopy service and when reported with modifier 33.  When a screening 
colonoscopy  becomes  a diagnostic  colonoscopy, moderate sedation  services  (G0500 
or 99153) are reported with only the PT modifier; only the deductible is waived.  
For dates of service in calendar year (CY) 2023 through CY 2026, when the PT 
modifier is appended to at least one code on the claim to indicate that a screening 
colorectal cancer procedure, HCPCS G0104, G0105, or G0121

3. Repeat  HCV screening  for a sub-set of high risk persons  regardless  of birth  year is  covered 
annually only for persons who have had continued illicit injection drug use since the prior negative HCV screening test.  
 
NOTE:  Annual  means  a full 11 months  must  elapse following the month in which  the previous 
negative HCV screening took place.  
 
B. Determination  of High  Risk  for Hepatitis  C Disease  
 
The determination  of “high risk for HCV”  is identified  by the  primary  care physician or practitioner  who 
assesses the patient’s history, which is part of any complete medical history, typically part of an annual 
wellness visit, and considered in the development of a comprehensive prevention plan. The medical 
record should be a reflection of the service provided.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document updates the Medicare Claims Processing Manual, Chapter 18, to include new provisions for Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) preventive screening services. It introduces HCPCS code G0567 for HCV screening procedures and adds place of service (POS) code 19 as an approved setting. These changes are effective from June 27, 2024, and aim to align with National Coverage Determination 210.13. The update waives patient deductibles and coinsurance for these services.

next_steps.action: Inform billing staff about the new HCPCS code G0567 and POS code 19 for HCV screening services.

key_requirements: Incorporate HCPCS code G0567 for HCV screening in billing processes.
Ensure compliance with the updated POS code 19 for off-campus outpatient hospital settings.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to Chapter 10 of the CMS Program Integrity Manual, focusing on provider enrollment procedures. It incorporates existing procedures and makes minor technical edits for clarity. No new procedures or practices are introduced, and the changes are effective from October 20, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and integrate the updated provider enrollment procedures into existing processes.

key_requirements: The contractor shall observe the additions and technical edits to Chapter 10 of CMS Pub. 100-08.

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The CMS Pub. 100-08, Chapter 10, outlines Medicare provider enrollment 
procedures and instructions. This CR has several objectives. First, it will formally add to Chapter 10 a number of existing operational procedures that have already been issued via othe r CRs and CMS 
directives. Second, it will make minor technical edits for purposes of clarity. No new procedures or practices will be established.  
B. Policy: This CR does not involve any legislative or regulatory policies.

The supplier must list the geographic areas in which it provides services.  If the supplier indicates that it furnishes services:  
 
• In more than one contractor's jurisdiction, it must submit a separate Form CMS -855B to each 
contractor.

When processing a Form CMS-855A, CMS-855B, CMS-855I, CMS-855S, or CMS-20134 initial or change of ownership application (if applicable), the contractor shall determine – using a system generated monthly listing – whether the provider, supplier, or any owner listed in Section 5 or 6 of the application has an existing or delinquent Medicare overpayment, as described in section 10
source_citations.context:
When processing a Form CMS-855A, CMS-855B, CMS-855I, CMS-855S, or CMS-20134 initial or change of ownership application (if applicable), the contractor shall determine – using a system generated monthly listing – whether the provider, supplier, or any owner listed in Section 5 or 6 of the application has an existing or delinquent Medicare overpayment, as described in section 10.4.2.2(F)(1) above and § 424.530(a)(6).  If such an overpayment exists, the contractor shall deny the application, using 42 CFR §424.530(a)(6) as the basis.  However, prior PEOG approval is required before proceeding with the denial.  The contractor shall under no circumstances deny an application under § 424.530(a)(6) without receiving PEOG approval to do so.  3. Examples 
 
Example #1:  Dr. X, a sole proprietor, has a $70,000 overpayment.  Three months later, Dr. X joins 
Group Y and becomes a 50 percent owner thereof.  Group Y submits an initial enrollment 
application two months thereafter.  Group Y’s enrollm

a.  Verification  
 If an FQHC is changing the physical location of an existing site, the FQHC must submit the following documentation (as applicable to that FQHC) to the contractor:   
• For §330 grantees, a HRSA Notice of Grant Award (NOA) approving the physical location

physical location change and listing the new address.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically Chapter 46 related to Rural Health Clinic Cost Reports. It includes revisions to instructions and forms, particularly addressing the end of productivity standards and updates to vaccine cost reporting. The changes are effective for cost reporting periods ending after December 31, 2024.

next_steps.action: Review and implement updated cost reporting instructions and forms.
next_steps.timeline: Before the end of the next cost reporting period after December 31, 2024.

key_requirements: Update cost reporting processes to align with new instructions.
Ensure accurate reporting of vaccine costs, including hepatitis B.

source_citations.claim: The document is a CMS transmittal updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically Chapter 46 related to Rural Health Clinic Cost Reports
source_citations.supporting_text:
Rural health clinics (RHCs) must file cost reports in 
accordance with 42 CFR 413. These forms must be used by all independent rural health clinics (RHC) for cost reporting periods 
beginning on or after October 1, 2017, and ending on or after September 30, 2018
source_citations.context:
4600.  GENERAL 
The Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 establishes the requirement that the private sector be 
informed why information is collected and how it will be used by the government.  In accordance 
with §§1815(a) and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the Act), providers of medical and 
other healthcare services as defined under §1861(s), participating in the Medicare program are 
required to submit annual information to achieve settlement of costs for health care services 
rendered to Medicare beneficiaries.  Rural health clinics (RHCs) must file cost reports in 
accordance with 42 CFR 413.24(f).  The data submitted on the cost reports supports management 
of federal programs.  The information reported on Form CMS-222-17, must conform to the 
requirements and principles set forth in the Provider Reimbursement Manual, CMS Pub. 15-1, as 
well as those set forth in the Medicare Benefit Policy Manual, CMS Pub. 100-02, chapter 13, and 
the Medicare Claims Processing Manual, C

source_citations.supporting_text:
Cost center coding is a methodology for standardizing the meaning of cost center labels as used 
by health care providers on the Medicare cost reports. --This cost center includes the cost related to the structured 
recording of patient health information, an electronic health care plan addressing all health issues, 
access to chronic care management (CCM) services, managing care transitions, and coordinating 
and sharing patient information with practitioners and providers outside the practice
source_citations.context:
BALANCE OF EXPENSES 
 
Use Worksheet A to record the trial balance of expense accounts from your accounting books and 
records.  The worksheet also provides for the necessary reclassifications and adjustments to certain 
accounts.  All cost centers listed do not apply to all RHCs using this worksheet.  For example, an 
RHC that does not have an intern and resident program will not complete lines 29 and/or 78.  In 
addition to those lines listed, the worksheet also provides blank lines for other RHC cost centers.  
Complete only those lines that are applicable. 
 
If the cost elements of a cost center are maintained separately on your books, a reconciliation of 
costs per the accounting books and records to those on this worksheet must be maintained and are 
subject to review by your contractor. 
 
Standard (i.e., preprinted) CMS line numbers and cost center descriptions cannot be changed.  If 
additional or different cost center descriptions are needed, add additional lines to the cos
source_citations.section: 4607. WORKSHEET A - RECLASSIFICATION AND ADJUSTMENT OF TRIAL

source_citations.context:
Worksheet B is used by the RHC to summarize (1) the visits furnished by your health care staff and 
by physicians under agreements with you, and (2) the overhead costs incurred by you which apply 
to RHC services. 
 
4611.1 Part I - Visits and Productivity.--Use Part I to summarize the number of facility visits 
furnished by the health care staff and to calculate the number of visits to be used in the rate 
determination.  Productivity standards established by CMS are applied as a guideline that reflects 
the total combined services of the staff.  Apply a level of 4200 visits for each physician and a level 
of 2100 visits for each nonphysician practitioner. (See CMS Pub. 100-02, chapter 13, §80.4.)  
Effective  for cost reporting periods ending after December 31, 2024, productivity standards no 
longer apply.   
 
Lines 1 through 11 (and applicable subscripts) of Part I list the types of practitioners (positions) 
for whom facility visits must be counted and reported.

source_citations.context:
Column 5.--Enter the greater of the visits from column 2 or column 4.  Contractors have the authority 
to waive the productivity guideline in cases where you have demonstrated reasonable justification 
for not meeting the standard.  In such cases, the contractor could set any number of visits as 
reasonable (not just your actual visits) if an exception is granted.  For example, if the guideline 
number is 4200 visits and you have only furnished 1000 visits, the contractor need not accept the 
1000 visits but could permit 2500 visits to be used in the calculation.  Effective for cost reporting 
periods ending after December 31, 2024, transfer the visits from column 2 to column 5 and do not 
apply productivity standards.

source_citations.context:
QUESTIONNAIRE 
 
This worksheet collects organizational, financial and statistical information previously reported on 
Form CMS-339.  Where instructions for this worksheet direct the RHC to submit 
documentation/information, mail or otherwise transmit the requested documentation to the 
contractor with submission of the electronic cost report (ECR).  The contractor has the right under 
§§1815(a) and 1883(e) of the Act to request any missing documentation.  When filing a 
consolidated cost report, this worksheet applies only to the primary RHC.  
 
To the degree that the information in the questionnaire constitutes commercial or financial 
information which is confidential and/or is of a highly sensitive personal nature, the information 
will be protected from release under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).  If there is any 
question about releasing information, the contractor should consult with the CMS Regional Office. 
 
NOTE: The responses on all lines are “yes” or “no” unless

source_citations.context:
The cost and administration of pneumococcal and influenza  vaccines to Medicare beneficiaries are 
paid at 100 percent of reasonable cost .  Effective January 1, 2025, hepatitis B vaccines and their 
administration are paid at 100 percent of reasonable cost.  This worksheet provides for the 
computation of the cost of the pneumococcal , influenza , and hepatitis B  vaccines.  Additionally, in 
accordance with §3713 of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, 
during the COVID-19 public health emergency (PHE), this worksheet computes the cost of COVID-
19 vaccines and monoclonal antibody products for treatment of COVID-19 and their administration 
to Medicare and Medicare Advantage (MA) enrollees for calendar years 2020 and 2021. 
 
For services rendered prior to July 1, 2025, report  the applicable data in columns 1, 2, 2.01, and 
2.02, for pneumococcal vaccines, influenza vaccines, COVID-19 vaccines, and monoclonal 
antibody products for treatment of COVID-19,

with §§1815(a) and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the Act), providers of medical and

source_citations.context:
4600.  GENERAL 
The Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 establishes the requirement that the private sector be 
informed why information is collected and how it will be used by the government.  In accordance 
with §§1815(a) and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the Act), providers of medical and 
other healthcare services as defined under §1861(s), participating in the Medicare program are 
required to submit annual information to achieve settlement of costs for health care services 
rendered to Medicare beneficiaries.  Rural health clinics (RHCs) must file cost reports in 
accordance with 42 CFR 413.24(f).  The data submitted on the cost reports supports management 
of federal programs.  The information reported on Form CMS-222-17, must conform to the 
requirements and principles set forth in the Provider Reimbursement Manual, CMS Pub. 15-1, as 
well as those set forth in the Medicare Benefit Policy Manual, CMS Pub. 100-02, chapter 13, and 
the Medicare Claims Processing Manual, C

Use this worksheet to determine the interim all inclusive rate of payment and the total Medicare 
payment reimbursement calculation for RHC services rendered to program patients for the reporting 
period. 
 
4613.1 Part I - Determination of Rate for RHC Services.--Use Part I to calculate the cost per visit 
for RHC services and to apply the screening guideline established by CMS on your health care staff 
productivity. 
 
Line 1.--Enter the total allowable cost from Worksheet B, Part II, line 18. 
 
Line 2.--Enter the total cost of injections/infusions from Worksheet B-1, line 15. 
 
Line 3.--Subtract the amount on line 2 from the amount on line 1 and enter the result. 
 
Line 4.--For cost reporting periods ending on or before December 31, 2024, enter  the greater of the 
minimum or actual visits by the health care staff from Worksheet B, Part I, column 5, line 10.  For 
cost reporting periods ending after December 31, 2024, enter the number of visits by health care 
staff from Works

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal related to the Rural Health Clinic Cost Report, which is required by law. It outlines the procedures for submitting cost reports, including certification by a CFO or administrator, and the potential consequences of misrepresentation. The document also provides instructions for the settlement summary and electronic signature requirements.

next_steps.action: Ensure all cost reports are prepared and submitted accurately and timely.
next_steps.timeline: Before the end of the reporting period

key_requirements: Cost reports must be certified by a CFO or administrator.
Reports must be prepared from the provider's books and records in compliance with applicable laws.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a transmittal from CMS updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically for Community Mental Health Center Cost Reports using Form CMS-2088-17. It includes revisions to instructions, worksheets, and electronic cost report specifications, effective for cost reporting periods ending on or after October 1, 2025. Key changes involve updates to Worksheet S-2 and the addition of new edits to the electronic specifications.

next_steps.action: Review and implement changes to Worksheet S-2 and electronic reporting specifications.

key_requirements: Update Worksheet S-2 with new instructions
Implement new electronic reporting edits 1030C and 1010D

source_citations.supporting_text:
Community mental health centers (CMHCs) 
providing partial hospitalization program (PHP) services must file cost reports  in accordance with

and principles set forth in the Provider Reimbursement Manual , CMS Pub
source_citations.context:
The Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 establishes the requirement that the private sector be 
informed why information is collected and how it will be used by the government.  In accordance 
with §§1815(a), 1866(e)(2) , and 1861(v)(1)(A) of the Social Security Act (the Act ), providers of 
medical and other healthcare services as defined under §1861( ff), participating in the Medicare 
program are required to submit annual information to achieve settlement of costs for health care 
services rendered to Medicare beneficiaries.   Community mental health centers (CMHCs) 
providing partial hospitalization program (PHP) services must file cost reports  in accordance with 
42 CFR 413.24(f) .  The data submitted on the cost reports supports management of federal 
programs.  The information reported on Form CMS -2088-17, must conform to the requirements 
and principles set forth in the Provider Reimbursement Manual , CMS Pub. 15-1, as well as those 
set forth in the Medicare Benefit Policy Manu

TABLE 6 - EDITS  
 
Medicare cost reports submitted electronically must meet a variety of edits. These include mathematical accuracy edits, certain minimum file requirements, and other data edits
source_citations.context:
TABLE 6 - EDITS  
 
Medicare cost reports submitted electronically must meet a variety of edits.  These include mathematical accuracy edits, certain minimum file requirements, and other data edits.  Any vendor software which produces an ECR file for Medicare CMHCs must automate all of these edits.  
Failure to properly implement these edits may result in the suspension of a vendor's system certification until corrective action is taken.  The vendor’s software should provide meaningful error me ssages to notify the CMHC of the ca use of every exception.  The edit message generated 
by the vendor systems must contain the related 4 digit and 1 alpha character, where indicated, reject/edit code specified below.  Any file submitted by a provider containing a level  1 edit will be 
rejected by the contractors.  Notification must be made to CMS for any exceptions.  
 The edits are applied at two levels.  Level 1 edits (1000 series reject codes) test the format of the 
data to identify error c

source_citations.context:
In accordance with 42 CFR 413.9, 42 CFR 415.55, 42 CFR 415.60, 42 CFR 415.70, and 42 CFR 415.102(d), you may claim as allowable cost only those costs which you incur for 
physician services that benefit the general patient population of the provider.  42 CFR 415.70 imposes limits on the amount of physician compensation which may be recognized as a reasonable provider cost.  
 
Worksheet A -8-2 provides for the computation of the allowable provider -based physician cost you 
incur.  42 CFR 415.60 provides that the physician compensation paid by you must be allocated 
between services to individual patients (professional services), services that benefit your patients generally (provider services), and nonreimbursable services such as research.  Only provider 
services are reimbursable to you through the cost report.  This worksheet also provides for the 
computation of the reasonable compensation equivalent (RCE) limits required by 42 CFR 415.70.  The methodology used in this worksheet

source_citations.claim: Implement new electronic reporting edits 1030C and 1010D
source_citations.supporting_text:
TABLE 6 - EDITS  
 
Medicare cost reports submitted electronically must meet a variety of edits. Failure to properly implement these edits may result in the suspension of a vendor's system certification until corrective action is taken
source_citations.context:
TABLE 6 - EDITS  
 
Medicare cost reports submitted electronically must meet a variety of edits.  These include mathematical accuracy edits, certain minimum file requirements, and other data edits.  Any vendor software which produces an ECR file for Medicare CMHCs must automate all of these edits.  
Failure to properly implement these edits may result in the suspension of a vendor's system certification until corrective action is taken.  The vendor’s software should provide meaningful error me ssages to notify the CMHC of the ca use of every exception.  The edit message generated 
by the vendor systems must contain the related 4 digit and 1 alpha character, where indicated, reject/edit code specified below.  Any file submitted by a provider containing a level  1 edit will be 
rejected by the contractors.  Notification must be made to CMS for any exceptions.  
 The edits are applied at two levels.  Level 1 edits (1000 series reject codes) test the format of the 
data to identify error c

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal related to the cost reporting requirements for Community Mental Health Centers (CMHCs). It outlines the legal obligations for submitting cost reports, the potential consequences of non-compliance, and the certification process by a Chief Financial Officer or Administrator. The document also includes instructions for completing the cost report and emphasizes the importance of accurate and truthful reporting to avoid legal repercussions.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CMS has issued an update to the Program Integrity Manual, specifically targeting inpatient hospital claims. This update removes the requirement for contractors to use proprietary screening tools and introduces new guidelines for patient status reviews. The responsibility for short stay inpatient hospital medical reviews has shifted from BFCC-QIO to Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs).

next_steps.action: Review and update internal processes to align with the new guidelines in Chapter 6 of Pub. 100-08 PIM.

key_requirements: Contractors shall conduct medical review in accordance with the updated sections in Chapter 6 of Pub. 100-08 PIM.
MACs will perform prepayment review of Medicare Part A claims as part of the Targeted Probe and Educate program.

source_citations.claim: The responsibility for short stay inpatient hospital medical reviews has shifted from BFCC-QIO to Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs)
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: On May 22, 2025, CMS announced that Medicare Administrative 
Contractors (MACs) will assume responsibility for conducting short stay inpatient hospital medical reviews and provider education (i. , patient status reviews) to determine the appropriateness of Part A payment for short stay inpatient hospital claims beginning on or after September 1, 2025
source_citations.context:
A. Background: On May 22, 2025, CMS announced that Medicare Administrative 
Contractors (MACs) will assume responsibility for conducting short stay inpatient hospital medical reviews and provider education (i.e., patient status reviews) to determine the appropriateness of Part A payment for short stay inpatient hospital claims beginning on or after September 1, 2025.  These reviews were previously conducted by the Beneficiary and 
Family Centered Care Quality  Improvement Organization (BFCC -QIO). MACs will per form 
prepayment review of Medicare Part A claims as part of the Targeted Probe and Educate program.  
B. Policy: 42 Code of Federal Regulations 412.3

source_citations.claim: The responsibility for short stay inpatient hospital medical reviews has shifted from BFCC-QIO to Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs)

selection of claims for medical review, and a 2 -midnight benchmark, which helps guide 
contractor reviews of short stay hospital claims for Part A paymen t. For purposes of determining the appropriateness of Medicare Part A payment, Medicare 
contractors shall conduct reviews of medical records for inpatient acute IPPS

source_citations.context:
For hospital stays that are expected to span less than 2 midnights, an inpatient admission may be payable under Medicare Part A on a case- by-case or individualized basis if the medical 
record supports the admitting physician/practitioner’s judgment that the beneficiary required hospital care on an inpatient basis despite the lack of a 2- midnight expectation. Medicare 
contractors shall consider, when assessing the physician’s decision, complex medical factors including, but not limited to:  
 
• The beneficiary history and comorbidities;  
• The severity of signs and symptoms;  
• Current medical needs; and 
• The risk of an adverse event.  
 
Medicare contractors shall note CMS’ expectation that stays under 24 hours would rarely qualify for an exception to the 2-  midnight benchmark, and as such, may be prioritized for 
medical review.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines revisions to Appendix C of the CMS Manual System, specifically focusing on survey procedures and interpretive guidelines for laboratories and laboratory services. These changes incorporate feedback from various stakeholders, including regional offices, state agencies, and professional organizations, as well as findings from a GAO audit. The updates reflect recent regulatory publications and advancements in laboratory medicine technologies.

next_steps.action: Review and update internal compliance protocols to align with new CMS guidelines.

key_requirements: Adherence to updated survey procedures
Implementation of new interpretive guidelines for laboratory services

This appendix provides survey protocols and additional guidance on the following sections of the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendment (CLIA) Regulations. 
(Rev. 140, Issued 05- 29-15) 
 
Subpart A --General Provisions 
 
§493.1 Basis and scope  
(Rev. 140, Issued: 05- 29-15, Effective: 05 -29-15, Implementation: 05- 29-15) 
 This part sets forth the conditions that all laboratories must meet to be certified to perform testing on human specimens under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA).  It implements sections 1861(e) and (j), the sentence following s ection 1861(s)(13), and 1902(a)(9) of the Social Security Act, and section 
353 of the Public Health Service Act, as amended by section 2 of the Taking Essential Steps for Testing Act of 2012.  This part applies to all laboratories as defined under “laborat ory” in §493.2 of this part.  This part also applies to 
laboratories seeking payment under the Medicare and Medicaid programs.  The requirements are t

§493.1289 Standard: Analytic systems quality assessment . 
 (a) The laboratory must establish and follow written policies and procedures for an ongoing mechanism to monitor, assess, and when indicated, correct problems identified in the analytic systems specified in §§493.1251 through 493.1283.  Interpretive Guidelines §493.1289(a) -(c) 
 Quality Assessment (QA) is an ongoing review process that encompasses all facets of the laboratory’ s technical and non- technical functions at all location/sites where testing is 
performed.  QA also extends to the laboratory’s interactions with and responsibilities to patients, physicians, other laboratories ordering tests, and non- laboratory areas of the 
facility of which it is a part.

§493.15(e) Laboratories eligible for a certificate of waiver must -- 
  (1) Follow manufacturers’ instructions for performing the test; and  
  (2) Meet the requirements in subpart B, Certificate of Waiver, of this part.  
 Interpretive Guidelines §493.15(e)  
 Tests listed on the waiver list in §493.15(c) are not  subject to routine survey.  A survey 
of waived tests may be conducted only when authorized by CMS in the following instances:  
 
• Determine if a laboratory is testing outside its certificate;  
• Collect information regarding the appropriateness of tests specified as waived tests; 
• Investigate a complaint from the public; and/or  
• Determine if the laboratory is operated and if testing is performed in a manner that does not constitute an imminent and serious risk to public health. 
 Refer to §§493.1773 and 493.1775 for additional guidelines for inspecting laboratories issued a certificate

The scope of risk assessments must encompass the entire testing process  - preanalytic, 
analytic, and postanalytic phases -  and include, at a minimum, the evaluation of the five 
risk assessment components listed above for each test for which the laboratory wishes to employ IQCP.  Use D5445. 
 
The laboratory director has the responsibility for ensuring that the risk assessment considers the CLIA Quality System requirements at 42 C.F.R. 493, Subpart K for accurate, reliable, and timely test results and that test result quality is  appropriate for 
patient care.  Re-evaluation of the RA must be considered by the director or his/her 
designee when changes occur in any of the following components: specimen, test system, reagent, environment and testing personnel.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines revisions to the State Operations Manual (SOM) Chapter 5, specifically sections 5500 to 5590, which pertain to the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA). These changes include updates to complaint investigation procedures in various laboratory settings, including non-accredited and accredited laboratories. The revisions aim to clarify and streamline the processes for conducting investigations and post-investigation actions.

next_steps.action: Review and update internal procedures to align with the revised SOM Chapter 5 guidelines.

key_requirements: Adherence to updated complaint investigation procedures for non-accredited laboratories.
Implementation of new guidelines for conducting investigations in laboratories with various certificates.

source_citations.context:
There are several entities that may address laboratory complaints including: CMS, SAs, SLLPs, and Accreditation Organizations (AO).  Each of these entities share a strong interest ensuring the quality of patient care and the services provided by laboratori es.  When the 
complaint involves more than one of these entities, CMS should coordinate communication to ensure an effective and timely resolution of the issue.  NOTE:  If a SA surveyor identifies potential fraudulent billing activities on a complaint 
survey,  the surveyor  should refer  the information to CMS  so that  the information can be 
referred to the State OIG with a copy to CMS.  CMS can then refer the laboratory to the 
federal OIG.  
 
5500.1 - Control  
(Rev.  234; Issued: 09- 12-25; Effective: 09 -12-25; Implementation: 09- 12-25) 
 The SA establishes a file for the complaint and logs the action in to the CLIA  Data System.   
The system  may  be manual  or automated but  must  facilitate  tracking  and control of al

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a change request by CMS to update claims processing systems for Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) to allow billing using HCPCS code P9603 calculated to the tenth of a mile. This change, effective April 1, 2026, aims to improve accuracy in reporting and reimbursement for travel allowances related to specimen collection from Medicare beneficiaries. The update rescinds a previous transmittal and adjusts business requirements, removing certain systems and responsibilities.

next_steps.action: Update claims processing systems to accommodate the new billing calculation for HCPCS code P9603.

key_requirements: Update claims processing systems for HCPCS code P9603 to calculate to the tenth of a mile.
Ensure compliance with the new effective and implementation dates.

is acceptable when calculated to the tenth of a mile (ex. Laboratories  bill Medicare using HCPCS  code  P9603 to receive payment  for the per-mile travel  
allowance amount, prorated by the number of beneficiaries for whom a specimen collection fee is 
paid

authorized by the Contracting Officer. If the contractor considers anything provided, as described above, to be outside the current scope of work, the contractor shall withhold performanc e on the part(s) in question

source_citations.claim: This change, effective April 1, 2026, aims to improve accuracy in reporting and reimbursement for travel allowances related to specimen collection from Medicare beneficiaries
source_citations.supporting_text:
HCPCS code P9603 specifically relates to travel allowance for specimen collection, which allows for reimbursement of transportation when collecting specimens from eligible Medicare beneficiaries. Policy: This Change Request (CR) instructs Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) to update 
their claims processing systems to allow the billing, acceptance, and adjudication of claims submitted with 
Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) code P9603 calculated to the tenth of a mile for
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Section 1833(h)(3)(B) of the Social Security Act authorizes Medicare payment for 
transportation and personnel expenses incurred by trained personnel traveling to collect specimens from 
eligible Medicare beneficiaries. This travel allowance is specifically designed to cover the costs associated with specimen collection from homebound or non -hospital inpatients.  
B. Policy: This Change Request (CR) instructs Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) to update 
their claims processing systems to allow the billing, acceptance, and adjudication of claims submitted with 
Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) code P9603 calculated to the tenth of a mile for claims with date of service on or after April 1, 2026. This enhancement provides more accurate reporting 
and reimbursement for certain travel distances.

their claims processing systems to allow the billing, acceptance, and adjudication of claims submitted with 
Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) code P9603 calculated to the tenth of a mile for claims with date of service on or after April 1, 2026. HCPCS code P9603 specifically relates to travel allowance for specimen collection, which allows for reimbursement of transportation when col
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Section 1833(h)(3)(B) of the Social Security Act authorizes Medicare payment for 
transportation and personnel expenses incurred by trained personnel traveling to collect specimens from 
eligible Medicare beneficiaries. This travel allowance is specifically designed to cover the costs associated with specimen collection from homebound or non -hospital inpatients.  
B. Policy: This Change Request (CR) instructs Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) to update 
their claims processing systems to allow the billing, acceptance, and adjudication of claims submitted with 
Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) code P9603 calculated to the tenth of a mile for claims with date of service on or after April 1, 2026. This enhancement provides more accurate reporting 
and reimbursement for certain travel distances.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the January 2026 update to ICD-10 and other coding revisions for National Coverage Determinations (NCDs). It highlights that no substantive changes were made other than updating the CR release date, transmittal numbers, and links. Key updates include changes to NCDs related to mammograms, PET scans for oncologic conditions, breast biopsies, dermal injections for facial lipodystrophy syndrome, adult liver transplantation, and therapies for wound treatment. Providers are advised to ensure their billing staff is aware of these updates.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff is informed about the updated NCDs and ICD-10 codes.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new ICD-10 codes effective January 1, 2026.
Review NCD spreadsheets for CR 14194 for detailed coding changes.

Background

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal updating ICD-10 coding changes specific to National Coverage Determinations (NCDs) effective January 1, 2026. It rescinds a previous transmittal to update policy sections and assigns responsibility to DME MACs for a specific business requirement. The update is part of routine maintenance and does not include policy-related changes.

A.  Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to provide a maintenance update of ICD -10 
conversions and other coding updates specific to NCDs. These NCD coding changes are the result of newly 
available codes, coding revisions to NCDs released separately, or c oding feedback received. Previous NCD 
coding changes appear in ICD -10 quarterly updates that can be found at: 
https://www.cms.gov/medicare/coverage/determination -process/basics/icd -10 
along with other CRs implementing new policy NCDs. Edits to ICD -10 and other coding updates specific to 
NCDs will be included in subsequent quarterly releases and individual CRs as appropriate. No policy- related 
changes are included with the ICD -10 quarter ly updates. Any policy- related changes to NCDs continue to be 
implemented via the current, longstanding NCD process.

quarterly releases as needed. No policy- rela

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the January 2026 update to ICD-10 and other coding revisions for National Coverage Determinations (NCDs). It highlights that no substantive changes were made other than updating the CR release date, transmittal numbers, and links. Key updates include changes to specific NCDs such as cardiac output monitoring, next-generation sequencing, and colorectal cancer screening tests. Providers are advised to ensure their billing staff is aware of these updates.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the October 2025 quarterly update for the Durable Medical Equipment, Prosthetics, Orthotics, and Supplies (DMEPOS) fee schedule. It includes updates to fee schedule amounts for new and existing codes and changes in payment policies. The update is mandated by the Social Security Act and relevant regulations, and it affects payment methodologies for DMEPOS items, including those not covered by the Competitive Bidding Program (CBP). The update is effective from October 1, 2025, with implementation starting October 6, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect new DMEPOS fee schedule amounts.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new DMEPOS fee schedule.
Ensure compliance with updated payment policies.

source_citations.context:
included in the DMEPOS Competitive Bidding Program (CBP) for payment of the items in areas that are not included in the CBP. Sections 1834(h)(1)(H)(ii), 1842(s)(3)(B) and 1834(z)(3) of the Act provide authority 
to adjust the fee schedule amounts or national payment amounts for, respectively, off -the-shelf orthotics, 
enteral nutrients, equipment, and supplies (enteral nutrition), and lymphedema compression tre atment items 
based on information from the DMEPOS CBP. The methodologies for adjusting DMEPOS fee schedule or national payment amounts are established at 42 CFR §414.210(g). The DMEPOS and PEN fee schedule files contain Healthcare Common Procedure Coding S ystem (HCPCS) codes that are subject to fee schedule 
adjustments using information on the payment determined for these items under the CBP, as well as codes that are not subject to the CBP or fee schedule adjustments.

source_citations.claim: The update is mandated by the Social Security Act and relevant regulations, and it affects payment methodologies for DMEPOS items, including those not covered by the Competitive Bidding Program (CBP)
source_citations.supporting_text:
Also, the DMEPOS fee schedule file includes national payment amounts for lymphedema compression treatment items established in accordance with §1834(z) of the Act and regulations at 42 CFR §414. Background: Payment on a fee schedule basis is required for certain Durable Medical Equipment 
(DME), prosthetic devices, orthotics, prosthetics, and surgical dressings by Subsection (§)1834(a), (h), and (i) of the Social Security Act (the Act)
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Payment on a fee schedule basis is required for certain Durable Medical Equipment 
(DME), prosthetic devices, orthotics, prosthetics, and surgical dressings by Subsection (§)1834(a), (h), and (i) of the Social Security Act (the Act). Also, payment on a fee schedule basis is a regulatory requirement at 42 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) §414.102 for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (PEN), splints, casts and Intraocular Lenses (IOLs) inserted in a physician’s office. Also, the DMEPOS fee schedule file includes national payment amounts for lymphedema compression treatment items established in accordance with §1834(z) of the Act and regulations at 42 CFR §414.1650.

 Change Request 14214  
 
 
SUBJECT: October Quarterly Update for 2025 Durable Medical Equipment, Prosthetics, Orthotics 
and Supplies (DMEPOS) Fee Schedule  
 
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to update the DMEPOS fee schedule on a quarterly basis, when necessary, in order to implement fee schedule amounts for new and existing codes, as applicable, and apply changes in payment policies. This recurring update notification applies to publication 100-04, Medicare Claims Processing Manual, chapter 23, section 60.  
 
EFFECTIVE DATE: October 1, 2025  
*Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service.  
IMPLEMENTATION DATE: October 6, 2025  
 
Disclaimer for manual changes only: The revision date and transmittal number apply only to red

based on information from the DMEPOS CBP. The methodologies for adjusting DMEPOS fee schedule or national payment amounts are established at 42 CFR §414.210(g). The DMEPOS and PEN fee schedule files contain Healthcare Common Procedure Coding S ystem (HCPCS) codes that are subject to fee schedule 
adjustments using information on the payment determined for these items under the CBP, as well as codes that are not subject to the CBP or fee schedule adjustments.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the October 2025 quarterly update to the DMEPOS fee schedule, including the addition and deletion of HCPCS codes and corrections to deflation factors. It addresses changes in payment policies and fee schedule amounts for DMEPOS items, particularly in former Competitive Bidding Areas. The update also includes adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index and updates to rural ZIP Code designations.

next_steps.action: Inform billing staff about the updated HCPCS codes and fee schedule changes.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new HCPCS codes.
Adjust billing practices to reflect corrected deflation factors.

determinations for these items.

October 1, 2025.

2024 Deflation Factors  
We identified an error affecting several 2024 deflation factors listed in CR 13888 and the  
Medicare Claims Processing Manual, Chapter 23, section 60.3. CR 14214 corrects these 4  
deflation factors:  
● Surgical dressings – corrected from 0.447 to 0.446  
● PEN – corrected from 0.486 to 0.485  
● Splints and casts – corrected from 0.745 to 0.743  
● IOLs – corrected from 0

Sections 1834(a), (h), and (i) of the Social Security Act  require payment on a fee schedule basis for 
certain DMEPOS and surgical dressings. Regulations at 42 CFR 414.102 also require fee schedule 
payment for parenteral and enteral nutrition (PEN), splints, casts, and intraocular lenses (IOLs) 
inserted in a physician’s office. The DMEPOS fee schedule file includes national payment amounts 
for lymphedema compression treatment items established according to section 1834(z) of the  
Social Security Act  and regulations at 42 CFR 414.1650.  
Payment for Items Provided in Former Competitive Bidding Areas

All Medicare Round 2021 DMEPOS CB P contracts for off -the-shelf (OTS ) back braces and OTS knee 
braces expired on December 31, 2023.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a Change Request (CR) to enhance the MCS 276/277 claim response processing by incorporating Medicare Adjudication Portal (MAP) claims. This enhancement aims to provide a consolidated claim status response for a subset of professional claims processed in MAP. The changes are set to be effective from January 1, 2026, with implementation by January 5, 2026, specifically for CGS J15.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate MAP claims processing.

key_requirements: MCS shall access finalized MAP claims and update related jobs to include them in the 276 claim search process.
MCS shall provide a 277 claims status transaction response that consolidates MCS and MAP claim status.

SUBJECT: Enhancing MCS 276/277 Claim Status Processing to Include Medicare Adjudication

I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to enhance the MCS 276/277 claim response processing to: 1) use the Medicare Adjudication Portal (MAP) claims when performing the 276 claim search process, and 2) to provide a 277 claims status transaction response that consolidates MCS and MAP claim status. This work is in support of processing a subset of professional claims in MAP.

processed in MAP, currently planned for 12/31/2025, and for CGS J15 only. The 1/1/2026 effective date is to align with the January Release for hours only.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines a Change Request (CR) to enhance the MCS 276/277 claim response processing by incorporating Medicare Adjudication Portal (MAP) claims
source_citations.supporting_text:
When CMS begins to process some claims in MAP, the current process will no longer support a complete r esponse if a request involves claims 
that were not processed in MCS. Background: Currently, MCS uses pending and finalized claim history to satisfy the 276 claim status 
search criteria that requires looking across claims in the MCS application
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Currently, MCS uses pending and finalized claim history to satisfy the 276 claim status 
search criteria that requires looking across claims in the MCS application. When CMS begins to process some claims in MAP, MCS needs to maintain a complete view of the claim's history to accurately perform the 276 claim search. Claim status transactions currently come in on a 276 transaction via MAC EDI gateways. The Combined Common Edit Module (CCEM) receives and validates the transactions and processes accepted requests. MCS provides a status response, which is packaged as a compliant 277 transaction and transmitted via CCEM back to the MAC EDI gateways. When CMS begins to process some claims in MAP, the current process will no longer support a complete r esponse if a request involves claims 
that were not processed in MCS.  
B. Policy: This CR does not implement regulation or policy.

source_citations.claim: This enhancement aims to provide a consolidated claim status response for a subset of professional claims processed in MAP
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: Currently, MCS uses pending and finalized claim history to satisfy the 276 claim status 
search criteria that requires looking across claims in the MCS application. When CMS begins to process some claims in MAP, the current process will no longer support a complete r esponse if a request involves claims 
that were not processed in MCS
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Currently, MCS uses pending and finalized claim history to satisfy the 276 claim status 
search criteria that requires looking across claims in the MCS application. When CMS begins to process some claims in MAP, MCS needs to maintain a complete view of the claim's history to accurately perform the 276 claim search. Claim status transactions currently come in on a 276 transaction via MAC EDI gateways. The Combined Common Edit Module (CCEM) receives and validates the transactions and processes accepted requests. MCS provides a status response, which is packaged as a compliant 277 transaction and transmitted via CCEM back to the MAC EDI gateways. When CMS begins to process some claims in MAP, the current process will no longer support a complete r esponse if a request involves claims 
that were not processed in MCS.  
B. Policy: This CR does not implement regulation or policy.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal detailing a quarterly update to the Medicare Physician Fee Schedule Database (MPFSDB) for October 2025. It amends payment files based on the 2025 MPFS Final Rule, effective for services from January 1, 2025, to December 31, 2025. The update involves notifying Medicare contractors to retrieve revised payment data from a cloud service and implement it into their systems.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the quarterly update to the Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule (CLFS) and laboratory services subject to reasonable charge payment. It specifies the effective and implementation dates for the update and provides background on the changes required by the Protecting Access to Medicare Act of 2014. The document also details the next data reporting period for Clinical Diagnostic Laboratory Tests (CDLTs) and the payment reduction schedule for non-advanced diagnostic laboratory tests.

next_steps.action: Prepare for the next data reporting period for CDLTs from January 1, 2026, to March 31, 2026.

key_requirements: Report private payer rate information for applicable laboratories.
Ensure no payment reduction for CDLTs in CY 2025 compared to CY 2024.

B. Policy: Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule (CLFS)  
Section 1834A of the Act, as established by Section 216(a) of the Protecting Access to Medicare Act of

System Final Rule” (CMS -1621-F) was published in the Federal Register on June 23, 2016. The CLFS final 
rule implemented section 1834A of the Act.
