primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the October 2025 update to the Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule (CLFS) and laboratory services subject to reasonable charge payment. It includes new and deleted CPT codes effective October 1, 2025, and details the data reporting period for clinical diagnostic laboratory tests (CDLTs) that are not advanced diagnostic laboratory tests (ADLTs). The document also specifies a 0% payment reduction for CY 2025 and a maximum 15% reduction for CYs 2026-28 for CDLTs that are not ADLTs.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the new and deleted CPT codes effective October 1, 2025.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new and deleted CPT codes.
Prepare for the next data reporting period from January 1, 2026, to March 31, 2026.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a Change Request (CR) from CMS instructing Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) to educate providers on the prior authorization (PA) process for certain services in the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) setting. This initiative targets services like blepharoplasty, botulinum toxin injections, panniculectomy, rhinoplasty, and vein ablation, which have seen increased utilization and potential for improper payments. The CR is part of a demonstration project in ten states to ensure these services are medically necessary.

next_steps.action: Educate providers on the PA process for targeted services in the ASC setting.

key_requirements: Providers must request prior authorization for targeted services.
MACs to provide education on the PA process.

January 1, 2023) 
Provider NPI Number: Provider NPI 
Dear Provider:  
 
The purpose of this letter is to inform you that the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has 
implemented a Prior Authorization (PA) Demonstration for Certain Ambulatory Surgical Center 
(ASC) Services furnished on or after Insert Date here XX,XX,XXXX, in select states. The documentation to be included with a prior authorization r equest is information that providers are regularly required to maintain for Medicare
source_citations.context:
Mail Date (ex. January 1, 2023) 
Provider NPI Number: Provider NPI 
Dear Provider:  
 
The purpose of this letter is to inform you that the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has 
implemented a Prior Authorization (PA) Demonstration for Certain Ambulatory Surgical Center 
(ASC) Services furnished on or after Insert Date here XX,XX,XXXX, in select states . The states included 
in this demonstration are California, Florida, Texas, Arizona, Ohio, Tennessee, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Georgia, and New York.  
Prior Authorization is for the following certain ASC  services:  
 
i. Blepharoplasty, Eyelid Surgery, Brow Lift, and Related Services  
ii. Botulinum toxin injections  
iii. Panniculectomy , Excision of Excess Skin and Subcutaneous Tissue (Including Lipectomy), and 
Related Services  
iv. Rhinoplasty and Related Services  
v. Vein ablation  and Related Services  
 
If a provider does not obtain a prior authorization request and the service is furnished, the claim will be 
su

source_citations.claim: This initiative targets services like blepharoplasty, botulinum toxin injections, panniculectomy, rhinoplasty, and vein ablation, which have seen increased utilization and potential for improper payments
source_citations.supporting_text: The Calendar Year 2020 Outpatient Prospective Payment System/Ambulatory Surgical Center Final Rule (CMS -1717-FC) established a nationwide PA process and requirements for certain hospital outpatient department services - blepharoplasty, botulinum toxin injections, rhinoplasty, panniculectomy, and vein ablation. The service categories targeted by the demonstration are blepharoplasty, botulinum toxin injections, panniculectomy, rhinoplasty, and vein ablation procedures

source_citations.claim: The CR is part of a demonstration project in ten states to ensure these services are medically necessary
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The CMS is using Section 402(a)(1)(J)of the Social Security Act (the Act) 
demonstration authority for a demonstration project for the PA of certain services provided in ASCs in ten states. These targeted services can potentially be provided as cosmetic procedures, rather than medically necessary procedures, resulting in improper or fraudulent payments

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CMS transmittal R13397OTN introduces a change to the ViPS Medicare System (VMS) by adding a field to display the region on VMS screens. This change aims to help users differentiate between test and production regions, reducing errors in data processing. The implementation is set for January 5, 2026, with no policy changes involved.

next_steps.action: Review and update internal processes to accommodate the new VMS screen changes.

key_requirements: GDIT shall modify all the screens in the VMAP/4C - Claims Parameters to display a four-position indicator, TEST or PROD.
GDIT shall modify the VMAP/4C CARRIER screen to remove the OVERPAYMENT and FINANCE department fields.

source_citations.claim: The CMS transmittal R13397OTN introduces a change to the ViPS Medicare System (VMS) by adding a field to display the region on VMS screens
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to add a field on VMS screens that will 
display the region. Before the Durable Medical Equipment Medicare Administrative Contractors (DME MACs) transitioned to 
using Healthcare Integrated General Ledger Accounting System (HIGLAS), the VMS test region was future dated
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to add a field on VMS screens that will 
display the region. By displaying the region, users will be able to differentiate between test and production 
regions while they are reviewing and processing information. 
Before the Durable Medical Equipment Medicare Administrative Contractors (DME MACs) transitioned to 
using Healthcare Integrated General Ledger Accounting System (HIGLAS), the VMS test region was future dated. Because the date displays at  the bottom right footer on most VMS screens, users/operators were able 
to confirm the region by reviewing the date. The test region displayed a future date, and the production region displayed the current date. 
Now that both the production and test regions have the dates synchronized, it is difficult to differentiate 
between the two regions when viewing and updating information. Errors have occurred updating production data instead of test data due to the synchronized date. This

source_citations.claim: This change aims to help users differentiate between test and production regions, reducing errors in data processing

regions while they are reviewing and processing information. Now that both the production and test regions have the dates synchronized, it is difficult to differentiate 
between the two regions when viewing and updating information

source_citations.supporting_text:
Because the date displays at  the bottom right footer on most VMS screens, users/operators were able 
to confirm the region by reviewing the date. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to add a field on VMS screens that will 
display the region
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to add a field on VMS screens that will 
display the region. By displaying the region, users will be able to differentiate between test and production 
regions while they are reviewing and processing information. 
Before the Durable Medical Equipment Medicare Administrative Contractors (DME MACs) transitioned to 
using Healthcare Integrated General Ledger Accounting System (HIGLAS), the VMS test region was future dated. Because the date displays at  the bottom right footer on most VMS screens, users/operators were able 
to confirm the region by reviewing the date. The test region displayed a future date, and the production region displayed the current date. 
Now that both the production and test regions have the dates synchronized, it is difficult to differentiate 
between the two regions when viewing and updating information. Errors have occurred updating production data instead of test data due to the synchronized date. This

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the Fiscal Year 2026 updates to the Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) and Long-Term Care Hospital (LTCH) Prospective Payment System (PPS). These updates are part of a recurring Change Request (CR) and are effective for hospital discharges from October 1, 2025, to September 30, 2026. The updates include new IPPS and LTCH PPS Pricer software packages to ensure accurate payments.

Medicare, Medicaid, and State Children's Health Insurance Program  (SCHIP) Balanced Budget Refinement

1, 2002. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is required to make updates to these prospective payment systems annually. This CR outlines those change s for FY 2026.

source_citations.context:

source_citations.supporting_text:
If a MAC 
believes that an LTCH is either incorrectly included or excluded from the list of LTCHs that receive the 5 percent cap for the F Y 2026 applicable IPPS comparable wage index, please contact 
LTCHPPS@cms. For all other LTCHs, MACs will ensure the Special Payment Indicator field and the 
Special Wage Index field are blank
source_citations.context:
NOTE: Hospitals and/or MACs can request an alternative CCR to the statewide average CCR per the 
instructions in section 150.24 of chapter 3 of Pub. 100- 04, Medicare Claims Processing Manual.  
Additionally, for all LTCHs, use of a total CCR of 0.0 or any other alternative CCR requires approval from the CMS Central Office.  
LTCH Wage Indexes  
For FY 2026, a 5 percent cap is applied to any decrease in an LTCH’s wage index from its FY 2025 wage index. A list of LTCHs whose FY 2026 LTCH PPS wage index decreased by more than 5 percent along with their capped FY 2026 LTCH PPS wage index value can be  found on the FY 2026 MAC Implementation 
Files webpage. For these LTCHs, MACs will enter into the PSF a ‘1’ in the Special Payment Indicator field (data element 33) and the LTCH’s capped FY 2026 LTCH PPS wage index value in the Special Wage Index field (da ta element 38). For all other LTCHs, MACs will ensure the Special Payment Indicator field and the 
Special Wage Index field are blank.

source_citations.context:
The special payment provisions provided to a Medicare Dependent Small Rural Hospital (MDH) are not authorized by statute beyond FY 2025. Therefore, beginning October 1, 2025, all hospitals that previously qualified for MDH status will no longer have MDH st atus and will be paid based solely on the Federal rate. 
(We note that, our SCH policy at Subsection (§)412.92(b) allows MDHs to apply for SCH status and be paid as such under certain conditions, following the expiration of the MDH program.)   Provider Types  14 and 15 
are no longer valid beginning FY 2026, and contractors shall update the PSF accordingly to reflect the appropriate provider type with an effective date of October 1, 2025.

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The Social Security Amendments of 1983 (P.L. 98- 21) provided for the establishment of 
a Prospective Payment System (PPS) for Medicare payment of inpatient hospital services. In addition, the 
Medicare, Medicaid, and State Children's Health Insurance Program  (SCHIP) Balanced Budget Refinement 
Act of 1999 (BBRA), as amended by the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 (BIPA), required that a budget neutral, per discharge PPS for LTCHs based on Diagnosis -Related Groups (DRGs) be implemented for cost reporting periods beginning on or after October 
1, 2002. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) is required to make updates to these prospective payment systems annually. This CR outlines those change s for FY 2026.  
B. Policy: The following policy changes for FY 2026 went on display on August 1, 2025, and appear in 
the Federal Register on August 4, 2025. All items covered in this instruction are effective for hospita

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the updates to the Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) and Long-Term Care Hospital (LTCH) Prospective Payment System for Fiscal Year 2026. Key changes include updates to rates, factors, and policies, as well as modifications to the Medicare Severity Diagnosis-Related Group (MS-DRG) system. The document also details new technology add-on payments and adjustments to payment policies for replaced devices. These changes are effective for discharges on or after October 1, 2025.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the FY 2026 updates to IPPS and LTCH PPS.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new IPPS and LTCH PPS rates and factors.
Review and implement changes to MS-DRG assignments and new technology add-on payments.

source_citations.supporting_text:
Uncompensated Care Payments 
In the FY 2026 IPPS and LTCH PPS final rule, we finalized a Factor 3 for each Medicare DSH 
hospital representing its relative share of the total uncompensated care payment amount paid to 
Medicare DSH hospitals along with a total uncompensated care payment amount. We determine a hospital’s NAH 
MA payment by applying a ratio of the hospital -specific NAH Medicare Part A payments, total 
inpatient days, and MA inpatient days to the national totals of those same amoun
source_citations.context:
Medicare Advantage Nursing & Allied Health Education Payments – Rates for CY 2024  
Under 42 CFR 413.87, hospitals that operate approved nursing and allied health (NAH) education 
programs and receive Medicare reasonable cost reimbursement for these programs also receive 
additional payments if they treat Medicare Advantage (MA) enrollees. We determine a hospital’s NAH 
MA payment by applying a ratio of the hospital -specific NAH Medicare Part A payments, total 
inpatient days, and MA inpatient days to the national totals of those same amounts from cost 
reporting periods ending in the FY that’s 2 years prior to the current CY. The formula is:  
(((Hospital NAH pass -through payment / Hospital Part A i npatient days) * Hospital MA i npatient days) 
/ ((National NAH pass -through payment / National Part A i npatient days) * National MA i npatient 
days)) * Current year payment pool

MAC implementation file 1 for the FY 2026 MS -DRG weighting factor used for these discharges.  
Under this policy, we’ll apply a payment adjustment to claims that group to MS -DRG 018 and meet 1 
of these criteria : 
● Includes ICD-10-CM diagnosis code Z00.6 
● There’s an expanded access use of immunotherapy  
● The immunotherapy product isn’t purchased in the usual manner, such as obtained at no cost

product s in the usual manner but the case involves a clinical trial of a different product, we won’t 
apply the payment adjustment in calculating the payment  for the case.

source_citations.claim: The document also details new technology add-on payments and adjustments to payment policies for replaced devices
source_citations.supporting_text:
Replaced Devices Offered Without Cost or w ith a Credit  
For specified MS -DRGs, we reduce a hospital’s IPPS payment when they replace an implanted 
device without cost or with a credit equal to 50% or more of the cost of the replacement device. We 
add new MS -DRGs to the list subject to the policy for payment under the IPPS for replaced devices 
offered without cost or with credit when they’re formed from procedures previously assigned to  
MS-DRGs that were already on the list

October 1, 2025, all hospitals that previously qualified for MDH status will lose that status, and we’ll 
pay them solely on the federal rate.

certain conditions once the MDH program expires.

accordingly to reflect the appropriate provider type with an effective date of October 1, 2025.

● There’s an expanded access use of immunotherapy

source_citations.context:
age 13 of 14 MLN Matters: MM14203  Related CR 14203  
LTCH Statewide Average CCRs  
See Table 8C  for the FY 2026 Statewide average LTCH total CCRs for urban and rural LTCHs. Per 
42 CFR 412.525(a)(4)(iv)(C)  and 412.529(f)(4)(iii) , for FY 2026, we use statewide average CCRs in 
the following instances:  
● New hospitals that haven’t yet submitted their first Medicare cost report. For this purpose, we 
define a new hospital as any entity that hasn’t accepted assignment of an existing hospital’s 
provider agreement per 42 CFR 489.18.  
● LTCHs with a total CCR more than the applicable maximum CCR threshold (that is, the LTCH 
total CCR ceiling, which we  calculate at 3 standard deviations from the national geometric 
average CCR). See MAC implementation file 2 for the LTCH total CCR ceiling.  
● Any hospital for which data isn’t available to calculate a CCR.  
Note : Hospitals and MACs can request an alternative CCR to the statewide average CCR per 
instructions in the Medicare Claims

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the implementation of the Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM) 3-Day Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) Waiver, which allows hospitals to discharge patients to SNFs without the traditional 3-day hospital stay requirement. This change is facilitated by demonstration code A9, which will be associated with SNF claims. The initiative aims to enhance care coordination and reduce Medicare expenditures while maintaining or improving care quality.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing processes to incorporate demonstration code A9 for SNF claims.
Ensure compliance with new waiver requirements and update training materials for staff.

key_requirements: Waive 3-day hospital stay for SNF claims
Use demonstration code A9 for eligible claims

A. Background: Section 1115A of the Social Security Act (the Act) authorizes the Centers for Medicare 
& Medicaid Services’ (CMS) Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (Innovation Center) to test 
innovative payment and service delivery models to reduce Medicare, Medicaid, and Children’s Health 
Insurance Program (CHIP) expenditures while preserving or enhancing the quality of care furnished to 
beneficiaries. The CMS Innovation Center is using this authority to test the Transforming Episode 
Accountabilit y Model (TEAM), an episode -based payment model that aims to reduce Medicare expenditures 
while preserving or enhancing the quality of care, and to further advance care coordination across acute and chronic medical care settings.

quality of care for selected surgical procedures. These responsibilities will span from the time of surgery

beneficiary care, CMS is conditionally waiving certain Medicare payment requirements for beneficiaries in 
TEAM episodes, effective for episodes starti ng on or after January 1, 2026 (the start of TEAM Performance 
Year 1). TEAM is set to launch on January 1, 2026, and will run for five years, concluding on December 31, 2030

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM) is a mandatory, episode-based payment model by CMS aimed at reducing Medicare spending and improving care quality. It allows acute care hospitals to discharge patients to skilled nursing facilities without a 3-day hospital stay, provided certain criteria are met. The model, running from 2026 to 2030, holds hospitals accountable for the cost and quality of care for selected surgical procedures, fostering better care coordination and patient engagement.

source_citations.context:
age 5 of 6 MLN Matters: MM 14098  Related CR 14098  
Key Updates 
SNF 3 -Day Rule Waiver  
To enhance care coordination across the post -acute spectrum and support participating hospitals in 
managing patient care, we’re conditionally waiving certain Medicare payment requirements for 
patients in TEAM episodes starting for dates of service on or after January 1, 2026. Specifically, per 
regulations at 42 CFR 512.580(b) , we’re waiving the requirement for a 3- day inpatient hospital stay 
prior to a Medicare- covered SNF stay for eligible TEAM patients.  
Under standard Medicare rules, we cover  SNF services if a patient has  a qualifying inpatient hospital 
stay of at least 3 consecutive days (including the day of hospital admission but not the day of 
discharge) . Effective for episodes starting on or after January 1, 2026, until December 31, 2030 , 
patients  in a TEAM episode of care may  receive SNF or  swing bed services without meeting  
the 3-day hospital stay  requirement . Pay

SNF 3 -Day Rule Waiver  
To enhance care coordination across the post -acute spectrum and support participating hospitals in 
managing patient care, we’re conditionally waiving certain Medicare payment requirements for 
patients in TEAM episodes starting for dates of service on or after January 1, 2026. Specifically, per 
regulations at 42 CFR 512.580(b) , we’re waiving the requirement for a 3- day inpatient hospital stay 
prior to a Medicare- covered SNF stay for eligible TEAM patients.  
Under standard Medicare rules, we cover  SNF services if a patient has  a qualifying inpatient hospital 
stay of at least 3 consecutive days (including the day of hospital admission but not the day of 
discharge) . Effective for episodes starting on or after January 1, 2026, until December 31, 2030 , 
patients  in a TEAM episode of care may  receive SNF or  swing bed services without meeting  
the 3-day hospital stay  requirement . Pay

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CMS Transmittal 13395 updates the revenue codes for billing renal dialysis services for individuals with Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) starting in 2025. This change allows for home dialysis billing, which was previously restricted to in-center treatments. The transmittal rescinds a previous version to include additional reason codes and clarifies billing instructions for AKI dialysis services.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to include new revenue codes for AKI home dialysis.

key_requirements: Revise billing instructions to include revenue codes 084X and 085X for home dialysis.
Ensure compliance with updated CMS guidelines for AKI dialysis billing.

SUBJECT: Allowing Additional Revenue Codes for Payment for Renal Dialysis Services Furnished to Individuals with Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) beginning in Calendar Year (CY) 2025
 
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES : The  purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to revise the applicable 
revenue codes allowed for AKI dialysis billing in Original Medicare systems and to update billing instructions to include those revenue codes.  
 
EFFECTIVE DATE: January 1, 2025 *Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service.  
IMPLEME

source_citations.context:
A. Background: On June 29, 2015, the Trade Preferences Extension Act of 2015 was enacted in which 
section 808 amended Section 1861(s)(2)(F) of the Social Security Act (the Act) (42 U.S.C. 1395x(s)(2)(F)) by extending renal dialysis services paid under section 1881(b)(14)  of the Act to beneficiaries with Acute 
Kidney Injury (AKI) effective January 1, 2017.  Originally, payment for renal dialysis services furnished to 
beneficiaries with AKI was only allowed for in- center treatments.   However, payment for home  dialysis was 
allowed for AKI beneficiaries effective January 1, 2025.

claims.   In this CR, we clarified that these revenue codes corresponded to Continuous Ambulatory 
Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD) and Conti

source_citations.claim: This change allows for home dialysis billing, which was previously restricted to in-center treatments
source_citations.supporting_text:
When billing for CAPD or CCPD in the home setting for AKI patients, payment will be made at the daily rate based on hemodialysis -equivalent 
treatments. ESRD facilities billing for training or re -training for AKI home and self -dialysis will be required to include 
condition code 84 as well as either 73 or 87 as appropriate
source_citations.context:
ESRD facilities billing for training or re -training for AKI home and self -dialysis will be required to include 
condition code 84 as well as either 73 or 87 as appropriate. When billing for CAPD or CCPD in the home setting for AKI patients, payment will be made at the daily rate based on hemodialysis -equivalent 
treatments.   
This CR does not make any changes to the use of revenue codes 082X, 083X or 881 for AKI 
beneficiaries.   As such, any of revenue codes 082X, 083X, 084X, 085X or 0881 may be used when billing 
for AKI beneficiaries.   These codes should be billed with condition code 84, to indicate AKI, and the 
appropriate second condition code to indicate site of care of 73, 74 or 87, when relevant.

End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) facilities billing for AKI dialysis treatments will be required to include 
both condition codes 74 and 84 on home AKI dialysis claims. Policy: Payment for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) home dialysis   
When payment for renal dialysis services furnished to beneficiaries with AKI was only allowed in -center, 
CMS published CR 10574, which disallowed the use of revenue codes 084X and 085X for AKI dialysis 
claims
source_citations.context:
A. Background: On June 29, 2015, the Trade Preferences Extension Act of 2015 was enacted in which 
section 808 amended Section 1861(s)(2)(F) of the Social Security Act (the Act) (42 U.S.C. 1395x(s)(2)(F)) by extending renal dialysis services paid under section 1881(b)(14)  of the Act to beneficiaries with Acute 
Kidney Injury (AKI) effective January 1, 2017.  Originally, payment for renal dialysis services furnished to 
beneficiaries with AKI was only allowed for in- center treatments.   However, payment for home  dialysis was 
allowed for AKI beneficiaries effective January 1, 2025.   
B. Policy: Payment for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) home dialysis   
When payment for renal dialysis services furnished to beneficiaries with AKI was only allowed in -center, 
CMS published CR 10574, which disallowed the use of revenue codes 084X and 085X for AKI dialysis 
claims.   In this CR, we clarified that these revenue codes corresponded to Continuous Ambulatory 
Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD) and Conti

source_citations.context:
A. Background: On June 29, 2015, the Trade Preferences Extension Act of 2015 was enacted in which 
section 808 amended Section 1861(s)(2)(F) of the Social Security Act (the Act) (42 U.S.C. 1395x(s)(2)(F)) by extending renal dialysis services paid under section 1881(b)(14)  of the Act to beneficiaries with Acute 
Kidney Injury (AKI) effective January 1, 2017.  Originally, payment for renal dialysis services furnished to 
beneficiaries with AKI was only allowed for in- center treatments.   However, payment for home  dialysis was 
allowed for AKI beneficiaries effective January 1, 2025.   
B. Policy: Payment for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) home dialysis   
When payment for renal dialysis services furnished to beneficiaries with AKI was only allowed in -center, 
CMS published CR 10574, which disallowed the use of revenue codes 084X and 085X for AKI dialysis 
claims.   In this CR, we clarified that these revenue codes corresponded to Continuous Ambulatory 
Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD) and Conti

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to Chapter 3 and the Appendices Chapter in CMS Publication 100-15, focusing on the Medicaid Proactive Project Development process and Medicaid Medical Review for Program Integrity Purposes. These updates are technical and pertain to contractor processes, ensuring they have the latest guidance. The changes do not impact providers or beneficiaries and do not require provider education.

next_steps.action: Review and understand the updated guidance in Chapter 3 and Appendices.

SUBJECT: Updates of Chapter 3 and the Appendices Chapter in Publication (Pub.) 100 -15, Including 
Updates to the Medicaid Proactive Project Development Process  
 
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to revise various sections 
within Chapter 3 and the Appendices Chapter in Pub. 100-15. The revisions include updates to the Medicaid 
Proactive Project Development process, in addition to the Medicaid Medical Review for Program Integrity Purposes processes. Additionally, the Analytic Findings Report Sample has been added to the Appendices Chapter.   
These updates do not affect the provider and/or beneficiary populations. Rather, these updates are solely related to contractor technical processes and procedures. All updates ensure our

source_citations.claim: The document outlines updates to Chapter 3 and the Appendices Chapter in CMS Publication 100-15, focusing on the Medicaid Proactive Project Development process and Medicaid Medical Review for Program Integrity Purposes
source_citations.supporting_text:
9 - Medical Review for Program Integrity Purposes  
(Rev. 13 385; Issued: 0 8-28-25; Effective: 0 9-29-25; Implementation: 0 9-29-25) 
 Medical Review (MR) for program integrity purposes is one of the parallel strategies of the UPIC to encourage the early detection of fraud, waste, and abuse
source_citations.context:
CHAPTER 3 – Medicaid Investigations & Audits  
(Rev.  13385; Issued: 8 -28-25) 
 
 
 
 
3.2 - Proactive Project Development  
(Rev. 13 385; Issued: 0 8-28-25; Effective: 0 9-29-25; Implementation: 0 9-29-25) 
 
Through ongoing collaboration with each state, the UPIC shall discuss areas of interest and convey CMS’ priorities related to Medicaid fraud, waste, and abuse for purposes of potential investigations. As outlined in the UPIC statement of work, the UPIC shall be flexible and shall have the capability to adapt to the changing landscape of fraud, waste, and abuse in their jurisdiction. The U PIC shall keep CMS and the state informed 
as to the highest investigative priorities in such a way as to assure that CMS and the state always has a full understanding of the UPIC’s highest priorities and supports State PI efforts.  
 Once an investigative area of interest is identified, the UPIC shall access the applicable Medicaid claims data for analysis through the CMS/CPI Integrated Data R

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CMS Transmittal 13391, issued on August 27, 2025, replaces a previous transmittal to update implementation dates and add new sub-requirements for Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) edits and Informational Unsolicited Responses (IURs). The Change Request 13767 aims to enhance compliance and payment accuracy by identifying incorrect use of Place of Service (POS) code 32 when a beneficiary is in a covered Part A SNF stay. This update addresses non-compliance issues that could lead to Medicare overpayments.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing practices to ensure correct POS code usage.

key_requirements: Establish system edit for identifying incorrect POS code usage.
Implement Informational Unsolicited Response (IUR) for compliance.

source_citations.claim: The Change Request 13767 aims to enhance compliance and payment accuracy by identifying incorrect use of Place of Service (POS) code 32 when a beneficiary is in a covered Part A SNF stay
source_citations.supporting_text:
Practitioners sometimes apply the non- facility POS code 32 (indicating services were provided to a beneficiary 
in Nursing facility (NF) or during a non- covered SNF stay) when, in fact, the beneficiary was covered under 
Part A. Alternatively, POS code 32 is used for all services furnished in NFs, and for services furnished in SNFs when beneficiaries have exhausted their Part A coverage
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Medicare pays practitioners separately for physician services, distinct from payments made 
to inpatient facilities (such as Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) or hospital). Practitioners report a two -digit place -
of-service (POS) code on Medicare claim lines, r eflecting where the service was furnished. The Office of 
Inspector General’s (OIG) analysis revealed that practitioners do not always follow the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services’ (CMS) regulations and guidance when reporting the appr opriate code for where they 
rendered services. This non- compliance increases the risk of Medicare making overpayments for physician 
services provided to inpatients of SNFs or hospitals. The primary issue is the incorrect use of POS codes. Practitioners sometimes apply the non- facility POS code 32 (indicating services were provided to a beneficiary 
in Nursing facility (NF) or during a non- covered SNF stay) when, in fact, the beneficiary was covered under 
Part A. The c

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal that updates ICD-10 coding conversions and other coding updates specific to National Coverage Determinations (NCDs) for January 2026. It rescinds a previous transmittal to correct a URL error. The updates are part of a quarterly maintenance process and do not include policy-related changes. The effective date is January 1, 2026, with implementation on January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Review and update ICD-10 coding systems in line with the new transmittal.

key_requirements: Ensure ICD-10 coding systems are updated by the implementation date.
Verify that the corrected URL is used in the Part B Policy section.

Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to provide a maintenance update of ICD -10 
conversions and other coding updates specific to NCDs. Edits to ICD -10 and other coding updates specific to 
NCDs will be included in subsequent quarterly releases and individual CRs as appropriate
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to provide a maintenance update of ICD -10 
conversions and other coding updates specific to NCDs. These NCD coding changes are the result of newly 
available codes, coding revisions to NCDs released separately, or c oding feedback received. Previous NCD 
coding changes appear in ICD -10 quarterly updates that can be found at: 
https://www.cms.gov/medicare/coverage/determination -process/basics/icd -10 
along with other CRs implementing new policy NCDs. Edits to ICD -10 and other coding updates specific to 
NCDs will be included in subsequent quarterly releases and individual CRs as appropriate. No policy- related 
changes are included with the ICD -10 quarter ly updates. Any policy- related changes to NCDs continue to be 
implemented via the current, longstanding NCD process.  
B. Policy: Edits to ICD -10, and other coding updates specific to NCDs, will be included in subsequent 
quarterly releases as needed. No policy- relate

source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to provide a maintenance update of ICD -10 
conversions and other coding updates specific to NCDs. Previous NCD 
coding changes appear in ICD -10 quarterly updates that can be found at: 
https://www
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to provide a maintenance update of ICD -10 
conversions and other coding updates specific to NCDs. These NCD coding changes are the result of newly 
available codes, coding revisions to NCDs released separately, or c oding feedback received. Previous NCD 
coding changes appear in ICD -10 quarterly updates that can be found at: 
https://www.cms.gov/medicare/coverage/determination -process/basics/icd -10 
along with other CRs implementing new policy NCDs. Edits to ICD -10 and other coding updates specific to 
NCDs will be included in subsequent quarterly releases and individual CRs as appropriate. No policy- related 
changes are included with the ICD -10 quarter ly updates. Any policy- related changes to NCDs continue to be 
implemented via the current, longstanding NCD process.  
B. Policy: Edits to ICD -10, and other coding updates specific to NCDs, will be included in subsequent 
quarterly releases as needed. No policy- relate

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the National Coverage Determinations (NCDs) related to ICD-10 coding revisions effective January 1, 2026. It includes changes to specific NCDs such as mammograms, PET scans for oncologic conditions, and treatments for facial lipodystrophy syndrome. The document emphasizes the need for billing staff to be aware of these updates, although no substantive changes were made other than updating release dates and transmittal numbers.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the updated NCDs and ICD-10 codes.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new ICD-10 codes.
Review NCD spreadsheets for CR 14194.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a transmittal from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically regarding the compensation of owners. It clarifies the application of inflation factors on a calendar year basis, using data from the Employment Cost Index for Professional and Related Services. The transmittal adds the inflation factor for CY 2024 and removes the factor for CY 2014, ensuring compensation ranges are updated accordingly.

next_steps.action: Review and update compensation policies to align with the new CY 2024 inflation factor.

key_requirements: Apply the CY 2024 inflation factor to compensation ranges.
Remove the CY 2014 inflation factor from calculations.

--Where a trust operates an institution or has an interest in the corporation or 
partnership operating the facility, the compensation of an employee who is the settlor or grantor

source_citations.context:
902.6 Trusts .--Where a trust operates an institution or has an interest in the corporation or 
partnership operating the facility, the compensation of an employee who is the settlor or grantor 
of the trust, a trustee, or a beneficiary of the trust, is subject to the test of reasonableness. 
 
902.7 Compensation for Persons Related to Owner .--The actual compensation to an immediate 
relative of an owner (as described in §902.5) is subject to the test of reasonableness.  No cost may be imputed for the value of these services.  
 
902.8 Proprietary Provider.-- A proprietary provider is a provider organized and operated with 
the expectation of earning a profit for the owners (as distinguished from a provider organized and operated on a nonprofit basis).

Where only a portion of the total beds of an institution are 
certified, the provider should be classified by the total beds available since the compensation paid administrators is based on services rendered to the entire facility. In general, the determination as to the reasonableness of a person's compensation is made by comparing it with the compensation paid to other individuals in similar circumstances
source_citations.context:
In general, the determination as to the reasonableness of a person's compensation is made by comparing it with the compensation paid to other individuals in similar circumstances. To obtain uniformity in application of the principle, the contractor (1)  identifies compensation paid to 
individuals other than owners by comparable institutions in the same geographical area, and (2) applies a set of criteria based on the qualifications and responsibilities of the owner to determine his placement within the range.  
 In establishing the ranges, abnormally low amounts of compensation sometimes received by employees of religiously sponsored providers may be ignored since circumstances led to the establishment of their rate of pay which are not applicable to other persons. primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal updating the Provider Reimbursement Manual, specifically regarding the reasonable cost of therapy and other services furnished by outside suppliers. It clarifies the application of inflation factors for Critical Access Hospitals (CAHs) and CAHs with swing beds, which are not paid under a prospective payment system. The transmittal updates Exhibit C-3 with inflation factors for 2024, based on the Composite Therapy Index from IHS Global Insight, Inc., and includes Federal Register citations.

next_steps.action: Review and implement updated inflation factors for cost reporting periods starting in 2024.
next_steps.timeline: Before the start of the 2024 cost reporting period

key_requirements: Apply updated inflation factors for CAHs and CAHs with swing beds.
Ensure compliance with salary equivalency guidelines.

employed by providers in the area for the type of service furnished. These expenses include office space, telephone, bookkeeping, billing and accounting fees, an answering service or a secretarial 
service, and professional costs, a
source_citations.context:
1402.1  Prevailing Salary .--The cost of therapy services furnished by outside suppliers is 
evaluated in terms of the actual cost incurred by the provider for the services in comparison with the prevailing hourly salary rates paid to full -time therapists or other health -related specialists 
employed by providers in the area for the type of service furnished.  The prevailing salary is the hourly salary rate based on the 75th percentile of the range of salaries, by type of therapy, paid by 
providers in the geographical area to therapists or other health- related specialists working full time 
in an employment relationship.  These rates are based on salary data compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics  (BLS) in their triennial surveys along with data from several other sources of 
hospital and nursing home data.  The rates will be updated for intervening years through use of a rehabilitation therapist price index.  
 
1402.2  Fringe Benefit and Expense Factor .--The fringe benefit

This additional allowance equals the depreciation on equipment and cost of supplies and is based on both the reasonable direct and indirect costs of the equipment and supplies, which generally may not exceed the lower of the actual cost incurred by the outside supplier or the amount the provider would have incurred directly if it has purchased these items.  The cost of these items is also subject to the Medicare program's prudent buyer cost determinations.  Direct costs are those costs actually attributable  to the items themselves whereas indirect costs are those incurred in 
purchasing, shipping and storage of the equipment and supplies. primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a change in the frequency of No-Pay Medicare Summary Notice (MSN) mailings from every 120 days to every 180 days, effective January 1, 2026. This change is intended to conserve funding and will affect all no-pay batch MSNs, including large print and alternate formats, except electronic MSNs. Contractors are required to update the 'Claims Processed Between' section to reflect the new 180-day span.

next_steps.action: Update mailing systems to reflect new 180-day cycle for no-pay MSNs

key_requirements: Contractors shall change the frequency of MSN mailings from every 120 days to every 180 days.
Contractors shall update the 'Claims Processed Between' section on page 1 of all no-pay batch MSNs to show a span of 180 days.

10 - General  Medicare  Summary Notices  (MSN)  Requirements  
(Rev. 13380 ; Issued: 08 -21-25; Effective: 01 -01-26; Implementation: 01- 05-26) 
 
Effective July 1, 2002, the MSN  is used by all A/B  MACs  (A), (B), (HHH),  and DME  MACs.  
The MSN is the primary vehicle by which beneficiaries are notified of decisions on their claims 
for Medicare benefits.  The A/B MAC (A), (B), (HHH), or DME MAC mails a single MSN at 
the end of the month to each beneficiary for whom claim was processed during the month to inform  the beneficiary  of the disposition of  all claims.  All MACs  shall  issue  No-Pay MSNs  on a 
180-day mailing cycle.  MSNs with checks to the beneficiary will continue to be mailed out as 
processed.  To ensure that all messages are uniform throughout the Medicare program, A/B 
MACs (A), (B), (HHH), a

For Medicare Administrative  Contractors  (MACs):  
 
The Medicare Administrative  Contractor  is hereby  advised  that this constitutes  technical  direction  as defined 
in your contract. CMS does not construe this as a change to the MAC Statement of Work. The contractor is 
not obligated to incur costs in excess of the amounts allotted in your contract unless and until specifically authorized by the Contracting Officer. If the contractor considers anything provided, as described above, to be outside the current scope of work, the contractor shall withhold performance on the part(s) in question and immediately notify the Contracting Officer, in writing or by e -mail, and request formal directions 
regarding continued performance requirements.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal reminding Medicare contractors about the quarterly update to the HCPCS file for January 2026. This update includes existing, new, revised, and discontinued HCPCS codes. Contractors are required to download the updated file from the Cloud and implement it into their systems. The effective date for these changes is January 1, 2026, with an implementation date of January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Download the updated HCPCS file from the Cloud

key_requirements: Contractors shall download the HCPCS data from the Cloud service and implement it into their testing and production regions.
Data Centers shall work with Part B MACs to implement the data into their systems upon email notification from CMS.

source_citations.context:
CMS Manual System  Department of Health & 
Human Services (DHHS)  
Pub 100 -04 Medicare Claims Processing  Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS)  
Transmittal 13377  Date: August 21, 2025  
 Change Request 14183  
 
SUBJECT: January 2026 Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) Quarterly Update 
Reminder  
 
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES: The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to remind the Medicare 
contractors that the quarterly update to the HCPCS file is available for them to download. The complete 
HCPCS file is updated and released quarterly to the Medicare contractors. The file con tains existing, new, 
revised and discontinued HCPCS codes for the January 2026 quarter. Contractors shall retrieve the data via 
the Cloud when instructed in a separate communication from CMS. The recurring update notification 
applies to Publication 100- 04, Chapter 23, Section 20. 
EFFECTIVE DATE: January 1, 2026 
*Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service

HCPCS file is available for them to download. The complete HCPCS file is updated and released quarterly

source_citations.context:
A. Background: This change request reminds the Medicare contractors that the quarterly update to the 
HCPCS file is available for them to download. The complete HCPCS file is updated and released quarterly 
to the Medicare contractors. The file contains existing, new, revi sed and discontinued HCPCS codes for the 
January 2026 quarter. Contractors must download the file in December 2025. The recurring update notification applies to chapter 23, section 20 of the Medicare Claims Processing Manual. 
B. Policy: There is no new policy associated with this change request.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a quarterly update to the Home Health (HH) Grouper software, effective January 1, 2026. This update reflects changes in the calendar year 2026 HH final rule and incorporates the latest ICD-10-CM code set updates. The update is mandatory for processing HH claims with specific types of bills from January 1, 2026. CMS will provide national provider education through the Medicare Learning Network.

next_steps.action: Implement HH Grouper version 07.0.26 for processing relevant claims

key_requirements: Contractors must process HH claims with the updated Grouper software from January 1, 2026.
CMS will release provider education content through the MLN Connects newsletter.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines a quarterly update to the Home Health (HH) Grouper software, effective January 1, 2026
source_citations.supporting_text:
gov/Medicare/Medicare -Fee-for-Service-
Payment/HomeHealthPPS/CaseMixGrouperSoftware. Background: The HH Grouper assigns each claim to a Home Health Resource Group (HHRG) based 
on the reported claim and patient assessment information, including diagnosis codes
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The HH Grouper assigns each claim to a Home Health Resource Group (HHRG) based 
on the reported claim and patient assessment information, including diagnosis codes. The International 
Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD -10-CM)  code set is updated 
annually, effective October 1. Each year, the Grouper contractor, Solventum, develops a new HH Grouper 
software package to reflect these updates.  
Additional HH Grouper updates may be needed in quarterly releases when HH rulemaking changes the case-
mix grouping policies or if additional ICD -10-CM diagnosis codes are created throughout the year. CR 
14067 provided the October 2025 update to reflect the October ICD -10-CM code set updates. This CR 
provides the January 2026 changes to reflect the policies of the calendar year 2026 HH final rule. 
The HH Grouper and related documentation for each update is located on the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS) web page at https://w

mix grouping policies or if additional ICD -10-CM diagnosis codes are created throughout the year. This CR 
provides the January 2026 changes to reflect the policies of the calendar year 2026 HH final rule

A. Background: The HH Grouper assigns each claim to a Home Health Resource Group (HHRG) based 
on the reported claim and patient assessment information, including diagnosis codes. The International 
Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD -10-CM)  code set is updated 
annually, effective October 1. Each year, the Grouper contractor, Solventum, develops a new HH Grouper 
software package to reflect these updates.  
Additional HH Grouper updates may be needed in quarterly releases when HH rulemaking changes the case-
mix grouping policies or if additional ICD -10-CM diagnosis codes are created throughout the year. CR 
14067 provided the October 2025 update to reflect the October ICD -10-CM code set updates. This CR 
provides the January 2026 changes to reflect the policies of the calendar year 2026 HH final rule.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the annual update to the Clotting Factor Furnishing Fee for 2026, as mandated by the Medicare Modernization Act. The update specifies that a furnishing fee of $0.265 per unit will be added to the payment for clotting factors when no payment limit is published on the ASP or NOC drug pricing files. This change is effective from January 1, 2026, with implementation starting January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing systems are updated to include the new furnishing fee for clotting factors.

key_requirements: Contractors shall make separate payment for the clotting factor furnishing fee when the payment limit is not included on the ASP or NOC files.
CMS will release national provider education content through the MLN Connects newsletter.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines the annual update to the Clotting Factor Furnishing Fee for 2026, as mandated by the Medicare Modernization Act
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The purpose of this annually recurring Change Request (CR) is to announce the update 
to the Clotting Factor Furnishing Fee. The Medicare Modernization Act section 303(e)(1) added section 
1842(o)(5)(C) of the Social Security Act which requires that a furnishing fee will be paid for items and services associated with clotting factor
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this annually recurring Change Request (CR) is to announce the update 
to the Clotting Factor Furnishing Fee. The Medicare Modernization Act section 303(e)(1) added section 
1842(o)(5)(C) of the Social Security Act which requires that a furnishing fee will be paid for items and services associated with clotting factor.  
B. Policy: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) includes the clotting factor furnishing 
fee in the published national payment limits for clotting factor billing codes. When the national payment limit for a clotting factor is not included on the Average Sale s Price (ASP) Medicare Part B Drug Pricing 
File or the Not Otherwise Classified (NOC) Pricing File, the contractor must make payment for the clotting factor as well as make payment for the furnishing fee.  
For 2026, the clotting factor furnishing fee of $0.265 per unit is included in the published payment limit for clotting factors and shall be added to the payment for

source_citations.claim: The update specifies that a furnishing fee of $0
source_citations.supporting_text:
The clotting factor furnishing fee is updated each calendar year based on the percentage increase in the consumer price index (CPI) for medical care for the 12- month period ending with June of the previous year. source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this annually recurring Change Request (CR) is to announce the update 
to the Clotting Factor Furnishing Fee. The Medicare Modernization Act section 303(e)(1) added section 
1842(o)(5)(C) of the Social Security Act which requires that a furnishing fee will be paid for items and services associated with clotting factor.  
B. Policy: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) includes the clotting factor furnishing 
fee in the published national payment limits for clotting factor billing codes. When the national payment limit for a clotting factor is not included on the Average Sale s Price (ASP) Medicare Part B Drug Pricing 
File or the Not Otherwise Classified (NOC) Pricing File, the contractor must make payment for the clotting factor as well as make payment for the furnishing fee.

These updates are part of a maintenance process and do not include policy-related changes. The updates are based on newly available codes, coding revisions, and feedback, and will be included in subsequent quarterly releases.

quarterly releases as needed. No policy- relate

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the January 2026 update to ICD-10 and other coding revisions for National Coverage Determinations (NCDs). It highlights that no substantive changes were made other than updating the CR release date and transmittal numbers. Key updates include changes to specific NCDs such as cardiac output monitoring, next-generation sequencing, and colorectal cancer screening tests. Providers are advised to update their billing practices accordingly.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems with new ICD-10 codes effective January 1, 2026.

key_requirements: Ensure billing staff are aware of new and deleted ICD-10 codes.
Review NCD spreadsheets for CR 14197 for detailed coding changes.

Affected Providers 
● Physicians 
● Suppliers

new or deleted ICD -10 diagnosis codes effective January 1, 2026. 
Background 
CR 14197 provides a maintenance update of ICD -10 conversions and other NCD -specific coding 
updates. These NCD coding changes result from newly available codes, separately released NCD coding revisions, or coding feedback received by CMS.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a change in Medicare coverage policy, effective June 9, 2025, allowing for the reimbursement of Respiratory Assist Devices (RADs) and Home Mechanical Ventilators (HMVs) for home use in treating Chronic Respiratory Failure (CRF) due to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). This change is based on sufficient evidence supporting the use of these devices for high-intensity noninvasive ventilation. The implementation date for this policy is October 22, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate new reimbursement policy for RADs and HMVs.
Ensure clinical staff are informed about the new coverage policy and patient eligibility criteria.
Verify compliance with new CMS guidelines and update internal policies accordingly.

key_requirements: Contractors shall pay claims for RADs and HMVs for home use in treating CRF due to COPD.
Devices must meet specific patient criteria for coverage.

source_citations.claim: This change is based on sufficient evidence supporting the use of these devices for high-intensity noninvasive ventilation
source_citations.supporting_text:
Policy: Effective for services performed on or after June 9, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS) has determined that the evidence is sufficient to cover RADs, with or without a backup rate feature and HMVs, in the home, to deliver high intensity Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV) as treatment for patients with CRF consequent to COPD as long as certain patient criteria is met. Background: RADs with bi -level capability, with or without a backup rate feature, are devices that 
use
source_citations.context:
A. Background: RADs with bi -level capability, with or without a backup rate feature, are devices that 
use a non- invasive interface (mask) to deliver a higher level of airway pressure when the patient inhales than 
when the patient exhales. A backup rate feature enables the device to provide a prespecified respiratory rate 
if the patient’s spontaneous respiratory rate decreases below a set number. 
A  HMV delivers a predetermined amount of air with each breath and typically has more monitoring, safety, 
alarm and backup power features (batteries) than a RAD.  
B. Policy: Effective for services performed on or after June 9, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS) has determined that the evidence is sufficient to cover RADs, with or without a backup rate feature and HMVs, in the home, to deliver high intensity Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV) as treatment for patients with CRF consequent to COPD as long as certain patient criteria is met.

source_citations.context:
A. Background: RADs with bi -level capability, with or without a backup rate feature, are devices that 
use a non- invasive interface (mask) to deliver a higher level of airway pressure when the patient inhales than 
when the patient exhales. A backup rate feature enables the device to provide a prespecified respiratory rate 
if the patient’s spontaneous respiratory rate decreases below a set number. 
A  HMV delivers a predetermined amount of air with each breath and typically has more monitoring, safety, 
alarm and backup power features (batteries) than a RAD.  
B. Policy: Effective for services performed on or after June 9, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS) has determined that the evidence is sufficient to cover RADs, with or without a backup rate feature and HMVs, in the home, to deliver high intensity Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV) as treatment for patients with CRF consequent to COPD as long as certain patient criteria is met.

Pub 100 -03 Medicare National Coverage

Medicaid Services (CMS)  
Transmittal  13374  Date: August 21, 2025  
 Change Request 14177  
 
SUBJECT: Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) in the Home for the Treatment of 
Chronic Respiratory Failure (CRF) Consequent to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  
I. SUMMARY OF CHANGES:  The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to inform contractors that effective June 9, 2025, contractors shall pay claims for Respiratory Assist Device (RADs) with or without a backup rate feature and Home Mechanical Ventilators (HMVs), in the home, as tr eatment for patients with 
Chronic Respiratory Failure (CRF) consequent to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). 
EFFECTIVE DATE: June 9, 2025 
*Unless otherwise specified, the effective date is the date of service.  
IMPLEMENTATION DATE: October 22, 2025 
 
Disclaimer for manual

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CMS transmittal R13374CP outlines a change request effective June 9, 2025, allowing contractors to pay claims for Respiratory Assist Devices (RADs) and Home Mechanical Ventilators (HMVs) for home treatment of Chronic Respiratory Failure due to COPD. This change supports the use of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation in the home setting. The implementation date for these changes is October 22, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate new HCPCS codes E0470 and E0471 for RADs and HMVs.

key_requirements: Contractors shall pay claims for RADs and HMVs for home treatment of CRF due to COPD.
Ensure compliance with patient criteria for coverage of RADs and HMVs.

source_citations.claim: Ensure compliance with patient criteria for coverage of RADs and HMVs.
source_citations.supporting_text:
Policy: Effective for services performed on or after June 9, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS) has determined that the evidence is sufficient to cover RADs, with or without a 
backup rate feature and HMVs, in the home, to deliver high intensi ty Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV) as 
treatment for patients with CRF consequent to COPD as long as certain patient criteria is met. Background: RADs with bi -level capability, with or without a backup rate feature, are devices that
source_citations.context:
A. Background: RADs with bi -level capability, with or without a backup rate feature, are devices that 
use a non- invasive interface (mask) to deliver a higher level of airway pressure when the patient inhales than 
when the patient exhales. A backup rate feature enables th e device to provide a prespecified respiratory rate 
if the patient’s spontaneous respiratory rate decreases below a set number.  
A HMV delivers a predetermined amount of air with each breath and typically has more monitoring, safety, 
alarm and backup power features (batteries) than a RAD.  B. Policy: Effective for services performed on or after June 9, 2025, the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services (CMS) has determined that the evidence is sufficient to cover RADs, with or without a 
backup rate feature and HMVs, in the home, to deliver high intensi ty Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV) as 
treatment for patients with CRF consequent to COPD as long as certain patient criteria is met.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the implementation of the Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM) 3-Day Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) Waiver. This waiver allows hospitals to discharge patients to SNFs without the traditional 3-day hospital stay requirement, applicable to certain outpatient surgeries or inpatient stays. The change is facilitated by associating demonstration code A9 with SNF claims, effective January 1, 2026, with implementation starting January 5, 2026.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing processes to incorporate demonstration code A9 for SNF claims.
Ensure compliance with new waiver requirements and update policy documentation.

key_requirements: Incorporate demonstration code A9 in SNF claims.
Remove hard coded editing for termination dates in the model.

source_citations.context:
A. Background: Section 1115A of the Social Security Act (the Act) authorizes the Centers for Medicare & 
Medicaid Services’ (CMS) Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (Innovation Center) to test innovative 
payment and service delivery models to reduce Medicare, Med icaid, and Children’s Health Insurance Program 
(CHIP) expenditures while preserving or enhancing the quality of care furnished to beneficiaries. The CMS 
Innovation Center is using this authority to test the Transforming Episode Accountabilit y Model (TEAM), an 
episode -based payment model that aims to reduce Medicare expenditures while preserving or enhancing the 
quality of care, and to further advance care coordination across acute and chronic medical care settings. 
Under TEAM, participating acute care hospitals (TEAM participants) will be responsible for the cost and 
quality of care for selected surgical procedures. These responsibilities will span from the time of surgery 
through the first 30 days after a

source_citations.claim: This waiver allows hospitals to discharge patients to SNFs without the traditional 3-day hospital stay requirement, applicable to certain outpatient surgeries or inpatient stays
source_citations.supporting_text:
Specifically, CMS is waiving the requirement for a 3 -day inpatient hospital stay prior to a Medicare -
covered SNF stay for eligible beneficiaries if certain conditions are met, as outlin ed in regulations at 42 CFR 
512. • The beneficiary must meet the following eligibility criteria for TEAM upon admission for a 
hospital inpatient stay or hospital outpatient procedure:  
o Are enrolled in Medicare Parts A and B  
o Are not eligible for Medicare on the basis of having end- stage renal disease

Year 1)

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM) is a mandatory, episode-based payment model by CMS aimed at reducing Medicare spending and improving care quality. It allows acute care hospitals to discharge patients to skilled nursing facilities without a 3-day hospital stay, provided certain criteria are met. The model will run from January 1, 2026, to December 31, 2030, and includes three participation tracks with varying financial risks.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about TEAM participation and payment details.

key_requirements: Hospitals must discharge patients to SNFs within 30 days of hospital discharge.
SNF claims must include the TEAM demonstration code A9.

source_citations.context:
age 5 of 6 MLN Matters: MM 14098  Related CR 14098  
Key Updates 
SNF 3 -Day Rule Waiver  
To enhance care coordination across the post -acute spectrum and support participating hospitals in 
managing patient care, we’re conditionally waiving certain Medicare payment requirements for 
patients in TEAM episodes starting for dates of service on or after January 1, 2026. Specifically, per 
regulations at 42 CFR 512.580(b) , we’re waiving the requirement for a 3- day inpatient hospital stay 
prior to a Medicare- covered SNF stay for eligible TEAM patients.  
Under standard Medicare rules, we cover  SNF services if a patient has  a qualifying inpatient hospital 
stay of at least 3 consecutive days (including the day of hospital admission but not the day of 
discharge) . Effective for episodes starting on or after January 1, 2026, until December 31, 2030 ,

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a new National Coverage Determination (NCD) for Transcatheter Edge-to-Edge Repair (T-TEER) for Tricuspid Valve Regurgitation, effective July 2, 2025. This procedure is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) and requires contractors to process claims accordingly. The implementation date for these changes is January 5, 2026, and CMS will provide educational content to providers through the Medicare Learning Network.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to accommodate new T-TEER coverage requirements
Educate clinical staff on T-TEER procedure and coverage criteria
Ensure compliance with CED criteria for T-TEER

key_requirements: Contractors shall cover T-TEER for symptomatic tricuspid regurgitation under CED.
Refer to NCD Manual, Chapter 1, Section 20.38 for criteria.

(NCD) manual, Chapter 1, Section 20.38

source_citations.claim: This procedure is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) and requires contractors to process claims accordingly
source_citations.supporting_text:
Nationally Covered Indications  
 The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) covers tricuspid transcatheter edge -to-edge repair 
(T-TEER) for the treatment of symptomatic tricuspid regurgitation (TR) under Coverage with Evidence 
Development (CED) according to the provisions  below:  
 Coverage Criteria:  
 T-TEER is covered when furnished according to a Food and Drug Administration (FDA) market -authorized 
indication and all the following conditions are met:. Section A: For Medicare A
source_citations.context:
Section A: For Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs):  
The Medicare Administrative Contractor is hereby advised that this constitutes technical direction as defined in your contract. CMS does not construe this as a change to the MAC Statement of Work. The contractor is not obligated to incur costs in excess of the amounts allotted in your contract unless and until specifically authorized by the Contracting Officer. If the contractor considers anything provided, as described above, to be outside the current scope of work, the contractor shall withhold performance on the part(s) in question and immediately notify the Contracting Officer, in writing or by e- mail, and request formal directions 
regarding continued performance requirements.  ATTACHMENTS: 0  
 
   
 
     
 
    
 
Medicare National Coverage Determinations Manual  
Chapter 1  - Coverage Determinations  
 
Table of Contents  
(Rev. 13366; Issued: 08-14-25) 
  
20.38 - Transcatheter Edge -to-Edge Repair for Tricuspid V

source_citations.claim: This procedure is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) and requires contractors to process claims accordingly
source_citations.supporting_text: of CMS’ Coverage with Evidence Development Guidance Document, published August 7, 2024. gov/medicare -coverage- database/view/medicare -coverage -document
source_citations.context:
The T -TEER items and services are furnished in the context of a CMS- approved CED study. CMS- approved 
CED study protocols must: include only those patients who meet the criteria in section B.1; furnish items 
and services only through practitioners who meet the criteria in section B.2; and include all of the 
following:  
 a)   Primary outcomes of all -cause mortality, hospitalizations, or a composite of these, through a minimum 
of 24 months. For composite outcome measures, physiologic, patient -reported, and other relevant health 
outcomes should be co -directional (i.e., all outcomes comprising the composite outcome should demonstrate 
movement in the same direction). Each component of a composite outcome must be individually reported.  b)  An active comparator.  c)  A care management plan that includes the experience and role of each member of the heart team described in section B.2.  
 d) Design sufficient for subgroup analyses by:  
• Practitioner and facility level variable

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the national coverage determination for Transcatheter Edge-to-Edge Repair (T-TEER) for tricuspid valve regurgitation, effective July 2, 2025. It specifies that T-TEER is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) criteria and provides detailed claims processing requirements. The document also highlights the necessity for T-TEER to be part of a CMS-approved study and provides specific billing codes and conditions for both professional and institutional claims.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the new T-TEER coverage and claims processing requirements.

key_requirements: T-TEER must be part of a CMS-approved study.
Claims must include specific ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes and clinical trial identifiers.

source_citations.claim: The document also highlights the necessity for T-TEER to be part of a CMS-approved study and provides specific billing codes and conditions for both professional and institutional claims
source_citations.supporting_text:
Professional Claims  
We cover claims for T- TEER in a clinical research study when billed with:  
● CPT codes 0569T and  0570T  
● The appropriate ICD -10-CM principal diagnosis code and  Z00. 6 as other diagnosis  code  
● The 8- digit clinical trial identifier number  
● Modifier Q0 — Investigational clinical service provided in a clinical research study that’s in an 
approved clinical research study  
Institutional Claims

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a new coverage policy for Transcatheter Edge-to-Edge Repair for Tricuspid Valve Regurgitation (T-TEER) under Medicare, effective July 2, 2025. This procedure is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) and includes specific billing and coding requirements. The implementation date for these changes is January 5, 2026, and contractors are required to process claims according to the outlined criteria.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate new T-TEER coding and billing requirements.

key_requirements: Contractors shall allow claims for T-TEER under CED according to the criteria outlined in the NCD Manual.
Contractors shall process T-TEER claims with specific ICD-10-PCS and ICD-10-CM codes and billing criteria.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the national coverage determination for Transcatheter Edge-to-Edge Repair (T-TEER) for tricuspid valve regurgitation, effective July 2, 2025. It specifies that T-TEER is covered under Coverage with Evidence Development (CED) for symptomatic tricuspid regurgitation. The document provides detailed billing and claims processing requirements, including specific procedure and diagnosis codes. It also highlights the need for clinical trial identifiers and appropriate modifiers for claims processing.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are trained on new T-TEER coverage and claims processing requirements.

key_requirements: Use of specific ICD-10-PCS and CPT codes for T-TEER claims.
Inclusion of clinical trial identifiers and appropriate modifiers in claims.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Medicare Part B Preventive Vaccine Administration file, including the National Fee Schedule for Vaccine Administration. It covers the administration rates for preventive vaccines, COVID-19, and monoclonal antibody products. The document specifies that Medicare will continue to cover COVID-19 monoclonal antibody products under the Part B preventive vaccine benefit, even after the EUA declaration ends, provided they have market authorization.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to incorporate new vaccine administration rates.

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new vaccine administration rates.
Ensure compliance with updated Medicare Part B preventive vaccine coverage.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines updates to the Medicare Part B Preventive Vaccine Administration file, including the National Fee Schedule for Vaccine Administration
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The “National Fee Schedule for Vaccine Administration (VAXA)” previously 
known as the Medicare Part B Vaccine Administration file will now serve as a comprehensive source 
for the administration rates of preventive vaccines, COVID -19, and monoclonal antibod y products. Under section 1861(s)(10) of the Act, Medicare Part B covers both the vaccine and its administration for the 
specified preventive vaccines —the influenza, pneumococcal, and Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) vaccines
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The “National Fee Schedule for Vaccine Administration (VAXA)” previously 
known as the Medicare Part B Vaccine Administration file will now serve as a comprehensive source 
for the administration rates of preventive vaccines, COVID -19, and monoclonal antibod y products. 
This file will be updated with pricing data as needed in the future.  
  
Under section 1861(s)(10) of the Act, Medicare Part B covers both the vaccine and its administration for the 
specified preventive vaccines —the influenza, pneumococcal, and Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) vaccines. Under 
sections 1833(a)(1)(B) and 1833(b)(1) of the Act, respectively, there is no applicable beneficiary coinsurance, and the annual Part B deductible does not apply for these vaccinations. Section 1861(s)(10)(A) of the Act, as amended by section 3713 of the Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) (Pub. L. 116– 136) includes the COVID–19 vaccine and its administration in the same subpa

prophylaxis (PrEP) of COVID- 19 under the Part B preventive vacci

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The “National Fee Schedule for Vaccine Administration (VAXA)” previously 
known as the Medicare Part B Vaccine Administration file will now serve as a comprehensive source 
for the administration rates of preventive vaccines, COVID -19, and monoclonal antibod y products. 
This file will be updated with pricing data as needed in the future.  
  
Under section 1861(s)(10) of the Act, Medicare Part B covers both the vaccine and its administration for the 
specified preventive vaccines —the influenza, pneumococcal, and Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) vaccines. Under 
sections 1833(a)(1)(B) and 1833(b)(1) of the Act, respectively, there is no applicable beneficiary coinsurance, and the annual Part B deductible does not apply for these vaccinations. Section 1861(s)(10)(A) of the Act, as amended by section 3713 of the Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) (Pub. L. 116– 136) includes the COVID–19 vaccine and its administration in the same subpa

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the October 2025 update to the National Fee Schedule for Vaccine Administration, detailing new coding updates for AVTOZMA® and other newly FDA-approved products. It specifies the coverage and payment policies for COVID-19 monoclonal antibody products under Medicare Part B. The update includes the establishment of new HCPCS Level II codes for AVTOZMA® and a Not Otherwise Classified code for monoclonal antibodies used in COVID-19 treatment.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems with new HCPCS Level II codes for AVTOZMA® and other monoclonal antibody products.

key_requirements: Ensure billing staff are aware of new coding updates for AVTOZMA® and other products.
Align billing practices with updated Medicare payment policies.

source_citations.context:
We established HCPCS Level II code Q0237 to describe AVTOZMA® for post -exposure prophylaxis 
or treat ing COVID -19 and associated administrative codes  effective January 24, 2025. HCPCS Level 
II codes Q0237, M0237, and M0238 ( see descriptors below) have the same effective date as FDA 
approval to align with appropriate Medicare payment policies.  
● Q0237: Injection, tocilizumab -anoh, for hospitalized adult patients with COVID -19 who are 
receiving systemic corticosteroids and require supplemental oxygen, non- invasive or invasive 
mechanical ventilation, or e xtracorporeal membrane oxygenation ( ECMO ) only, 1 mg  
● M0237: Intravenous infusion, tocilizumab- anoh, for hospitalized adult patients with COVID -19 who 
are receiving systemic corticosteroids and require supplemental oxygen, non- invasive or invasive 
mechanical ventilation, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation ( ECMO ) only, includes infusion 
and post administration monitoring, first dose
