primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a Change Request (CR) by CMS to clarify documentation requirements for claims related to refills of essential accessories for beneficiary-owned CPAPs, RADs, and CGMs. It updates terminology from 'replacement' to 'refill' to align with §42 C.F.R. 410.38(d)(4). The effective date for these changes is January 1, 2024, with implementation set for September 16, 2025. The CR also specifies that contractors must conduct medical reviews according to the revised manual instructions.

next_steps.action: Review and update internal documentation processes to align with new CMS requirements for refills.

key_requirements: Contractors shall conduct medical review in accordance with revised language in Publication 100-08, Chapter 5, Section 5.10.2.
Terminology change from 'replacement' to 'refill' for consistency with §42 C.F.R. 410.38(d)(4).

In addition, it changes the terminology "replacement" and instead uses "refill(s)". Background: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services recently codified the

source_citations.context:
A. Background: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services recently codified the 
documentation that would be anticipated to support payment for refills at §42 C.F.R. 410.38, durable medical equipment, prosthetics, orthotics and supplies: Scope and conditions, as detaile d in paragraph (d)(4). This CR removes parts of the prior manual text, and instead, 
defers to that regulatory text. In addition, it changes the terminology "replacement" and instead uses "refill(s)".  
B. Policy: §42 C.F.R. 410.38

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a quarterly maintenance update for ICD-10 coding conversions and other coding updates specific to National Coverage Determinations (NCDs), effective January 1, 2026. It clarifies that these updates do not include policy-related changes, which continue to be implemented through the existing NCD process. The updates are a result of newly available codes, coding revisions, or feedback received, and are intended to ensure accurate coding without altering the original intent of the NCDs.

next_steps.action: Review and integrate the updated ICD-10 codes into billing and compliance systems.

key_requirements: Ensure all billing and coding staff are trained on the new ICD-10 updates.
Verify that the updated codes are correctly implemented in the billing software.

conversions and other coding updates specific to NCDs. These NCD coding changes are the result of newly 
available codes, coding revisions to NCDs released separately, or coding feedback received. Previous NCD coding changes appear in ICD-10 quarterly updates that can be found at: https://www.cms.gov/medicare/coverage/determination -process/basics/icd -10 
along with other CRs implementing new policy NCDs. Edits to ICD-10 and other coding updates specific to NCDs will be included in subsequent quarterly releases and individual CRs as appropriate. No policy- related 
changes are included with the ICD-10 quarterly updates. Any policy-related changes to NCDs continue to be implemented via the current, longstanding NCD process.

quarterly releases as needed. No policy-related changes are

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the National Coverage Determinations (NCDs) related to ICD-10 coding revisions effective January 1, 2026. It includes changes to specific NCDs such as mammograms, PET scans for oncologic conditions, and adult liver transplantation. The document emphasizes that these updates are maintenance changes resulting from new codes and feedback received by CMS. Providers are advised to ensure their billing staff is aware of these updates.

next_steps.action: Inform billing staff about the updated NCDs and ICD-10 codes

key_requirements: Update billing systems with new ICD-10 codes
Review NCD spreadsheets for CR 14194

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal announcing changes to the Laboratory National Coverage Determination (NCD) Edit Software for October 2025. It rescinds a previous transmittal to correct typographical errors in ICD-10 codes and effective dates. The changes are part of a quarterly update to ensure uniform processing of laboratory claims across the nation. The effective date for these changes is October 1, 2025, with implementation on October 6, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect new ICD-10 codes and effective dates.

key_requirements: Update ICD-10 code Z8411 instead of Z841
Change effective date to October 1, 2025, for BR 14153.5.3

source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The purpose of this CR is to announce the changes that will be included in the October 
2025 quarterly release of the edit module for clinical diagnostic laboratory services. This instruction 
communicates requirements to Shared System Maintainers (SSMs) and contractors, notifying them of changes to the laboratory edit module to update it for changes in laboratory NCD code lists for January 2025
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The purpose of this CR is to announce the changes that will be included in the October 
2025 quarterly release of the edit module for clinical diagnostic laboratory services. The NCDs for clinical 
diagnostic laboratory services were developed by the laboratory negotiated rulemaking committee, and the final rule was published on November 23, 2001. Nationally uniform software was developed and incorporated in the Medicare shared systems so that laboratory claims subject to one of the 23 NCDs (Publication 100-03, Sections 190.12 - 190.34) were processed uniformly throughout the nation, effective 
April 1, 2003. 
B. Policy: In accordance with Chapter 16, §120.2, Publication 100-04, the laboratory edit module is 
updated quarterly as necessary to reflect ministerial coding updates and substantive changes to the NCDs 
developed through the NCD process. The changes are a result of coding analysis decisions developed under the procedures for maintenance of codes in the negoti

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal that rescinds and replaces a previous transmittal to update Chapter 10 of CMS Pub. 100-08 by removing gender references. The changes are effective from May 5, 2025, and primarily involve updates to manual instructions related to various healthcare roles and facilities.

agreements.)  Given this, the contractor shall v erify that the OTP submitted a signed and dated 
Form CMS -1561 with its initial enrollment package. The provider agreement must be signed by 
an authorized or delegated official (as those t erms are defined in § 424.502) of the OTP; the 
signature can be handwritten or digital. This form may be accepted via mail, fax, email, or document upload.  The legal business name on the Form CMS -1561 must match that on the

applicable, the ownership transfer still qualifies as a change in majority ownership for purposes of the 36-month clock.  To illustrate, assume that an HHA initially enrolled in Medicare effective July 1, 2010.  It underwent a change in majority ownership effective February 1, 2012.  The contractor determined that the transaction was exempt from § 424.550(b)(1) because the HHA submitted full cost reports in the previous 2 years.  On February 1, 2014, the HHA underwent another change in majority ownership that did not qualify for an exception.  The HHA thus had to enroll as a new HHA under § 424.550(b)(1) because the transaction occurred within 36 months of the HHA’s most recent change in majority ownership - even though the February 2012 change was exempt from § 424.550(b)(1).

When determining whether a location is considered an administrative location or a community setting, MDPP suppliers must consider w
source_citations.context:
When determining whether a location is considered an administrative location or a community setting, MDPP suppliers must consider whether their organizational entity is the primary user of that space and whether coaches are based or dispatched from this location. If so, the location would be considered an administrative location, even if this location dually provides other services benefiting the community. In comparison, community settings are locations not primarily associated with the supplier where many activities occur, including MDPP services; that is, a community setting is a location where the supplier furnishes MDPP services outside of its administrative locations in a meeting location that is open to the public but not primar ily associated with the supplier.  
 An MDPP supplier must update its enrollment application with locations where services are furnished in community settings. While these settings are not subject to site visits, they serve as a form of recordkeeping a

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the annual update for influenza vaccine payment allowances for the 2025-2026 season, effective from August 1, 2025. It specifies that the payment allowances are based on 95% of the Average Wholesale Price (AWP) and are applicable to Medicare Part B. The update also clarifies that the payment allowances for pneumococcal vaccines are updated quarterly. The document provides guidance for Medicare Administrative Contractors regarding the implementation of these changes.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect new payment allowances for influenza vaccines.

key_requirements: Contractors shall determine the Medicare Part B payment allowance for influenza vaccines based on 95% of AWP.
All providers must take assignment on the claim for the vaccine.

virus vaccines in the CMS Seasonal Influenza Vaccines Pricing webpage: 
https://www.cms.gov/medicare/medicare -part-b-drug-average -sales -price/vacci ne-pricing.  
Seasonal Influenza Vaccines  payment is based on 95 percent of the Average Wholesale Price (AWP). The 
Medicare Part B payment allowances  apply for the dates indicated as effective dates on the website.  
Payment allowances for codes for which products have not yet been approved will be provided when the 
products have been approved and pricing information becomes available to CMS.  
The payment allowances for pneumococcal vaccines are also based on 95 percent of the AWP and are updated on a quarterly basis via the Quarterly Average Sales Price (ASP) Drug Pricing Files.

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document is a CMS transmittal updating hospice payment rates, wage index, and Pricer for FY 2026, effective October 1, 2025. It also updates the hospice aggregate cap amount, following the methodology extended by recent legislative acts. These updates are part of the annual adjustments required by the Social Security Act, using the inpatient hospital market basket adjusted for productivity and other factors.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to reflect new hospice payment rates and cap amounts.

key_requirements: Update hospice payment rates and wage index for FY 2026.
Adjust hospice aggregate cap amount as per the extended methodology.

source_citations.claim: The document is a CMS transmittal updating hospice payment rates, wage index, and Pricer for FY 2026, effective October 1, 2025
source_citations.supporting_text:
The FY 2026 hospice payment rates are effective for care and services furnished on or after October 
1, 2025, through September 30, 2026. The revised payment rates and wage index will be incorporated into the Hospice Pricer and forwarded to the Medicare contractors
source_citations.context:
A. Background: Payment rates for hospice care, the hospice cap amount, and the hospice wage index are 
updated annually.  
The law governing payment for hospice care requires annual updates to the hospice payment rates. Payment 
rates are updated annually according to section 1814(i)(1)(C)(ii)(VII) of the Social Security Act ("the Act"), which requires CMS to use the inpatient hospital market basket, adjusted for Multifactor Productivity (MFP) and other adjustments as specified in the Act, to determine the hospice payment update percentage.  
The hospice cap amount is updated annually in accordance with § 1814(i)(2)(B) of the Act and provides for an increase (or decrease) in the hospice cap amount. For accounting years that end after September 30, 2016 
and before October 1, 2025, the hospice ca p is updated by the hospice payment update percentage. After FY 
2025, the annual update to the cap amount would have reverted to the original methodology that updates the cap amount by the C

source_citations.claim: It also updates the hospice aggregate cap amount, following the methodology extended by recent legislative acts
source_citations.supporting_text:
After FY 
2025, the annual update to the cap amount would have reverted to the original methodology that updates the cap amount by the Consumer Price Index (CPI). Before the enactment of this provision, the hospice cap update was set to revert to the original methodology of updating the annual cap amount by the CPI –U beginning on October 1, 2032

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document provides an update on hospice payments for FY 2026, including changes to payment rates, inpatient and aggregate caps, and the hospice wage index. The payment update is set at 2.6%, with a reduction for hospices not meeting quality reporting requirements. The hospice cap amount is updated to $35,361.44, and a 5% cap on wage index decreases is maintained. These changes are effective from October 1, 2025, and are part of ongoing adjustments to reflect local wage differences and quality reporting compliance.

next_steps.action: Ensure billing staff are informed about the FY 2026 hospice updates.

key_requirements: Update billing systems to reflect new payment rates and caps.
Ensure compliance with quality reporting requirements to avoid payment reductions.

source_citations.context:
Hospice Payments: FY 2026 Update  
Page 1 of 3 Related CR Release Date:  July 31, 2025  MLN Matters Number:  MM14190  
Effective Date:  October 1, 2025  Related Change Request (CR) Number:  CR 14190
Implementation Date:  October 6, 2025  Related CR Transmittal Number:  R13331CP  
Related CR Title:  Update to Hospice Payment Rates, Hospice Cap, Hospice Wage Index and 
Hospice Pricer for Fiscal Year (FY) 2026  
Affected Providers 
● Hospices  
● Other providers billing Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) for hospice services 
Action Needed  
Make sure your billing staff knows about these FY 2026 hospice updates effective October 1, 2025:  
● Payment rates  
● Inpatient and aggregate caps  
● Wage index  
Background 
CMS updates payment rates for hospice care, the hospice cap amount, and the hospice wage index 
annually. We use the inpatient hospital market basket, which we adjust for multifactor productivity

source_citations.claim: 44, and a 5% cap on wage index decreases is maintained
source_citations.supporting_text:
To help reduce any significant 
negative impacts on hospices because of this transition, we calculated the permanent 5% cap on 
decreases on the county level as well as the CBSA level so individual counties moving to a new area didn’t experience more than a 5% decrease in wage index from the previous FY. For FY 2026, we’ll continue to calculate the 5% cap on wage index decreases at the county level

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates for the Fiscal Year 2026 regarding Medical Severity Diagnosis Related Groups (MS-DRGs) under the Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) for replaced devices offered without cost or with a credit. It adds MS-DRGs 209 and 213 to the list subject to this policy, with no removals. The changes are effective from October 1, 2025, and implementation is set for October 6, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate new MS-DRGs 209 and 213.

key_requirements: Update the list of MS-DRGs subject to IPPS payment policy.
Ensure compliance with the new policy for replaced devices offered without cost or with a credit.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines updates for the Fiscal Year 2026 regarding Medical Severity Diagnosis Related Groups (MS-DRGs) under the Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) for replaced devices offered without cost or with a credit
source_citations.supporting_text:
Pol
icy: The following are added to the list of MS-DRGs subject to the policy for reducing payment for
replaced devices offered without cost or with a credit:
•209- Complex Aortic Arch Procedures
•213- Endovascular Abdominal Aorta with Iliac Branch Procedures
The following MS-DRGs have conforming title changes: 
•023- Craniotomy with Major Device Implant or Acute Complex CNS Principal Diagnosis with MCC
or Antineoplastic Implant or Epilepsy with Neurostimulator
•024- Craniotomy with Major Device
source_citations.context:

payme nt for specified MS-DRGs, when t he implantation of a device is replaced wit hout c ost or with a credit 
equa l to 50 perce nt or m ore of t he cos t of the replaceme nt device. Ne w MS-DRG s are added to t he list, 
subjec t to the IPP S payment pol icy for replaced device s offered wit hout c ost or w ith a credit, when they are 
formed fr om p rocedure s assigned to MS-DRG s that were previously on t he list.

offered wit hout c ost or with a credit.  N o MS-DRGs a re being remov ed from the lis t.

icy: The following are added to the list of MS-DRGs subject to the policy for reducing payment for

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines updates to the Medicare Severity Diagnosis-Related Groups (MS-DRGs) under the Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) for Fiscal Year 2026. It specifies the addition of two new MS-DRGs related to complex aortic and endovascular procedures, which are subject to reduced payments when devices are replaced without cost or with a significant credit. The document also includes conforming title changes for two existing MS-DRGs and provides a comprehensive list of affected MS-DRGs.

next_steps.action: Update billing systems to reflect new MS-DRGs and title changes

key_requirements: Incorporate new MS-DRGs into billing processes
Ensure compliance with updated IPPS payment policies

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines the continuation of system changes to automate the processing of inpatient claims for Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T-Cell and other immunotherapy cases. The changes involve the automation of applying condition code ZD to claims, indicating a payment adjustment factor for cases where the product was not purchased in the usual manner. This is part of the Fiscal Intermediary Shared System (FISS) updates, effective October 1, 2025, with implementation on October 6, 2025.

next_steps.action: Review and update billing systems to accommodate the new automation process for CAR T-Cell claims.

key_requirements: Automate the application of condition code ZD for CAR T-Cell claims.
Ensure systems are updated to reflect changes by the implementation date.

source_citations.claim: The document outlines the continuation of system changes to automate the processing of inpatient claims for Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T-Cell and other immunotherapy cases
source_citations.supporting_text:
Background: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) created MS -DRG 018 "Chimeric 
Antigen Receptor (CAR) T -Cell Immunotherapy" in Fiscal Year (FY) 2021 for cases that include procedures 
describing CAR -T cell therapies. Beginning FY 2022, the title was revised to "Chimeric Antigen Receptor 
(CAR) T -Cell and Other  Immunotherapies"
source_citations.context:
A. Background: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) created MS -DRG 018 "Chimeric 
Antigen Receptor (CAR) T -Cell Immunotherapy" in Fiscal Year (FY) 2021 for cases that include procedures 
describing CAR -T cell therapies.  Beginning FY 2022, the title was revised to "Chimeric Antigen Receptor 
(CAR) T -Cell and Other  Immunotherapies".  A DRG  weight  adjustment  factor  is applied  to claims  that group  to 
MS-DRG 018 for clinical trial and expanded access use immunotherapy cases, where the immunotherapy 
product is not purchased in the usual manner.  
 
CMS recently became aware that there  are other instances in which the immunotherapy product is not 
purchased in the usual manner, such as provided at no cost. Beginning in FY 2026, in cases where the 
immunotherapy product  is not purchased  in the usual  manner,  such as provided  at no cost, the payment 
adjustment will be applied.

document_info.title: HHS Advances Women’s Health, Removes Misleading FDA Warnings on Hormone Replacement Therapy

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has announced the removal of misleading FDA warnings on hormone replacement therapy (HRT) as part of its efforts to advance women's health. This decision is based on updated research indicating that previous warnings may have overstated the risks associated with HRT. The change aims to improve access to HRT for women who may benefit from it, particularly in managing menopausal symptoms. This move is expected to influence healthcare providers' prescribing practices and patient education regarding HRT.

next_steps.action: Review and update clinical guidelines and patient education materials related to hormone replacement therapy.

key_requirements: Update clinical guidelines
Educate staff on new HRT information

document_info.title: CMS Announces New Drug Payment Model to Strengthen Medicaid and Better Serve Vulnerable Americans

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has introduced a new drug payment model aimed at enhancing Medicaid services and supporting vulnerable populations. This model seeks to improve drug affordability and access by restructuring payment methodologies. It is part of a broader initiative to ensure that Medicaid beneficiaries receive necessary medications without financial barriers. The model is expected to streamline processes and reduce costs for both providers and patients.

next_steps.action: Review and adjust billing processes to align with the new payment model.

key_requirements: Adopt new payment methodologies
Ensure compliance with updated Medicaid guidelines

document_info.title: All 50 States Seek to Transform Rural Health with CMS

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The document outlines a collaborative initiative involving all 50 states and the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) to enhance healthcare delivery in rural areas. The initiative aims to address challenges such as access to care, workforce shortages, and financial sustainability. It emphasizes the use of innovative payment models and telehealth to improve outcomes and reduce costs. The effort is part of a broader strategy to ensure equitable healthcare access across the United States.

next_steps.action: Evaluate current rural health programs and identify areas for integration with CMS initiatives.

key_requirements: Adoption of new payment models
Implementation of telehealth services

document_info.title: FDA Acts to Protect Children from Unapproved Fluoride Drug Products

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The FDA has taken action to protect children from unapproved fluoride drug products that are being marketed without proper authorization. These products have not been evaluated for safety and efficacy, posing potential health risks to children. The FDA's initiative aims to ensure that all fluoride products meet the necessary regulatory standards to safeguard public health.

next_steps.action: Review and identify any unapproved fluoride products in use

key_requirements: Ensure all fluoride products are FDA-approved
Discontinue use of unapproved fluoride products

document_info.title: FDA Moves to Accelerate Biosimilar Development and Lower Drug Costs

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The FDA has announced new measures to expedite the development of biosimilar drugs, aiming to increase market competition and reduce drug costs. This initiative includes streamlined regulatory processes and enhanced guidance for manufacturers. The goal is to make biosimilars more accessible, thereby lowering healthcare expenses for patients and providers. The FDA's efforts are part of a broader strategy to improve drug affordability and accessibility in the United States.

next_steps.action: Review and update procurement strategies to include biosimilars

key_requirements: Adopt new FDA guidelines for biosimilar approval
Implement cost-reduction strategies for drug procurement

document_info.title: FDA Awards First-Ever National Priority Vouchers to Nine Sponsors

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The FDA has awarded the first-ever National Priority Vouchers to nine sponsors, marking a significant milestone in incentivizing the development of drugs for rare diseases. These vouchers are intended to expedite the review process for future drug applications, potentially bringing critical treatments to market more quickly. This initiative is part of a broader effort to address unmet medical needs and encourage innovation in the pharmaceutical industry.

next_steps.action: Review the implications of the National Priority Vouchers on drug approval timelines and adjust strategic planning accordingly.

key_requirements: Understand the criteria for National Priority Vouchers
Assess the impact on drug approval processes

document_info.title: CDC Immunization Schedule Adopts Individual-Based Decision-Making for COVID-19 and Standalone Vaccination for Chickenpox in Toddlers

primary_analysis.detailed_summary: The CDC has updated its immunization schedule to incorporate individual-based decision-making for COVID-19 vaccinations, allowing healthcare providers to tailor recommendations based on patient-specific factors. Additionally, the schedule now includes a standalone chickenpox vaccine for toddlers, separating it from the MMRV combination. These changes aim to enhance personalized care and improve vaccination rates among young children.

next_steps.action: Review and update vaccination protocols to align with the new CDC schedule.

key_requirements: Implement individual-based decision-making for COVID-19 vaccinations
Administer standalone chickenpox vaccine for toddlers
